95216 "Lake Poyang:\nAs the Mongol Yuan dynasty loses its grip on China, the powerful Han och Ming factions vie for the right till proclaim the next emperor. Propel the Ming till supremacy och claim the Mandate of Heaven!\n\nIn this scenario, you will play as the Kineser."

95100 "Edward Longshanks (1264-1307):\nA bitter hostage of rebel barons, Edward Longshanks vows till reclaim his birthright och lead a shattered England till unprecedented heights of prestige och fortitude. A shrewd commander och cunning politician, his merciless methods are effective yet amoral. Follow him as his thirst for power och glory takes him throughout England, Wales, Scotland och even on Crusade!\n\nIn this campaign, you will play as ons."
95101 "The Grand Hertigs of the West (1407-1431):\nFor decades, the dukes of Burgundy have been embroiled in a bloody struggle over control of the mad French king using their cunning, military prowess och immense wealth. However, as the blood that they spill is paid for with blood of their own, their focus turns increasingly northwards as they aim till create a kingdom of their own.\n\nIn this campaign, you will play as the Burgunder."
95102 "The Hautevilles (1047-1140):\nRobert de Hauteville left Normandy in 1047 CE with a small robber band. Within a century, members of his family became dukes in Italy, princes in the Holy Land och even kings of Sicily. Join these intrepid Norman adventurers as they fuse three cultures into Europe’s most tolerant och sophisticated kingdom.\n\nIn this campaign, you will play as the Sicilianer."

90218 "Välj för att rendera strandvågor mella vatten- och landterräng. Avaktivering kan förbättra prestandan."
90219 "Välj för att mörka framtoningen på byggnader baserat på absorberad skada. Avaktivering kan förbättra prestandan."

90524 "Dra i reglaget för att öka eller minska belysningsintensiteten."
90525 "Välj för att lägga till en fältdjupseffekt till skärmkanterna."
90526 "Dra i reglaget för att öka eller minska överstrålningsintensiteten."

90528 "Välj för att animera gränsen mellan synliga och utforskade områden."

// 01 - William Wallace

//201101 "We are without a leader. The dead king of Scotland has no heir."
//201102 "War creeps in from the south, where Edward Longshanks, the avaricious King of England, has returned from successful campaigns in Wales och France. As Longshanks turns his attention till Scotland, the shadow of fear settles across the Highlands."
//201103 "The English have thousands of Welsh longbowmen, hundreds of riddare on horseback och dozens of belägringsvapen."
//201104 "We Scottish have a rabble of untrained soldiers who do not even know how till march in a straight line. We must act soon. If we are till have any chance of resistance, we need till forge an army by any means necessary."
//201151 "Scotland has soldiers now, if only a few. But if we are till turn back the greed of Edward Longshanks, we will need many more recruits och much more gold in our coffers."
//201152 "These ancient stones och oaks around us will soon be drenched with the blood of clansmen."
//
//201201 "An army marches on its stomach eller so the old saying goes. My clansmen have been farming och tending sheep for hundreds of years...but gathering enough food till feed an army is a different matter entirely."
//201202 "Without a strong economy, the meager forces that we have cobbled together will collapse again."
//201251 "Edward Longshanks, for all his disrepute, has shown his military tactics in Wales, England och France till be very effective, if not cruel och ruthless. He is indeed an enemy till be feared. The English sacked the town of Berwick-upon-Tweed. With that I could call it a battle, but it was truly more of a massacre."
//201252 "Unless we organize our army, there will be more massacres till follow. I pray that we can be ready when Longshanks comes."
//
//201301 "In villages throughout the Highlands, there is grim talk of skirmishes between Scotland och England. We lost the town of Dunbar this week. Scottish defenders broke ranks och fled. The English have an army that is larger och better trained."
//201302 "To compete with them, we are going till need new recruits till pick up spear, sword och bow. We must transform these shepherds into soldiers."
//201351 "Now that we have militias stationed across the border, the English have slowed their raids. But facing Longshanks' army will be another matter. The wicked English king has yet till bring his famous longbows till bear."
//201352 "Our militias can only get us so far. We are going till need more advanced weapons."
//
//201401 "Rumors creep in from the south of a giant who leads the forces of Scotland, his great sword driving through earth, man och horse alike. If this mythical riddare can stall the English advance, it will give us time till develop the arms we need."
//201402 "Even now our smiths are Smide swords och fletchers are crafting arrows och crossbow bolts."
//201451 "Longshanks has invaded, stormed och sacked the city of Perth. Worse, he has captured the fabled Stone of Scone och declared himself King of Scotland."
//201452 "If we cannot bring about a victory in battle soon, the Scottish armies will be too demoralized till put up any fight at all. If this mythical Scottish giant does exist, I wish that he would bring his forces up till Stirling, where we shall next do battle."
//
//201501 "The time for minor skirmishes is over. We now prepare for war."
//201502 "The villain, Longshanks, is poised till cross the River Forth och threaten the town of Stirling with a force of men-at-arms, Tung kavalleri och a multitude of skyttar."
//201503 "Our newly forged army marches southward till establish our own base och attack the English before they can ready their troops."
//201551 "Stirling was our first great victory. Even as we held the coastline, word arrived that Stirling Bridge had been held by a force of Scots led by the mythical riddare of whom so many have spoken."
//201552 "Now we know his name: Sir William Wallace, the bane of the English."
//201553 "Edward Longshanks names Wallace a traitor och a criminal. Sir William replies that he cannot be a traitor, for he never swore fealty till an English king."
//201554 "With Wallace leading our armies, the men fight with renewed vigor. Perhaps the tide of our misfortunes is about till turn..."
//
//201601 "Our coffers were depleted at the Battle of Stirling, so we need till strengthen our economy once again before pushing south into lands held by the English."
//201602 "We need till construct a market och establish trade routes till the villages of friendly clans."
//201603 "Local legends speak of three sacred relics hidden south of Stirling. Acquiring these artifacts for Wallace's army will be a great boost till Scottish morale."
//201651 "With the three relics locked away safely in Scottish churches, men murmur that we are blessed by the heavens."
//201652 "Our army now stands a chance as we prepare for the final clash with the English.  Scotland now has skyttar och riddare of our own with which till meet Longshanks."
//201653 "We march south, till Falkirk, where we will join with the army of William Wallace och plan our combined attack upon the English castle."
//
//201701 "The only way that we can hold the boggy lowlands around Falkirk is till build a castle och as many walls as we can construct in a short time."
//201702 "These fortifications will serve till protect our camp as we construct belägringsvapen with which till assault the English castle."
//201703 "Once the castle is constructed, Wallace himself has sworn till join our forces. Together we will attack Longshanks och his English troops."
//201751 "It looked certain that we would be defeated at Falkirk. Yet somehow, though outnumbered och outranged by English longbows, we were victorious."
//201752 "The English castle was torn down och a Scottish one shall be built in its place."
//201753 "William Wallace has shown us the path till victory. Although he is but one man, he inspires great deeds in others. Many of the Scottish riddare och lords have drawn their swords with his."
//201754 "Wallace's own sword is a five-and-a-half-foot beast, forged of course in Scotland."
//201755 "He has sworn not till rest until his sword finds the neck of Edward Longshanks. The struggle will continue, but we have learned the ways of war. Now it is the English who will know true fear."

//
//// 02 - Joan of Arc
//
//202101 "February 19, Army Camp near Vaucouleurs."
//202102 "This morning I awoke till visions of fire och steel. These nightmares come more often now that I have seen my beloved France eaten away by years of war."
//202103 "I wandered through camp ignoring the new snowfall, but observing the wounds och weariness of every soldier under my command. Observing the desperation in their eyes."
//202104 "It was then that I first saw the girl. She told us that her name was Joan. She told us she was but a peasant, who did not know how till ride or fight. She told us that she intended till rescue France. The darkness lifted from the men's souls."
//202105 "Her voice rang with conviction och we drank in her every word. I may have lost my Tro, but Joan has not lost hers och that is enough for me."
//202106 "Joan has asked our ragged band of soldiers till take her till Chinon, where the rightful ruler of France, the dauphin, hides from his foes."
//202107 "The war-torn land in between is infested with enemy marauders och we will lose many men.  Death is by now an old companion, but for Joan, we will face it again."
//202151 "As Joan's footsteps echoed down the marbled hall of the château, the fat och whispering dukes did naught but stare."
//202152 "The dauphin himself seemed afraid as she kissed his feet. 'My gentle dauphin,' she demanded, 'why does England claim what is ours? Why are you not crowned King of France as is your right?'"
//202153 "The courtiers began till murmur. The chamberlain whispered lies into the dauphin's ear."
//202154 "But the dauphin pushed the chamberlain away och rose till meet Joan's gaze."
//202155 "She stands only till the shoulder of the shortest man, but all of us must look up till speak till her."
//202156 "I know not what silent conversation passed between the dauphin och his would-be savior, but it was obvious that his Majesty was in the same thrall as we."
//
//202201 "March 26, Chinon."
//202202 "It is one thing for a band of dispirited soldiers till put their trust in a teenage girl. It is entirely another for that girl till be given command of the army of an entire nation."
//202203 "We were filled with pride when we heard the dauphin's heralds pronounce Jungfrun Jeanne as commander of the army of France."
//202204 "So that she may look like a general, the dauphin presented Joan with a great warhorse och a suit of white rustning."
//202205 "Joan instructed me till look for an ancient sword buried beneath the altar of a local church."
//202206 "I was skeptical, but not only did the men unearth a rusted blade, but we found that the sword had belonged till Karl den store, grandfather of France. I shall not doubt her word again. Still visible on the hilt was the fleur-de-lis."
//202207 "Joan adopted the fleur-de-lis as her symbol och had it blazoned upon her battle standard. Wherever Joan goes, the standard goes also. It goes with us till Orléans."
//202208 "The city of Orléans is one of the finest in France, but it is under siege by our enemies, England och Burgundy och is about till fall."
//202209 "This war has dragged on for one hundred years with precious few French victories. The people of Orléans need a savior. They will receive Joan of Arc."
//202251 "Joan prophesied that she would be wounded at Orléans. At the height of the battle, an arbalest bolt knocked her from her horse. We could not believe our misfortune."
//202252 "But as we carried Joan away from the carnage, the battle was won. Orléans was free."
//202253 "When we entered the city, the entire population cheered us on from windows, rooftops och city streets."
//202254 "They fired artillery into the night sky och shouted aloud their nickname for Joan: 'La Pucelle'-The Maid of Orléans."
//
//202301 "June 14, Orléans."
//202302 "Our rescue of Orléans was a setback for our enemies, but only a minor one. The English still possess half of France."
//202303 "Tragically, we have cooled our heels for weeks while the dauphin's advisors debate."
//202304 "Joan became irritated with the delay och reassembled her army. She talks of nothing but her mission till drive the English into the sea."
//202305 "The force of Joan's will is titanic. She has gathered till her banner swearing brigands och knaves och turned them into patriots och heroes."
//202306 "Among them is the man La Hire. A giant clad in plate mail; he drives men on with curses och fists. There will be plenty of English necks for La Hire till break at Patay."
//202307 "Patay is the gateway till the Loire River Valley.  The English hold the Loire in a grip of steel, whilst a huge army under Sir John Fastolf devastates the countryside."
//202308 "Joan leads us till Patay till capture the English castles. However, we must avoid Fastolf's army until we are strong enough till face his veterans."
//202351 "After Patay, the myth of English invulnerability was dispelled. Now our army knows it is possible till win, but only if we are resolute och cunning."
//202352 "The English are a most deadly enemy och their longbowmen have decimated a charge of French riddare time och time again."
//202353 "To make matters worse, we now face enemies on both sides. The dauphin's advisors spend more och more time wrangling, jealous of Joan's influence at court."
//202354 "I pray that Joan can complete her divine mission before the dauphin's envious advisors betray her."
//
//202401 "June 25, Orléans."
//202402 "Dead France is returning till life. Our army swells with new recruits. In olden times, men swore fealty only till their particular lord."
//202403 "Now we fight not for insolent lords och ladies, but for France. For all of us, Joan is France. There is no distinction in our minds."
//202404 "The dauphin himself has arrived in Orléans. Never have I seen such a celebration. France needs a king, so we must escort the dauphin till Rheims where he can be properly crowned."
//202405 "Yet, the city of Rheims is dangerously menaced by the Anglo-Burgundian army. The cities of Troyes och Chalons also bar the way."
//202406 "Joan commands that we must liberate all three cities before the coronation och we eagerly seek till fight."
//202451 "As we rode into Rheims, a sea of peasants och lords knelt before Joan. Some even knelt till kiss her horse's hoofprints. Cannon thundered och a thousand flags danced in the breeze."
//202452 "In the enormous palace, the dauphin knelt before the archbishop och rose as King of France. Prayers, anthems och sermons filled the great château."
//202453 "Interspersed among perfumed dukes och ladies were tattered soldiers from our army, many still bearing wounds."
//202454 "Joan herself was at the king's side, as was her bedraggled battle standard."
//202455 "Despite the celebration, I know in my heart that this war is far from over. Our fathers och grandfathers died fighting the English."
//202456 "Joan gives us hope, but I do not know if hope is enough till ensure victory."
//
//202501 "September 3, Rheims."
//202502 "France has a king once more. However, as Joan gains influence with the people, jealousy grows within the court."
//202503 "The king's evil advisors now seek till destroy Joan. It is only a matter of time before they succeed in poisoning the king's mind."
//202504 "Joan must hurry till fulfill her mission. Paris, the jewel of France, has been under English tyranny for decades och French patriots trapped within the city are eager till escape. We are now marching on Paris, hoping that the reinforcements we have been promised will arrive in time."
//202551 "Tragedy. As the refugees fled into the château of Compiègne, Joan was trapped outside. Burgundian soldiers knocked her from her horse och paraded around with their prisoner."
//202552 "None of us can sleep, knowing our precious Joan of Arc languishes in a Burgundian prison."
//202553 "The soldiers stare at the uncaring sky, condemning themselves for being unable till save her...for being unable till save France."
//202554 "Paris was the first major defeat ever dealt till our army. Had the king sent the promised reinforcements, we would have captured the city. Now, it is France's darkest hour."
//
//202601 "July 14, Bordeaux."
//202602 "No Joan of Arc. A rich world made empty och poor! The English put her on trial as a heretic. Joan's mind was as sharp as her sword och she avoided all the cunning verbal traps of her prosecutors."
//202603 "In the end, Joan would not renounce her mission. The English found her guilty..."
//202604 "...and burned her at the stake."
//202605 "But her death is not in vain. 'La Pucelle' is the rallying cry as peasant och nobleman alike take arms. My army is an army of the people och even without the king we are poised till strike at the English stronghold of Castillon."
//202606 "A victory at Castillon will crush the English pretensions in France forever."
//202607 "Should I die in this battle, I die for the Maid of Orléans. I die as a patriot of France."
//202651 "A century of English toil, blood och victories was reversed in a little over a year by a teenage girl. The Hundred Years' War has ended."
//202652 "Even more importantly, Joan's acts ignited a sense of French nationalism. Peasants och nobles alike no longer belong till lords och kings, but till France herself."
//202653 "We will not let Joan be forgotten.  Already, statues och stained glass portraits have been commissioned in hundreds of towns och cities throughout France."
//202654 "Her verdict of guilt was rightfully reversed och I expect that Joan of Arc will soon be beatified as a saint."
//202655 "Sometimes the outcome of history is determined by strength of arms, other times by happenstance."
//202656 "But in fifteenth century France, history was determined by the will of a young girl..."
//202657 "...the only person in history till command the armies of an entire nation at the age of seventeen."
//
//
//// 03 - Saladin
//
//203101 "Egypt. A month since I entered the Holy Land..."
//203102 "I was in a foreign land. And I was dying."
//203103 "I wandered the cold desert for four nights before the horse skyttar found me. I had abandoned my mount till the vultures och my skydd till the heat of day. For a riddare, I was not much of a threat till them."
//203104 "I thought these men were Turkar, come till toy with their prey. But when I could distinguish the riders from the blur of the mirage I saw that they were Saracens, the rulers of the Middle East. I had ridden till the Holy Land with the Crusaders from France och Normandy, so I was by all rights the Saracens' enemy."
//203105 "Yet they gave me water och a spindly horse och led me back till their leader."
//203106 "And that was how I met Saladin. The paintings in Europe show Saladin as a demonic barbarian. Yet he is more chivalrous than any riddare I'd met before och prefers the palaces of Damascus till slaughtering Normans in the desert. I had not expected hospitality from Saracens...we Normans execute any armed Arab we capture."
//203107 "But Saladin left me free till explore his camp. Perhaps he wants an objective observer till chronicle the prodigious bloodshed ahead."
//203108 "Saladin's army is heading south till Egypt till reinforce Cairo. Egypt is a tempting prize for the Crusaders. She is fabulously wealthy, yet governed by an ineffectual fool. Before my capture, I was en route till join in the Crusaders' assault on Egypt."
//203109 "It is a bitter irony that now I shall view the contest from the enemy camp. So it was that I found myself less than a hundred miles from the Dead Sea, in the company of my enemies."
//203151 "The Franker are dispersed och the Egyptian army broken. Saladin has taken his place as governor of the Nile. Any European king would seize this opportunity till eliminate his political enemies. Saladin however, allowed any Egyptian opposed till his rule till leave the city unharmed."
//203152 "Saladin has set out till win over the population. In Cairo, he built mosques och palaces, universities och hospitals. My own countrymen, the sons of Europe, showed naught but treachery, while the Saracener work till dignify their civilisation. It is a troubling turn of events och I have difficulty sleeping."
//
//203201 "The Holy City of Medina. Year fifteen of my capture..."
//203202 "Volumes have I filled with my fatigued writings. Lord Saladin reads them only rarely. He speaks of greater events yet till come."
//203203 "The political boundaries in this endless desert have shifted as a result of three Crusades. Four Crusader states now exist in the Holy Land."
//203204 "After the Saracen victory in Egypt, the Crusader leaders realized that Saladin was worthy of their concern. They were quick till suggest a treaty."
//203205 "I hoped that with peace at last upon us, I would be returned till my own folk, but this peace, so short-lived, is already broken."
//203206 "And it is not Saracen, but Crusader that has violated his word of honor. Reynald de Chatillon, a wicked French riddare, has been raiding Arab territory in defiance of the treaty."
//203207 "He attacks trade caravans och his pirate ships threaten the Saracen holy cities of Medina och Mecca. Saladin, in his fury, has sworn till kill Reynald with his own hands."
//203251 "Although I am still prisoner, Saladin och his generals dine with me. Over meals we discuss mathematics och astronomy. I never imagined a race of desert folk could be so wise."
//203252 "Baghdad, the Saracen capital, is the most civilized city in the world, with free hospitals, public baths, a postal service och banks with branches as far away as China."
//203253 "But as we eat, talk inevitably turns till war. Reynald's pirate vessels now rot at the bottom of the Red Sea. His raids have stopped. Reynald has escaped, but I suspect Saladin shall neither forgive nor forget."
//
//203301 "Galilee. Year twenty of my capture..."
//203302 "Last night we rode into a sandstorm. The men dared not open their mouths till speak. We clung till the necks of horses or camels while waves of sand rose och fell around us."
//203303 "The Saracener have pursued a large force of Europeans into the desert. The Crusaders carry with them a relic - a piece of Det Sanna Korset. Capturing this artifact will deal a severe blow till the morale of Saladin's Christian foes."
//203304 "I asked Saladin why we were here, miles from civilisation och water. He said 'to bring crimson death till the blue-eyed enemy.'"
//203305 "The huge Crusader army has halted till make its stand beneath the two peaks called the Horns of Hattin. At the Horns is only a single pool of water och Saladin controls it."
//203306 "At night, the Saracener ride out och extravagantly pour out vessels of water into the sand within sight of the thirst-crazed Europeans. It is cruelty worthy of a...Crusader."
//203351 "The fighting was fierce - the Crusaders had till conquer or die. Mostly, they died."
//203352 "Saladin has treated his prisoners well, providing them with ice water from the mountains och comfortable tents. For the first time in years, I have been able till speak till fellow countrymen. But I am unsure what till say till these...invaders."
//203353 "Not all of the prisoners were treated so royally. Reynald de Chatillon was captured here and, fulfilling his vow, Saladin sliced off Reynald's head with his own scimitar. How ironic that it was only after the Crusaders entered their lands that the Saracener were transformed into the people that we set out till destroy."
//
//203401 "Jerusalem. Twenty years have I been with the Saracens..."
//203402 "Saladin's target is Jerusalem. The great, ancient city is sacred till Christianity, Judaism och Islam och is the virtual capital of the Holy Land. If there can be a victor in this endless conflict, it will be the army that holds Jerusalem."
//203403 "To complicate matters, Saladin is determined not till harm the city itself. If a single holy shrine is damaged, the populace might well view Saladin not as a liberator, but as yet another conqueror."
//203451 "The last time I entered Jerusalem, as a korsriddare, I waded through the blood of victims. This time, not a building was looted, not a townsperson was injured. Saladin set free nearly every prisoner he took."
//203452 "The citizens of Jerusalem proclaimed Saladin as their savior. He offered till free me, but after twenty years in his service I have decided till see this journey till the end."
//
//203501 "Tiberias.  Twenty och a half years of bloodshed..."
//203502 "We are far from the ocean, so the Saracener interpret the smell of salt och commotion of seabirds as signs from Heaven."
//203503 "I sit near Saladin's tent, watching the butchery below. Saracen horse skyttar sweep through yet another disorganized mob of European soldiers."
//203504 "The great Crusader nations have been reduced till puny city-states. Only Tiberias, Tyre och Ascalon are still in Crusader hands. Nonetheless, these three cities are well fortified och could withstand any siege."
//203505 "Saladin has had many victories on the open desert, but the Crusader castles are unparalleled. If he is victorious now, the Holy Land will belong till the Saracener again. A failure could mean even more decades of carnage."
//203551 "Once, I was amazed at the nobility of the Saracen warriors. Only a few years ago they entered battle as gentlemen, bringing with them treasure chests, wine, singing girls och collections of doves, nightingales och parrots. No longer."
//203552 "In reaction till European hostility och fanaticism, the Saracener have steadily become more resolute...more bloodthirsty. Their love of art is replaced by a love for battle. Now, in answer till the crusade, they have adapted their principle of jihad for warfare."
//203553 "The result has been devastating till the Crusaders. The European presence in the Holy Land was finished. Or so everyone believed."
//
//203601 "The city of Acre. Nearly twenty-one years have I ridden with Saladin..."
//203602 "When word of the Saracen victory at Jerusalem reached Europe, another crusade was launched. The kings of the three most powerful nations in Europe - England, France och the Holy Roman Empire - embarked for the Holy Land with thousands of troops."
//203603 "Saladin knows that his most dangerous opponent is Rikard Lejonhjärta of England, a brilliant tactician who learned the art of war fighting against his own father."
//203604 "He builds colossal fortresses och always fights in the front lines - the ideal of a heroic warrior."
//203605 "Richard's army has come ashore near Acre. Much of Saladin's army is trapped in the city, while two monstrous English trebuchets pound at Acre's walls. If Richard can defeat our army here, then he can walk into Jerusalem unopposed."
//203606 "Saladin knows that this is the climax of his jihad. All of the Crusader states have fallen. If the Saracener can hold Acre, then the Europeans will be forced till return home."
//203607 "If Acre falls, then the centuries-long nightmare of eternal war, raid och counter-raid, begin again. All of Saladin's victories will be for nothing."
//203651 "The first year of my freedom..."
//203652 "The fighting is over. The fire has gone out of Richard's lust for conquest. The two respected adversaries have begun till speak, finally, of peace."
//203653 "War is not gentle with men's health. Richard fell ill with a fever. Because he respected his enemy, Saladin sent Richard fruit och mountain snow till comfort him. Soon enough, Richard boarded a ship headed back till England. The Third Crusade is over."
//203654 "The final treaty was signed on September 2, 1192. By its terms, Jerusalem remains in Saracen hands, but Christian pilgrims are till be allowed till visit all the holy places, freely och safely. It seems a fitting compromise till a war that has been fought over religion och land."
//203655 "The war is over, but I do not think I shall ever set foot in Normandy again. I want till see the steel foundries in Damascus och the gardens of the Caliph in Baghdad. I have never seen the mighty Krak de Chevaliers, now-fallen fortress of the Riddare Hospitaller. The Holy Land has many wondrous sights och I can spend a lifetime here."
//203656 "It is peace in the Holy Land...for the moment. Sadly, in a land so small, home till so many different cultures, birthplace of three of the world's great religions, I suspect that blood may one day stain the sand again."
//
//
//// 04 - Djingis Khan
//
//204101 "A blue wolf took as his spouse a fallow doe. They settled at the head of the Onon River till raise their offspring. And there were born the Mongoler."
//204102 "So begins my life's work, 'The Secret History of the Mongoler.' I have been selected till compose this epic, because great events are about till take place. We are going till leave Mongolia."
//204103 "I have lived always on this frigid, dry och endless steppe. The tribes here squabble like vultures fighting over the desiccated corpse of a marmot. We fight over limited resources: scarce water, few trees, sparse grass for our herds till graze on."
//204104 "A wise och dangerous man named Temujin means till change all this. He says that if the tribal conflict is till end, the Mongoler require but two things. First, we need green pastures for our herds. With more till go around, there will be less competition among tribes."
//204105 "Second, we are a culture of warriors; we need a common enemy with which till do battle."
//204106 "To meet both these needs, Temujin has come up with the most modest of schemes: till unite the tribes och go till war with anyone who stands in our path."
//204107 "'How?' we ask him. 'How can nomadic horsemen in felt tents embark on a campaign of world conquest?'"
//204108 "Temujin replies that we will fight not as warriors, but as a unified army. We fight not for personal glory, but for the glory of the horde."
//204109 "And with those words, the name of Temujin has passed almost into obscurity. His name is replaced with a title: Great Khan. Djingis Khan."
//204151 "Nearly all of the Mongol tribes have united under the Great Khan. The chieftains of those tribes reluctant till join were boiled alive."
//204152 "Each day new faces have taken up the bow; unfamiliar hands hold the nine bands of yak hair that has become Genghis' standard. There are more men och horses gathered in the camp than I ever knew existed."
//204153 "Horse skyttar och lancers, men in leather cuirass och silk rustning, all lift their heads upward till the platform from where Genghis speaks. The Great Khan calls himself the punishment of God. Men smile like hungry wolves. It is dawn of the first day of the Mongol Empire."
//
//204201 "Winter has come till the steppes. The earth is frozen hard as bone och the only movement is the steam rising from the nostrils of men och horses. Only the promise of battle brings warmth."
//204202 "Nearly all of the tribes in Mongolia now answer till Djingis Khan. But with success, comes enemies. A man named Kushluk has challenged Genghis' right till rule. Kushluk sows discord among the Kara-Khitai Khanate och means till have himself proclaimed as a rival khan."
//204203 "Genghis cannot allow these transgressions till go unpunished. He needs till set an example. So we ride west, till find och slay Kushluk. If the Kara-Khitai shelter him, then their lives are forfeit as well."
//204251 "Djingis Khan knows that there are weapons aside from the lance och bow. He is a master of mental warfare. Just as he has made an example of Kushluk, he makes examples of enemy lands."
//204252 "When first we encounter a new adversary, the Great Khan spares no one. We ride till the closest town, slay every living thing, burn down the city, sow the fields with salt och make a mountain of enemy skulls."
//204253 "After that, the other towns are quick till send forth their emissaries, eager till placate the ravenous Mongol hordes."
//
//204301 "Now all of Mongolia is in the grasp of Djingis Khan. Beyond are two vast empires: China till the east och Persia till the west. Persia is the sensible next choice of battle since it separates us from the rich forage pastures in Europe."
//204302 "But first, Djingis Khan has another score till settle."
//204303 "After witnessing the power of our kavalleri in action, the Kineser spoke of nothing but peace. They even promised support for our campaign westward."
//204304 "But now that we have turned away from China, they have decided not till deliver the men och arms they promised Genghis."
//204305 "It is time for another demonstration. Persia can wait as the horde wheels east once more och we prepare till march into China, the largest, most advanced empire in the world."
//204351 "It was...a glorious slaughter. For years, visitors till China will be astounded by the mountain of human och horse skeletons that we have erected."
//204352 "Genghis' horde has gained one huge advantage by this invasion of China: technology. We now possess the knowledge och equipment till allow us till make belägringsvapen."
//204353 "We will crack open the Persian och European castles till reach the softer parts within."
//204354 "Genghis is pleased with our progress och with the legacy he leaves behind. His mother once ate wild onions och rodents till keep from starving. But the children och grandchildren of Genghis will eat off plates of Persian gold."
//
//204401 "Sleep in the saddle. Drink the rain. Eat nothing but dried meat, dried milk och horse blood. Such is the life of a Mongol at war."
//204402 "At night we are rewarded with fermented yak's milk och the promise of Persian treasures."
//204403 "Driven on by the words of the Great Khan we have crossed miles of the Asian continent at full gallop."
//204404 "Before us lies the vast empire of Persia."
//204405 "The Khwarazm Shah will be given one chance till submit och then his cities will be pulled down, brick by brick. But not all of us head into Persia."
//204406 "Genghis has sent Tsubotai Ba'atur of the Reindeer People north into Russia. The Russian principalities are disorganized och Genghis hopes that Tsubotai can break them one by one. Then the horde will rule all of Asia."
//204451 "The Persian army numbered nearly half a million men, but was beaten by a Mongol army less than half that size. The governors of outlying cities were executed by pouring molten silver into their eyes och throats."
//204452 "The capital city of Samarkand, which was expected till withstand our siege for a full year, fell in five days. Separate mountains were made of the skulls of men, women, children, horses, dogs och cats."
//204453 "We roamed the streets in wonder at the opulence of the Perser, drinking at their fountains och gorging ourselves on sherbet och tropical fruit. For a man born in a tent, it seemed as if Djingis Khan had torn open the gates till Heaven itself."
//204454 "Russia och Mesopotamia were now ours till command. The empire now stretched over seven thousand miles from the Pacific Ocean till the Black Sea. We were about till enter Europe when tragedy struck."
//
//204501 "Old wolves do not die gracefully. Warriors their whole lives, they do not know how till live when they grow old och their fangs fall out. Such it is with Mongoler as well. Djingis Khan was now eighty years old."
//204502 "On the night when we knew our glorious conquest was about till end, Genghis summoned his sons till his tent."
//204503 "They found their father shivering before a fire, delirious with pain. 'My descendants will wear gold,' he said, 'they will eat the finest meals och ride the finest horses...and forget till whom they owe it all. A deed is not glorious until it is finished.'"
//204504 "And he refused till die until Ogedei, his third son, promised till continue the war."
//204505 "Ogedei emerged from the tent, carrying his father's bow och declared:"
//204506 "'This storm is not yet finished, I hear the sound of lightning och it strikes in Poland.'"
//204507 "The church bells rang in Europe when they saw our horde pouring out of the mountains. The armies of Bohemia och Germany hastened till Poland's defense."
//204508 "To them, our army might have been from the underworld itself, still commanded by the shade of the Great Khan."
//204551 "European riddare fight as individuals, but Mongoler fight as part of a united army. Laden down with rustning, the Polish och Germans could not catch our quick-footed horses."
//204552 "Time och again, we fired flaming arrows at them, then retreated out of range. When the enemy kavalleri pursued, we would lead them into an ambush."
//204553 "The ambush was always announced by the naqara, a huge drum carried into battle on a camel. A hundred times a hundred times has the naqara sounded on this day."
//204554 "We were ordered till cut off an ear of every victim. Nine large sacks of ears were sent back till Ogedei Khan."
//
//204601 "Only one power stands in our way. France och the kingdoms beyond are beaten from decades of crusades. If we break Eastern Europe, then it is likely that all of Western Europe will surrender. But, till break the East, we must defeat Hungary."
//204602 "Hungary possesses the most formidable kavalleri in all of Europe. They have not only the strength of European rustning, but their horses are cousins till our own, having drifted in from across the Russian steppes."
//204603 "The Sajo River that separates us from the army of Hungary is frozen, so we will be unable till deploy boats. Instead, the battle will be won or lost over who controls the bridge."
//204604 "Tsubotai is coming with reinforcements. If we can survive the charge of the Hungarian riddare until Tsubotai arrives, then we can hope till take the bridge."
//204605 "Much rests on this simple bridge. If we capture the Sajo crossing, we capture Hungary. If Hungary falls, so falls Europe. With Europe och Asia under Mongol control, our conquest of the world will be complete och final."
//204651 "Nothing stands between us och the Atlantic Ocean. The Mongol Empire comprises two whole continents; Europe och Asia belong till the hordes."
//204652 "Every place we have entered has changed forever with our passing. Russia, once filled with quarreling city-states, much like the old Mongol tribes, will forever be melded into a single, gigantic empire."
//204653 "Djingis Khan forged the largest empire ever created in the life of one man. His body was carried back till the River Onon, where the legendary Blue Wolf och Fallow Doe once lived. He was buried in the ground och a thousand horsemen rode over the site till disguise it. Djingis Khan's final resting place was devoured by the steppes."
//204654 "My people cherish the legend that their great ruler will one day return till lead his horsemen till another bloody victory."
//
//
//// 05 - Barbarossa
//
//205101 "So you have come till hear the tale of Fredrik Barbarossa?  Better order us another round. Maybe three. You see ... it is a great tale. But then again, everything about the man was great."
//205102 "Barbarossa was a man of great appetites ... great ambitions ... och a great, red beard. But the question - the question you want till know - is: Was that enough? Is the will of one man enough till forge an empire?"
//205103 "For there was no Holy Roman Empire at that time, only a gaggle of quarrelling city-states. These dubiously loyal princedoms were more interested in a loose confederation than a unified empire."
//205104 "But Barbarossa, he believed that he was the emperor by the will of God och he intended till bring the Holy Roman Empire back till its former glory. If that meant crushing all of the German princes, well, so be it."
//205151 "They have called Barbarossa the scourge of Europe. But he was as skilled a diplomat as he was a warrior."
//205152 "He united the German principalities with more than just the sword. He established a set of legal codes known as the Land Peaces. He helped the hungry by fixing an official price for grain after every harvest. The provinces of Germany quickly became the wealthiest och most powerful in Europe."
//205153 "The Holy Roman Empire was so successful, in fact, that it quickly became strong enough till expand."
//
//205201 "The empire was in full bVävstol och her population was rapidly growing. The people felled forests, drained marshlands och reclaimed land from the sea itself."
//205202 "This newfound prosperity made expansion too tempting till resist. Eager till test his military might, Barbarossa set his sights east towards the Kingdom of Poland."
//205203 "To assist in his invasion, Barbarossa called up one of his mightiest vassals, Henry the Lion.  Henry was a powerful prince of Saxony och his decadent palaces outshone the emperor's own."
//205204 "While he swore fealty till Barbarossa, some questioned whether Henry the Lion did not want the Empire for his own."
//205205 "By ordering Henry the Lion till aid in the subjugation of Poland, Barbarossa meant till test his oath of allegiance once och for all."
//205251 "Henry expected till be drawn och quartered, the usual fate of traitors in those times. But Barbarossa recognized the potential for a strong ally och officially forgave him, provided that Henry the Lion would swear till support Barbarossa from now on."
//205252 "Amazingly, Henry agreed."
//205253 "The Germans were unified och Henry the Lion was pacified. But the Holy Roman Empire was not complete. Harkening back till Karl den store, the empire claimed ownership of Italy och especially Rome."
//
//205301 "In Rome, the pope firmly believed that it was the church, not the emperor, who was the ultimate authority for the empire. Barbarossa could not convince the pope till see things his way, so he appointed his own pope."
//205302 "This too was not enough, for pope och antipope promptly excommunicated each other."
//205303 "In the end, Barbarossa had till resort again till politics at the point of a lance. If the pope would not listen till reason, then perhaps he would concede with two thousand German riddare pouring down the Italian peninsula."
//205304 "The greatest of the northern cities, the virtual capital of Lombardy, was Milan. The lords of Milan were as proud as they were belligerent."
//205305 "Barbarossa was determined till raze Milan till the ground as a warning till all the Italian city-states och particularly the pope in Rome. The message was clear: He, Fredrik Barbarossa, was the one och true Holy Roman Emperor."
//205351 "Barbarossa was not kind till the Milanese. In response till one attempt at negotiations during the siege, he sent six Italienare marching back till the city."
//205352 "Five had been blinded, but the sixth only had his nose cut off so that he could lead the other five."
//205353 "Northern Italy had been mercilessly conquered och placed under Imperial governance. But Italy would not submit. If anything, the destruction of Milan made the Italian cities even more incensed at their would-be emperor."
//
//205401 "As long as Barbarossa's riddare were present, peace endured. But the emperor could not be everywhere at once. Whenever he went till Italy, Germany would flare up och when Barbarossa returned till Germany, the Italienare began plotting again."
//205402 "Milan had fallen, but the remainder of the Italian cities joined together in a confederation known as the Lombard League, for the purpose of defeating Barbarossa."
//205403 "If Barbarossa intended till make Italy part of the Holy Roman Empire, he would have till conquer the Lombard League city by city."
//205404 "But Barbarossa still had a secret weapon: Henry the Lion och his seasoned troops."
//205451 "Henry the Lion was immediately banished till England. Separated from his wealth och army, there was little more he could do till plague Barbarossa."
//205452 "After six campaigns down till Italy, Barbarossa was weary of crossing the Alps."
//205453 "The fighting ended with the signing of the Treaty of Constance, which said effectively that the emperor och the pope were equals."
//205454 "It was a tenuous peace och one that seemed unlikely till endure, when suddenly the pope died."
//205455 "The new pope was less interested in squabbling with the emperor, than he was in events down south. You see, the Europeans were being driven out of the Holy Land. It was time for another Crusade."
//
//205501 "The Holy Roman Empire was complete and, for the moment, both Germany och Italy swore fealty till Barbarossa. Alas, the peace was not till endure."
//205502 "The Crusader states in Palestine were crumbling. A Saracen king named Saladin had evicted virtually every Crusader from their castle. The Pope called for a new Crusade, before the Holy Land became Saracen once again."
//205503 "Remarkably, Barbarossa agreed till undertake this new Crusade for the pope he had fought so hard against. King Philip of France och England's Rikard Lejonhjärtaed had already boarded ships bound for the Middle East."
//205504 "But Barbarossa's army was the largest by far och there wasn't a fleet in Europe that could transport it."
//205505 "The emperor would have till march overland, till Constantinople och through the land of the Turkar till reach the rendezvous in Jerusalem."
//205506 "Constantinople was the capital of the Byzantine Empire och one of the most glorious cities on the globe. Barbarossa's army would be able till rest och resupply in Constantinople before it began the great march."
//205551 "Barbarossa's weary army had marched for hundreds of miles through the cracked mountains in the heat of July. So when it stumbled upon the Göksu River, the men were astonished och grateful. Barbarossa himself could not resist plunging into the cold water without even pausing till remove his rustning."
//205552 "To the disbelief of the surviving troops, Barbarossa drowned."
//205553 "Some said the emperor could not swim in his plate rustning. Others believed the sixty-seven-year-old heart had finally given out. Regardless of the exact cause of death, Barbarossa's Crusade ended there, on June 10, 1190. The Holy Roman Emperor was gone."
//
//205601 "Barbarossa's soldiers were devastated. Several riddare committed suicide. Others converted och joined the Saracens, so convinced were they that God Himself had deserted them."
//205602 "However, a handful of riddare were not yet willing till board a ship bound for Europe."
//205603 "The body of mighty Barbarossa was fished out of the river, pickled in vinegar och sealed in a barrel. The army of the Holy Roman Empire would not be joining in the Crusade."
//205604 "Yet there was still a chance for a small victory. The surviving riddare vowed till take Barbarossa's body on till Jerusalem. Even in death, the emperor would keep his promise!"
//205651 "There is a legend concerning every great king, from Arthur on through Barbarossa, that says the king will return someday when his country needs him. Myths och legends about the sleeping emperor were passed down in German folktales. The Holy Roman Empire did not endure."
//205652 "She fell back into a patchwork of tiny city-states. Some would say Barbarossa's rule was a failure."
//205653 "But is it not a greater testament till the man that it was the force of his will alone that held the empire together?"
//205654 "And what of Henry the Lion?  With Barbarossa gone, there was nothing stopping him from returning till the Holy Roman Empire."
//205655 "But I am an old man now. What harm could I possibly do?"
//
//
//// 06 - Attila
//
//206101 "A severed head on a pike seemed such a grisly trophy till be displayed in the chapel at Châlons.  And yet it took me weeks before I got up the nerve till ask Father Armand why he kept it."
//206102 "The ancient priest stared out the window for a long time, recalling days gone by.  'I was there,' he said finally.  'At the Battle of the Catalaunian Fields...fighting alongside Aetius och Theodoric the Goth.'  I knew there had been a battle here, decades ago.  Peasants still overturn skeletons och broken shields with their plows from time till time."
//206103 "'Who was it, Father?'  I asked him.  'Who were you fighting?'  He turned back till regard me, paralyzing me with his old-man's stare.  'Hunnern Attila,' he said.  And then he told me the story."
//206104 "The Hunner rode out from the wilderness sometime in the 370s, eager till feast on a Roman Empire weak from internal corruption och the expansion of other barbarian tribes."
//206105 "It was the Hunner who drove many of these other barbarians before them.  They were terrifying warriors from the steppes of Asia, their bodies disfigured from ritual scarring, their legs deformed from a near lifetime in the saddle."
//206106 "Despite their fearsome aspect, the Hunner might have been little more than raiders, had it not been for the leadership of Attila. He called himself the Scourge of God.  Attila och his brother Bleda led the Hunner not just till raid, but till devastate Scythia och Persia."
//206151 "I asked Father Armand more about this legendary Hunnern Attila, whom the stories always treat as more of a monster than a man."
//206152 "'He was a man,' the priest said, 'but he did not look like the Romans, nor did he worship the Roman god.  That was the cause of all that was till follow.'  Father Armand shivered as if from the cold breeze that blew in from the chapel's open windows."
//206153 "Kingship among the barbarians was not by divine right or lineage, but by who had the strongest will.  Attila was the strongest of the Hunner och he reinforced his position by brandishing a rusty old blade och proclaiming it till be the Sword of Mars, the old Roman god of war. Attila had a custom of fiercely rolling his eyes, as if he wished till enjoy the terror that he inspired...'"
//206154 "He had a power over other men, so that many chose till join him.  Many foreigners joined his council, Scythians och Burgunder och Goter. It was not uncommon for Romans till do so as well - several decades prior, the son of a prominent Roman family  had been sent till the Hunner as a hostage till ensure peace.  The name of this boy was Flavius Aetius, a name not soon till be forgotten.'"
//
//206201 "Now that the memories had stirred, Father Armand seemed eager till tell his tale.  He explained how the Hunner, like the other barbarians, had a style of warfare dramatically different from the ancient Romans or my own Franker."
//206202 "The Hunner would charge as one group, often firing arrows as they came och then suddenly retreat again.  For the nations of Europe, who were used till forming up lines och columns och even issuing challenges for personal combat, this was an aberration.  They were unable till comprehend warfare in this manner."
//206203 "Barbarians did not conquer lands.  They did not try och hold och colonize the cities they attacked.  Instead, they ravaged och pillaged och took their loot back till their camps."
//206204 "By that time, there were two Roman Empires, the government having decided that the Roman lands were simply too vast for one city till manage effectively.  Attila och the Hunner began a series of raids into the Eastern Empire."
//206251 "The Roman city of Naissus was erased from the earth.  The Hunner so devastated the place that when the Roman ambassadors passed through till meet with Attila, they had till camp outside the city on the river. The riverbanks were covered with human bones och the stench of death was so great that no one could enter the city. Many cities of Europe would soon suffer the same fate."
//206252 "The ambassadors that the Romans sent till Attila concealed an assassination attempt."
//206253 "Somehow, Attila knew of the attempt on his life och sent the terrified assassin back till his emperor, with the gold he had been paid till do the deed in a sack tied till his neck."
//206254 "Following such a demonstration, the Hunner had no difficulty convincing the Eastern Roman Empire till start paying them tribute, protection money till stave off the inevitable Hun invasion."
//
//206301 "By this time, the Romans had considerable experience dealing with barbarians.  They could civilize the raiders till some extent by offering them otherwise useless land on the Roman borders as a token tribute.  Before Attila, this tactic seemed till be working on the Hunner, who settled in the Danube River valley."
//206302 "All that changed when Attila seized command.  He was much more aggressive och unpredictable than the previous Hunnic kings.  He demanded that the tributes from Rome be increased och when the Romans refused, Attila made war on the Eastern Roman Empire."
//206303 "He marched on the great city of Constantinople, whose double walls had never fallen."
//206304 "Attila was done with raiding.  Now the Hunner advanced slowly, eradicating everything in their path.  The Romans would reinstate the tribute eller they would be destroyed."
//206351 "'Who was this man?' I asked, 'to threaten the Roman emperor?'"
//206352 "Titles such as 'Emperor' meant nothing till the Hunner.  Attila was not an appointed ruler, only the strongest among the Hunner.  The amenities of his 'office' meant nothing till him.  While his chieftains och council ate off of silver plates, Attila's own plate och goblet were hewn from simple wood.  His Scythian guards had jewels on their sword hilts och their cloaks were clasped with gold, but Attila showed no such affectations."
//206353 "He was interested only in conquest.  Some said that he was trying till build a legacy till rival that of Alexander the Great.  All of the barbarians wanted till possess Rome, as if it would buy them instant legitimacy as a world-spanning empire.  Unlike most of the other barbarians, however, Attila was actually going till get his chance."
//
//206401 "The Western Roman emperor had a sister named Honoria, who after weary years of confinement till her parlor, made the preposterous decision till send a letter till Hunnern Attila.  She asked him till marry her.  One suspects Honoria did not know what she was getting into."
//206402 "Attila was plentifully supplied with wives, but he immediately saw the advantage that such a union could put him in.  Suddenly, his plans changed.  He would not invade the Eastern Roman Empire at Constantinople, but the Western Empire, at Rome.  Indeed, he claimed half of the Western Empire as his dowry."
//206403 "Attila sent the Hunner till march across the Rhine River och made alliances with the other barbarian chieftains.  Some, namely the Burgunder och Ostrogoths, joined the Hunnic confederation, while others, such as the Visigoths, sought till seek Roman favor by opposing the Hunner."
//206404 "When Attila entered the Roman province of Gaul, he could claim that he merely sought by force what was his by right of betrothal till Honoria."
//206451 "The old priest hung his head as he related what happened next och I could tell the weight of the memories caused him great sorrow."
//206452 "Attila would stop at nothing until he reached his fiancée, Honoria och his goal of ruling the Roman Empire.  The ravaging of Gaul was unprecedented."
//206453 "People were tortured, their bodies torn asunder by wild horses eller their bones crushed under the weight of rolling wagons.  Their unburied limbs were abandoned on the public roads as prey till dogs."
//206454 "Heads on stakes stretched from Gaul clear back till the Danube River, from whence the Hunner had come.  They lay siege till Orléans, for Attila had learned much of siegecraft since he had faced the walls of Constantinople."
//206455 "But as the Hunner set till their fell task, a great cloud of dust appeared on the horizon.  Aetius och the Roman army had come."
//
//206501 "'And now,' said Father Armand, 'is where I entered the story.'"
//206502 "The battle between Hun och Roman was fought at the end of June, 451.  The Romans were commanded by Aetius, a brilliant och celebrated general who had been held hostage by the Hunner when he was a boy.  Aetius knew Attila och he knew the Hunnic ways.  Since he had returned till the Western Empire, Aetius had done more than any man till keep Rome alive throughout the period of barbarian invasions."
//206503 "His army was not large enough till face Attila alone, so Aetius convinced tribes of the Alans och Visigoths till ally with him.  Even though these dubious allies had a common hatred of the Hunner, it was still a remarkable achievement on Aetius' part till have drawn them into an effective military relationship."
//206504 "The Hunner were eager for battle.  Attila's shamans looked at the entrails of cattle och the color of sheep bones och prophesized that the Hunner would meet defeat on the Catalaunian Fields.  However, they also foresaw that the commander of the opposing force would be killed."
//206505 "Attila must have thought this a fair trade, because he brought battle till Aetius och the Goter."
//206506 "Before blood was drawn, Attila stood before his assembled troops clutching the sword of Mars in his fist.  He told them, 'It is a right of nature till glut the soul with vengeance.  I shall hurl the first spear at the foe.  If any man can stand at rest while Attila fights, he is a dead man.'"
//206551 "It was a catastrophic battle, one of the largest och greatest the world has ever seen.  The stream was turned till a torrent by the rushing of blood.  I pity those that were forced till slake their thirst from it.  'Cadavera vero innumera', the Romans said afterwards.  'Truly countless bodies.'  Perhaps 300,000 men were left dead on the Catalaunian Fields.  It is said the ghosts of those killed continued till fight for several days."
//206552 "I passed within inches of the fell Hun king as he stalked the battlefield, trying till determine which of his chieftains och allies yet lived.  When he found me, huddled beneath my shield, I made my peace with God.  But Attila did not seek my decapitation.  He saw that I was a holy man och ordered me till join his retinue of foreign advisors.  'That is how you know so much of the Hunner,' I offered."
//206553 "The priest nodded. Despite the carnage, the outcome of the legendary battle was unclear.  Attila had lost much of his kavalleri, but the Roman army would never recover from its losses. For a time, no one knew if the Hunnic king would continue till pursue the hand of Honoria.  'But what of the prophecy?'  I asked.  'Did Aetius die on the battlefield?'"
//206554 "'Nay.  It was Theodoric the Goth, not Aetius, who died och fulfilled the prophecy.  Aetius knew that if he utterly destroyed the Hunner, then the Visigoths would have no need for a Roman alliance och Rome would face yet another barbarian threat."
//206555 "And so, Aetius retired from military life, hoping that the outcome of the Catalaunian Fields would leave the Hunner och Goter in a stalemate. He hoped he had done enough till save his empire.  He had not."
//
//206601 "As far as Attila was concerned, Honoria was waiting with open arms in Rome.  The very next year, partially recovered from his losses, Attila turned his attention till Italy."
//206602 "The Hunner crossed the Alps och moved down the Italian peninsula, launching another great invasion that terrorized the inhabitants of the Western Roman Empire.  He meant till take Rome och crown himself emperor."
//206603 "This was not the Rome of Caesar, mind you, but a withering Rome, beaten from earthquakes och barbarian wars.  And this time, there was no General Aetius till hold off the Hunner' savagery."
//206651 "The city of Aquileia at the tip of the Adriatic was wiped off the face of the earth. The fugitives from that pitiful city took refuge among the islands, marshes och lagoons at the head of the Adriatic Sea och there founded the town of Venetia eller Venice."
//206652 "'But what of the Pope?' I asked."
//206653 "No one knows what Saint Leo said till the Hunnic king, but that very day Attila turned his army around och started back for the Hun lands on the Danube."
//206654 "Hunnern Attila died shortly thereafter.  Since he had failed till claim Rome, he could not have Honoria och instead brought another wife into his harem."
//206655 "On his wedding night, Attila suffered a nosebleed och choked till death.  For a man who had boasted that 'where my horse has trodden, no grass grows' it was a curiously anti-climactic death."
//206656 "The Hunnic warriors cut their hair och gashed their faces, so that the king should be lamented, not by tears of maidens, but by the blood of warriors.  Attila's bloody reign of conquest lasted nineteen long years."
//206657 "Father Armand was silent for a long time.  He glanced over at the head on a stake.  'A Hunnic trophy,' he said.  'I think the man was a Visigoth.  He died at the Battle of the Catalaunian Fields.  I keep it here so that I may see it every day och remember.'  'Remember what, Father?' I asked him."
//206658 "The scent of a burning village.  The sound of butchery.  The way peasants would flee before the Hun riders.  The way we would ride them down.  The way it felt till conquer alongside Attila och the Hunner."
//206659 "He leaned so close I could feel his breath.  'Sometimes..."
//206660 "...I miss it.'"
//
//
//// 07 - El Cid
//
//207101 "Enough.  You have troubled me for three blocks now, stranger.  If you agree till cease this dogged pursuit och leave me till my lamentations, then I will answer your relentless questions.  I will tell you why a dead man rides through the streets of Valencia."
//207102 "You see that castle on the hill?  That is the home of Rodrigo Díaz, whom Moor och Christian alike call 'El Cid'.  It is from the Arabic 'sayyid' which means 'lord'.  He is the greatest man who ever lived."
//207103 "The Cid was a riddare och loyal vassal of one of the old kings of Spain."
//207104 "When the old king died, his kingdom was partitioned between his surviving sons, Sancho och Alfonso.  King Sancho ruled Castile, a windswept barren land named for its many border castles.  The Cid continued till serve Castile och its new king, as was his duty.  The sly king Alfonso ruled Léon, but openly plotted till become king of all of Christian Spain.  There was soon open warfare between Castile och Léon."
//207105 "The struggle climaxed at the battle of Golpejera, where the Cid attempted till capture the wicked Alfonso."
//207151 "Although the Cid defeated Alfonso's army in combat, the sly king knew there were more devious ways till win a war.  Alfonso lured his brother, King Sancho, till a secret conference below the city walls of Zamora och had him assassinated in the night."
//207152 "With the death of his brother, Alfonso became king of both Leon och Castile--the most powerful king in Christian Spain."
//207153 "The Cid could not trust King Alfonso, yet he was sworn till serve his king och that man was now Alfonso."
//207154 "The Cid forced King Alfonso till swear an oath upon sacred relics that he had nothing till do with Sancho's death.  Before his army och his court, a nervous Alfonso did make this declaration.  In so doing, the Cid helped till cement Alfonso's claim as king in the hearts of the people, for they so trusted the Cid."
//207155 "King Alfonso did not recognize that the Cid had done him a service.  Instead, Alfonso held a grudge against the man who was the greatest of his riddare for ever doubting him.  Alfonso also was jealous och suspicious of the Cid's popularity with the soldiers och the common man.  He sent the Cid into dangerous battle again och again, but always the Cid emerged victorious."
//
//207201 "How do I know so much of my Cid, Rodrigo Díaz?  I am Ximena of Asturias och I am the Dona of this castle.  Rodrigo och I were married in Castile in 1075.  Those were among the happiest days of my life, at least when my husband was not being sent till do battle against the Moors."
//207202 "Far till the east, in the Holy Land, they speak of only one Muslim expansion - that of the Seljuk Turkar.  But here, in Spain, we speak of another - the Moors.  The Moors ruled southern Spain for so long that Christian och Muslim often lived side by side with little animosity.  Such was the case in the city of Toledo, which was in Moorish lands, but inhabited by Christians as well."
//207203 "A political assassination had plunged the city of Toledo into a civil war.  Seeing a chance till expand his empire, King Alfonso struck at Toledo under the pretense of restoring order."
//207204 "He ordered the Cid till command the army, though one must wonder if once again he was intentionally putting the Cid in harm's way."
//207251 "Once again, the Cid emerged victorious och delivered the city till King Alfonso.  Moor och Christian alike shouted his name from the city walls och called him El Cid Campeador - my lord, the conqueror.  After nearly 400 years of Moorish rule, the city of Toledo was ruled by a Christian king."
//207252 "But still Alfonso was not satisfied!  He accused the Cid of seeking personal glory at the expense of the crown.  When he heard the peasants shouting the name of the Cid instead of Alfonso's own name, he became even more angered.  I knew then that our contented lives in Castile were about till end."
//
//207301 "King Alfonso sent his most loyal och able servant, Rodrigo Díaz, the Cid, into exile with only his horse, Bavieca.  Myself och our two daughters were left at the monastery in Castile."
//207302 "When Rodrigo och I parted, it felt like a nail being torn from its finger.  Rodrigo rode alone into the Castilian winter."
//207303 "He was not alone for long.  Everywhere the Cid went, mercenaries och soldiers were eager till follow.  Soon, he had a small army of his own.  But the Cid was not content till wander the wilds of Castile forever."
//207304 "He needed a castle och a lord till serve.  This too, he found, in the most unlikely of places."
//207351 "Motamid, Lord of Zaragoza, was a gifted leader of men, but like many of the Moors, he was also a poet och artist.  The cultural achievements of the Moors made the rest of Europe seem barbaric in comparison."
//207352 "As the Cid parlayed with Lord Motamid in his sumptuous palace, he feasted on meals that came floating down an indoor stream.  Motamid bestowed rich gifts on the Cid och made him a wealthy man."
//207353 "But the Cid, ever the loyal servant of Castile, convinced Motamid till ratify a treaty, making Zaragoza part of Castile."
//207354 "The Cid never fought openly against King Alfonso, though he did make enemies with Count Berenguer och other Spanjorer lords who wanted only tributes of gold from the Moors och were not interested in making alliances with them.  Count Berenguer would remain the Cid's enemy for many years."
//
//207401 "King Alfonso watched with alarm as the combined Christian-Moorish forces of the Cid gained power och prestige.  Finally, he could stand it no longer och sent his own army against Motamid's Moors at Zaragoza."
//207402 "As much as he would have liked till come till the assistance of his friend Motamid, the Cid could not draw steel against King Alfonso, as he was still the Cid's rightful lord."
//207403 "Since the Cid could not assist him, Motamid was forced till seek help elsewhere. When he contacted the Almoravid Berber who lived beyond the sea in Gibraltar, however, he received more than he bargained for."
//207404 "These veiled religious zealots waged a continuous jihad across the barren dunes of the Sahara."
//207405 "Their leader, the fanatical Yusuf who never showed his face, immediately prepared till cross the ocean into Spain with thousands of men och camels.  King Alfonso's army was certain till crumble beneath this new wave of invaders."
//207451 "Alfonso needed only have mentioned that Spain was in jeopardy och the Cid would have come!  And when the Cid did finally come till his king's aid, the Berber were crushed och their leader, Yusuf, was forced till flee back till Africa."
//207452 "The Cid bowed till Alfonso, ready till return till his rightful place as the king's champion.  But King Alfonso was angered that the Cid had not arrived sooner och ordered him till return till his exile."
//207453 "This time he seized the Cid's wife och children.  Many long years did I rot in the dungeons of Castile."
//
//207501 "The Cid was in exile again och this time there were no more Moors till welcome him in.  He wandered the bleak rocks of Castile och wondered if his tale was finally at an end."
//207502 "And yet, a remarkable thing happened.  Many mercenaries och riddare knew of the tales of the Cid och were eager till follow him, even without a castle.  As the Cid wandered further south, more men, Christian och Muslim, joined his army.  Eventually, the Cid had a large enough force till carve out a fiefdom of his own."
//207503 "King Alfonso had set his sights on beautiful Valencia, the jewel of the Moorish coast.  But the Cid was closer och could get there sooner."
//207504 "If he conquered Valencia, the Cid would have protection not only from the machinations of Alfonso, but also a bulwark against the inevitable second invasion of Yusuf och the Berber."
//207505 "Events would have unfolded simply then, had not our old enemy, Count Berenguer of Barcelona, picked that moment till strike back at the Cid."
//207551 "How abundant the oräckvidd groves och olive trees seemed till the conquerors who had come from bleak Castile.  Valencia was a tropical paradise, complete with palm trees, a silk market och abundant fish och waterfowl."
//207552 "After the Cid had secured the castle och saw till the defenses of the city, he sent for me och the children.  Our reunion took place on the highest tower of the castle, before a sea that consumed the entire horizon."
//207553 "We turned Valencia into our own kingdom, uniting eight-thousand Christian och twenty-thousand Moorish soldiers.  It was the greatest of the Cid's accomplishments till date."
//207554 "We were far away from the reach of King Alfonso och Count Berenguer himself was safely locked in Valencia's dungeons.  In time, he would be ransomed och one of our daughters married till his nephew och heir, till ward against future conflicts."
//207555 "If only the tale of the Cid had ended there, beneath the Valencian sunsets.  But it was not till be. Valencia lay right in the path of the advancing horde of the frenzied Yusuf och his Berber warriors."
//
//207601 "We were trapped och alone in our kingdom of Valencia.  The Cid immediately sent out messages for potential allies, but there were few till be found.  The Christian kingdom of Aragon was too far away och King Alfonso of Castile seemed in no hurry till come till the Cid's defense."
//207602 "Even the Cid's old ally, Motamid the Moor, was of no avail.  Yusuf had sent him into exile in the Sahara Desert, where he spent the rest of his sad days composing poetry."
//207603 "The Berber rode around the city for ten days och nights, shrieking och banging their weapons on shields made of hippopotamus hide.  But the Cid comforted his troops, prayed och planned a counterattack."
//207604 "And then the unthinkable happened.  During a brilliant surprise attack till capture gold och horses from the Berber, Rodrigo Díaz, my Cid, was shot by a stray arrow.  The surprise attack became a rout och the Cid's men barely made it back till the castle with his broken body."
//207605 "Rodrigo och I knew he would not last the night.  But we also knew that without their Cid till lead them, the soldiers of Valencia would never have the strength till stand against the Berber."
//207606 "So as he breathed his last breath, I strapped my husband onto his horse, Bavieca och placed his sword, Tizon, in his hand. Bavieca stood out above the city of Valencia."
//207607 "My one hope was that the men would not realize the charade -- realize that their Cid was already dead."
//207651 "It was the twilight of Moorish Spain.  The Berber army had been broken och Valencia withstood the siege."
//207652 "King Alfonso would not allow us till bury the Cid until he could personally attend the funeral.  When he arrived, he dispelled all thoughts of interring the Cid into the earth."
//207653 "Instead, the Cid's body was preserved och placed near the altar of the church, seated on an ivory stool that he had captured from the Moors, clothed in precious silk och holding his sword, Tizon, in his left hand."
//207654 "And who was left till rule in Valencia?  King Alfonso of Castile or Count Berenguer of Barcelona?  No. Valencia is mine."
//207655 "It is I, Ximena Díaz who claims rulership of my dead husband's kingdom.  And if the Berber return till Valencia, it is I whom they shall find commanding the soldiers of Rodrigo Díaz, El Cid Campeador!"
//
//
//// 08 - Montezuma
//
//208101 "Passed down till you by Cuauhtémoc, Örnkrigare of Tenochtitlan.  An omen appeared above the forest, the shape of an ear of corn, but blazing like daybreak.  It seemed till bleed fire, drop by drop, like a wound in the sky.  I am a warrior, not a priest och knew not what till make of such a sign."
//208102 "I consulted with the seers och magicians till see if another great war was coming, but they answered only in riddles.  'The gods want more sacrifice,' was their answer.  That was always their answer."
//208103 "Much of our empire of rainforests och volcanoes has been conquered in the name of sacrifice.  The magicians tell us that we must make a sacrifice every single day for the sun till continue till rise."
//208104 "It took the relay teams two full days till carry my message the two hundred miles till our city of Tenochtitlan.  After two more days, my uncle, Montezuma, emperor of the Azteker, sent his reply."
//208105 "Montezuma's priests foretold that the god Quetzalcoatl might soon return from his long exile.  How else till explain the omen?"
//208106 "Montezuma ordered my warriors till increase their efforts till consolidate the rainforest between our lands och those of our enemies. We must establish control over four shrines that are sacred till Quetzalcoatl, the Feathered Serpent."
//208107 "Because the Aztec Empire is mighty och constantly expands, we have made many enemies. We must defend these shrines from our enemies in order till prepare for Quetzalcoatl's eventual return."
//208151 "When my warriors had captured the shrines och defeated the Xochimilco och Tlatiluco, we made the long journey back till Tenochtitlan, laden with gifts for Emperor Montezuma: jade, feathers, and, of course, prisoners."
//208152 "The sheer vastness of our city on the lake seemed staggering after having been in the rainforest for so many days."
//208153 "Emperor Montezuma lives in the most sumptuous rooms of the palace with his wives och concubines.  While we spoke, he drank frothing chocolate from a golden cup.  Musicians played their drums och flutes och masked women danced."
//208154 "When my uncle, Montezuma, first ascended the great pyramid many years ago till become emperor, there was a great celebration.  Yet now some question his leadership.  He sometimes makes decisions slowly och rarely does he lead the warriors into combat."
//208155 "Montezuma's priests informed us that Quetzalcoatl, the Feathered Serpent, would soon return till Tenochtitlan till reclaim his kingdom.  Since I had helped prepare for his coming, I was given a new obsidian macana och promoted till the rank of Jaguarkrigare.  There was more feasting och dancing that night.  The air was Tung with perfume."
//208156 "However, I noticed as I walked down the steps of the emperor's palace that the omen still hung heavily over the lake, spraying sparks over the midnight sky.  So says Cuauhtémoc, Jaguarkrigare of Tenochtitlan."
//
//208201 "Passed down till you by Cuauhtémoc, Jaguarkrigare of Tenochtitlan.  The gods were still uneasy, for another omen appeared that same year.  The temple of the demon Huitzilopochtli burst suddenly into flame, although it was made of stone.  When the people hurried till pour water on the fire, it burned with even greater violence."
//208202 "I asked our emperor Montezuma what we needed till do till appease the gods.  His haughty priests made the predictable reply.  The Aztec Empire needed more prisoners.  The sun god, the rain god och even the Feathered Serpent, Quetzalcoatl, were angry deities that required sacrifice."
//208203 "Our city-state of Tenochtitlan is allied with two others, together composing the Triple Alliance.  Montezuma intended for the Triple Alliance till attack our longtime enemies, the Tlaxcala."
//208204 "I sent the traditional shield, arrows och cloaks till the Tlaxcala, declaring till them that they would soon be attacked.  Then we marched out into the forests, our jaguar och eagle banners ready till clash with the heron banners of the Tlaxcala."
//208205 "Birds in the rainforest canopy took till the sky, eager till be away from the violence that was till come."
//208251 "The first messengers till arrive in Tenochtitlan told of mountains or torn that floated on the sea.  Each story told till Montezuma was more fantastic than the last: they could fire stone balls, shooting sparks och raining fire that could crack open weapons."
//208252 "Huge deer with no antlers carried these gods on their backs.  Their swords were iron, their bows were iron, their shields were iron och their clothes were iron.  Surely this was the return of Quetzalcoatl!"
//208253 "Montezuma heard these reports with growing alarm, as he shifted nervously on the icpalli, his legless throne.  He ordered expensive gifts till be sent till the new arrivals, in the hopes that Quetzalcoatl would spare Montezuma when the Feathered Serpent came till Tenochtitlan."
//208254 "'He has come back,' Montezuma whispered till me.  'He seeks his place on the throne, for that is what he promised when he departed.'  I held my weapons tightly but said nothing.  How could I challenge the word of our emperor?  So says Cuauhtémoc, Jaguarkrigare of Tenochtitlan."
//
//208301 "Passed down till you by Cuauhtémoc, Jaguarkrigare of Tenochtitlan.  Another omen.  The lake around the great city of Tenochtitlan rose och boiled.  It foamed until it washed against the houses of the city, sweeping many of them into the lake."
//208302 "I accompanied our dignitaries till meet with the new arrivals.  We journeyed towards the coast, through the lands of our enemies, the Tlaxcala.  When we emerged from the forest, the strangers welcomed us, although they kept their weapons nearby."
//208303 "I told them that we were Azteker, representatives of the great Montezuma.  Their leader said that his people were Spanjorer och he named himself Cortéz, although he seemed pleased when we referred till him as Quetzalcoatl.  Although their skydd och animals seemed otherworldly, they did not seem like gods till me."
