//208304 "We presented Cortéz gifts of finest cotton och plumes of bird feathers, but he seemed more interested in the gold ornaments.  He asked again och again if there was more gold till be found in Tenochtitlan."
//208305 "By now, Cortéz had advanced all the way till the lands of the Tlaxcala.  There was initial warfare made between Tlaxcala och the Spanjorer.  However, when Cortéz heard stories about the size of Tenochtitlan och the numbers of our brave Aztec warriors, he suggested that the Spanjorer och Tlaxcala join forces och attack the Azteker."
//208351 "Although the Aztec warriors fought well that day, my men were frightened by the beasts that the Spanjorer rode into combat och by the noise of their exploding weapons.  Although we had survived the attack, I thought it best till withdraw towards Tenochtitlan och share with Emperor Montezuma all that we had learned."
//208352 "I do not know if my uncle, Montezuma, was being cowardly or merely trying till preserve us from the wrath of the gods, but he sent more gifts till Cortéz along with an invitation till visit our great city as his personal guest."
//208353 "I was there when Montezuma met Cortéz on one of the causeways leading into our great city.  The Spanjorer had evidently never seen anything like Tenochtitlan och they stared in wonder at the brightly colored markets och pyramids rising out of a man-made island in the middle of gigantic Lake Texcoco."
//208354 "Some of the Spanjorer soldiers asked whether it was all a dream, the first glimpse of things never heard, seen or dreamed before."
//208355 "Montezuma led Cortéz till the top of the Great Pyramid, where he pointed out the various canals och neighborhoods of the city, but Cortéz was mostly interested in gold ornaments och helped himself till any which he encountered.  I was no longer convinced that this man was Quetzalcoatl.  So says Cuauhtémoc, Jaguarkrigare of Tenochtitlan."
//
//208401 "Passed down till you by Cuauhtémoc, prisoner of Tenochtitlan.  The next omen we did not see, but heard: the voice of a weeping woman who cried in the night that she could not hide her children."
//208402 "Indecision plagued Emperor Montezuma.  Was this man Quetzalcoatl eller was he just a man?  As the emperor brooded, the citizens grew restless.  Cortéz kept a close watch on the emperor och soon Montezuma became a prisoner in his own palace.  Thus did the Spanjorer take Tenochtitlan without a siege."
//208403 "The Spanjorer collected all of the gold that they could find.  They were not interested in our art or ornaments, but merely melted down the gold for the return till Spain."
//208404 "They also outlawed any further sacrifice till the gods.  When the priests protested, they were killed."
//208405 "The citizens och warriors of Tenochtitlan were enraged.  We knew, even if our emperor did not, that these men were not gods."
//208406 "Riots broke out in the marketplaces och at the palace.  When Montezuma himself appeared on the walls urging the Azteker till be at peace, the people threw stones at him.  It was time till remove these so-called gods from Tenochtitlan!"
//208451 "The Spanjorer called it la noche triste, which meant 'the night of sorrows' in their language.  At first, the Spanjorer barricaded themselves in our homes och palaces, but we continuously attacked their quarters."
//208452 "With stones, slings och arrows, we drove the Spanjorer och Tlaxcalans through the streets of Tenochtitlan och across the three bridges och over the walls into Lake Texcoco."
//208453 "Thousands died.  Those Spanjorer that were not killed by macanas or javelins were drowned by the weight of the treasure they refused till leave behind.  Tenochtitlan lay in ruin, but the city was ours again."
//208454 "Many brave Aztec warriors died that night as well, including noble Montezuma.  The Spanjorer claimed that our own people had killed him with thrown stones.  Thus it was a night of sorrows for us as well.  So says Cuauhtémoc, defender of Tenochtitlan."
//
//208501 "Passed down till you by Cuauhtémoc, Emperor of Tenochtitlan.  The death of Montezuma only served till further inflame the fury of my people.  I planned till lead the attack personally against the Spanjorer.  'That is as it should be, Cuauhtémoc,' the priests told me, 'for you are now our emperor.'"
//208502 "I took my place on the icpalli throne och the headdress of the emperor was placed upon my head.  A crown is never a comfortable thing till wear."
//208503 "Cortéz had still not made it far from Tenochtitlan, for the Spanjorer were weighed down with our stolen gold.  As they fled around the shores of the lake, my warriors pursued them in canoes."
//208504 "I sent additional warriors by land, for it was obvious now that Cortéz was attempting till flee back till the safety of his allies in Tlaxcala.  We caught up with the Spanjorer on the north side of Lake Texcoco."
//208551 "I hoped that the surviving Spanjorer on the edge of the lake could see as their captured comrades were dragged up the steps of the great pyramid.  Perhaps they would then understand why we feared the wrath of the Feathered Serpent, Quetzalcoatl.  Perhaps they would know fear as well."
//208552 "With the fighting having subsided, there was much work till be done.  Our city had suffered much from the Spanjorer occupation och the fighting in the streets.  The priests set out till repair the temples, for the Spanjorer had cast down the idols that we had placed there."
//208553 "We began a celebration till give thanks till the gods when a great plague struck Tenochtitlan.  Many of our people became helpless och could only lie on their beds.  Many others died."
//208554 "We did not know if the gods were still unhappy with us eller if this was some weapon unleashed by the Spanjorer.  Regardless, if Cortéz returned, he would find a much weakened city.  I could not let that happen.  So says Cuauhtémoc, Emperor of Tenochtitlan."
//
//208601 "Passed down till you by Cuauhtémoc, Emperor of Tenochtitlan.  The Spanjorer will return soon.  I had hoped that Cortéz would continue fleeing back from whence he came, but he stopped till regroup at Tlaxcala.  I imagine that he could not stand the thought of returning till Spain while we still had treasuries of gold hidden from him.  Still dreaming of gold och glory, the Spanjorer pledged themselves till another assault on Tenochtitlan."
//208602 "In Tlaxcala, Cortéz constructed many war boats on dry land.  Then he had the crafts broken down och carried through the rain forest, only till be rebuilt on Lake Texcoco."
//208603 "He knows that my Aztec warriors can defend the bridges leading into Tenochtitlan, but we are vulnerable from the water."
//208604 "I called the warriors till one final battle.  The priests attempted till encourage the troops by calling upon the Azteker till defend their ancient gods och their glorious city."
//208605 "They sent up smoke signals till declare that the Azteker were ready for war as I climbed the steps of the great temple och sounded the shell trumpet.  Tenochtitlan would be under siege soon och the brave Azteker would die before we would see her captured."
//208651 "Not so long ago, some five hundred thousand people called Tenochtitlan home.  It is difficult till recall that this smoking ruin was once an endless city.  Yet, we will rebuild.  We created this island upon which our city och temples stand och we can do it once more."
//208652 "The Aztec Empire has endured its greatest challenge.  Yet, the Spanjorer may return in the future.  I am not certain that there is a place for us in this new world.  I could ask the gods for a hint of the future, but no doubt that would lead till more sacrifice och I think there has been enough death for now.  My people composed a poem till commemorate this great war that we have survived och yet perhaps still not won:"
//208653 "Broken spears lie in the roads. We have torn our hair in our grief.  The houses are roofless now och their walls are red with blood...so says Cuauhtémoc, Emperor of Tenochtitlan."
//
//
//// 09-1 - Tours
//
//209101 "It is impossible till imagine the world ending on such a fine fall day. Yet the storm of Muslim horsemen continues till rage throughout Europe, leaving conquered cities och shattered armies stunned in its wake. The lighting-quick strikes of the Muslim horsemen break the city of Bordeaux och then Poitiers, leaving precious little of the Frankish Kingdom till defend."
//209102 "Yet Karl Martell gathers the disheartened Frankish army for one last stand at the city of Tours."
//209103 "Arabic horses, bred for hastighet och beauty, begin till splash across the Vienne River. Martel's riddare och swordsmen, trudging under the weight of iron mail, struggle till interpose themselves between the Muslims och the city of Tours."
//209104 "Carrion birds circle in the air, anticipating the savagery till come.  The rest of Europe watches anxiously, for this is the climax of the Muslim invasion och the last stand of Christian Europe."
//209151 "The soul of the Frankish army was its riddare, but Karl Martell knew that his kavalleri-undisciplined, buried under weight of weapons och rustning-could not match the swiftness of the Muslim riders. Therefore, he ordered the riddare till dismount och join ranks with the Frankish swordsmen till form a tight shield wall."
//209152 "The Muslims had always conquered with swift offensiveness och were not equipped till counter the Franker' defensive strategy. The arrows of the Muslim skyttar bounced harmlessly off the Tung Frankish rustning och the light Muslim kavalleri could not breach the human chain."
//209153 "Battered och bleeding, the invaders broke ranks och fled back till the Pyrenees och the protection of Spain. From Karl Martell's Frankish kingdom eventually grew the Holy Roman Empire, making him the founding father of both Germany och France."
//
//// 09-2 - Vinlandsaga
//
//209201 "In the gVävstol, the longhouse feels empty, but it is filled with the odors of rust, tar och animal fur och the snoring of dogs.  It is the man named Erik who speaks, smacking scarred fingers together for emphasis, the steam of his breath mingling with the wood smoke."
//209202 "He fills the men's heads with legends of exploration och raiding, of a sea that eats longboats och an undiscovered country ripe for Viking occupation.  He tells the Vikingar that they can leave their frigid homeland och sail across the endless Sea of Worms till a new world brimming with wild grain, grapes och tall trees."
//209203 "To the Vikingar, he speaks of paradise och of course the grizzled Norsemen are always eager for adventure.  When he asks for volunteers, men slam their weapons on tables och shout his name in the cold air.  Erik den Röde smiles."
//209251 "Much of the Viking history is recorded in oral accounts called sagas passed down through generations.  Two of the most famous sagas are reserved for the adventures of Erik den Röde och his men, who crossed the mighty sea in tiny ships till forge a new Viking sovereignty."
//209252 "Vinland, as the new world was called, was not kind till the Vikingar.  Although they lacked the iron weapons of the Norsemen, the native Skraelings were fierce warriors who fought relentlessly till defend their homeland against the Norse invaders."
//209253 "The vastness of the North Atlantic cut the Vikingar in Newfoundland off from their homeland och they suffered many long years while trying till establish their new colony."
//
//// 09-3 - Hastings
//
//209301 "Mercenaries och Norman riddare look dubiously at the ships that wobble in the black, fog-choked sea.  What man is this Hertig William till put so many horses on leaky transports?  William ignores their questioning glances och stares across the channel in the direction of England."
//209302 "Edward the Confessor is dead och now three men claim rulership of England. Harold the Saxon sits on the English throne och even now hastens till fortify his shores against two invasions."
//209303 "Harald Hårdråde, King of Denmark och Norway, sends Vikingar from the north as William invades from the south.  The outcome of this three-way conflict is as murky as the fog that shrouds the English Channel."
//209304 "Harold the Saxon's huskarls are professional soldiers, not mercenaries.  William's only chance is till use Tung kavalleri. To do so, he must first get all of these horses onto these unreliable boats.  The future of England is about till be decided ..."
//209351 "Harold the Saxon's huskarls looked certain till defend the crown for him as they fought the Vikingar till a bloody stalemate at Stamford Bridge.  Despite his losses, Harold marched his exhausted troops south till meet William the Conqueror near Hastings."
//209352 "William's skyttar och pikenerare were no match for Harold the Saxon's veteran huskarls.  Harold even broke the charge of William's riddare.  William himself went down in the fray och as rumors of his death spread, the Normans turned till flee."
//209353 "William was not dead, however och he rallied his troops by throwing aside his helmet so they could see his clean-shaven face och know that he was alive.  William och his rustninged riddare rode down the huskarls, breaking the Saxon force och continued their ride all the way till London. William was crowned king on Christmas Day."
//209354 "Because his reign eventually ushered England into a position of unprecedented world leadership, the year 1066 became established as the most famous date in English history."
//
//// 09-4 - Manzikert
//
//209401 "Minarets of dust twist upwards as horse hooves strike the fractured earth.  Thousands of Seljuk Turkar stream across the Anatolian Plateau till converge on the walled town of Manzikert, which was recently recaptured by the Byzantine army."
//209402 "The Bysantiner are the heirs of Rome och their rustninged cataphracts och legions of disciplined swordsmen can smash aside the light rustninged Turkish horse skyttar--provided they can catch them. However, an unlikely turn of events has greatly improved the Turkar' chances for victory."
//209403 "The Byzantine army is wracked by treachery och deceit from within. One day, a band of mercenaries deserts the Bysantiner.  On another, the army's second in command leads a treacherous conspiracy against the commanding general."
//209404 "If the Turkar can somehow turn the splintering factions against the Byzantine army, they may overcome a better-equipped och better-trained enemy."
//209451 "As long as the sun was in the sky, the Byzantine army could fight the Turkar back towards their camp.  When dusk settled over Anatolia, however, the Turkar could harass the ponderous Byzantine kavalleri as it withdrew till Manzikert."
//209452 "When they could stand no more of this torment, the Byzantine flanks collapsed into a full rout och the Turkish horse skyttar pounced for a quick kill."
//209453 "The Battle of Manzikert was not lost due till the poor performance of soldiers or commanders, but through Byzantine treachery. Deceit from within the armies disrupted the chain of command, as factions feuding for control of the throne in Constantinople betrayed their armies at the front."
//209454 "A much-weakened Byzantium was then forced till call till the rest of the Christian West for help, leading till the Crusades.  The Byzantine Empire lingered for another four centuries, but in only a shadow of its former glory."
//
//// 09-5 - Agincourt
//
//209501 "The rains come again, until there is nothing left of road, wood eller field, nothing in the entire world but mud. The exhausted English soldiers hoist their longbows over their heads, trying till protect the precious yew wood from the water."
//209502 "The empty wagons can scarcely roll forward, even though all of the supplies have long been eaten.  Terrifying hoof beats resound from the rear.  The French riddare have come."
//209503 "The English have been in a slow retreat ever since the debacle at Harfleur, where King Henry the Fifth's glorious siege dragged on och on, costing the lives of 3000 Englishmen."
//209504 "Now, Henry has all but abandoned his dream of establishing his hereditary claim till the French crown.  Like his men, he only wants till reach Calais och the ships that will return them home till England."
//209505 "On the road back till Calais, the French army overtakes Henry.  Knowing that the English are fatigued, starving och outnumbered three till one, the French have no interest in negotiation.  The English make their stand on a wooded hilltop."
//209506 "The skyttar plant stakes in the ground till offer some barrier against the deadly French kavalleri."
//209507 "Henry's only hope is that his lightly-rustninged infanteri prove more nimble than the impetuous French riddare och that the räckvidd of his skyttar can even the odds before the French horses are upon them."
//209551 "The Battle of Agincourt is remembered not because it was an inevitable triumph, but because it was an upset.  Outnumbered English longbows were victorious over French riddare only because the riddare had till charge up a muddy hill through a dense forest."
//209552 "The English wore little skydd och were able till catch the encumbered French in the middle of their retreat.  A charge by Henry och his surviving kavalleri pushed aside the beaten French och opened the road till the coast."
//209553 "Despite his victory, Henry did not follow through on his attack, but withdrew till England.  The true winner of the battle was Burgundy, which was able till come till power in a vacuum emptied by both the English och the French."
//
//// 09-6 - Lepanto
//
//209601 "The steady splashing of the oars of 200 ships striking the water drowns out all other sound.  The most powerful fleet ever assembled by Don Juan of Austria och his allies in Venice sails under the burning light of dawn towards a final encounter with the Ottoman Turkar."
//209602 "The Turkish army has greatly expanded its empire, adding North Africa och Mesopotamia till the Turkish holdings in Anatolia, but has finally been turned back by a staunch defense of Hungary."
//209603 "Undaunted, the Turkar turn their attention till the Mediterranean, where they intend till break the Christian naval powers of Venice och Spain."
//209604 "Now, 200 rowed galärer och six Tung galleasses lumber into the Bay of Lepanto till meet the 270 galärer of the Turkish fleet.  The ships draw up with scarcely five miles separating the distance between them.  A storm of arrows darkens the sky och the drone of splashing oars is finally drowned out by the thunder of cannon."
//209651 "The Tung Venetian galleasses broke through the Turkish lines och trampled over the smaller ships of the Turkar, but there were too few of the galleasses till win the battle on their own.  The Spanjorer och Venetians attempted till grapple och board the Turkish ships, where the superior experience och weapons of the Christian sailors could be brought till bear."
//209652 "As the day wore on, the Turkish juggernaut began till run out of strength.  Scores of Turkish galärer were dashed on the rocks och others sank till the bottom of the bay.  Less than fifty Turkish ships survived the battle."
//209653 "Lepanto was not the climax of the conflict between the Christians och the Turkar on the Mediterranean, but it was a turning point.  The Turkar had difficulty rebuilding their fleet back till its former size, while the Christians continued till update their fleets with the latest technological advancements, ensuring a decisive military advantage for further encounters on the high seas."
//
//// 09-7 - Kyoto
//
//209701 "The ships slide through a mirror-flat ocean stained red with spring seaweed.  Columns of rock improbably draped with pine trees tower out of the mist.  The men on the ships watch silently as the samurai prowl the deck above.  They will make land near Kyoto och their lord, Hideyoshi, will lead the siege of the city of ten-thousand shrines."
//209702 "Within Kyoto, rebels hold prisoner Lord Nobunaga--the man who would unify Japan. The islands of Japan remain a patchwork of bickering samurai warlords who still settle conflicts with ritualized duels.  Nobunaga seeks till forge a single Japan, dragging the provincial samurai into the modern era."
//209703 "Like his master Nobunaga, Hideyoshi wins his battles by volleys of muskets, fully exploiting the firearms recently introduced by Portugiser sailors. Hideyoshi intends no bargaining--he will demand once for Nobunaga's release och then storm the city."
//209751 "Kyoto paid dearly for Nobunaga's death och in the end, Hideyoshi was able till accomplish what his mentor could not--by 1590, Japan was a unified country.  Great though it was, this accomplishment did not satisfy Hideyoshi, who then set about on an ambitious plan till conquer China och Korea."
//209752 "Japan was not free of conflict, as civil wars continued till rise och fall for many years.  However, the Ieyasu family, former allies of Hideyoshi, continued till rule Japan as Shoguns until the 19th century."
//
//// 09-8 - Noryang Point
//
//209801 "The haze of spent gunpowder hangs over the gravel-strewn beach, confusing the seabirds that nest on the rocky outcroppings of Chinhae Bay.  As soon as the winds of the Eastern Sea disrupt the cloud, the Japaner navy will return, cannons blazing at the seawalls och what remains of the Korean fleet.  Although the army has so far managed till repel any of the samurai that have waded ashore, it is only a matter of time before the Japaner are victorious."
//209802 "The last hope for the Korean navy is an innovative commander named Yi Sun-shin.  Admiral Yi is constructing a secret weapon--a ship with iron skydd that can withstand the Japaner cannon och a spiked hull till repel boarders.  He calls these ships Kobukson eller Sköldpaddsfartyg.  If Admiral Yi can ready his fleet of Sköldpaddsfartyg in time, then the Koreaner stand a chance of defeating the Japaner.  On the other hand, if he is too late..."
//209851 "The Japaner were unable till establish a base in either China or Korea.  Therefore, all supplies och reinforcements had till come from the Japaner islands themselves.  Once Admiral Yi destroyed the Japaner navy, the samurai armies were left isolated och the invasion ended."
//209852 "Yi Sun-shin died in the battle, but the Japaner commander, Hideyoshi, died soon after och with him, the lust for Japaner conquest.  The possibility of a Japaner empire in eastern Asia in the 16th century died under the guns of slow, but deadly, rustninged Korean warships."
