//
//// 10 - Alaric
//
//210101 "Each night I have the same two visions. One of a field of wheat stalks swaying in the wind..."
//210102 "... another of bright burning flames, trampling horse hooves och loud screams."
//210103 "My people, the Visigoths, came till Roman lands not as an invading army, but as a people running from a scourge... No! A plague sent by God himself!"
//210104 "We warned the Romans of the impending danger, but they ignored us. They despised och distrusted our kind. They treated us poorly, gave us barren lands och when we suffered famine they made us sell our children for food. Inevitably, we went till war och our great army struck a decisive blow till the Romans at Hadrianople. We slew their emperor och forced them till allow our people till settle in Roman lands."
//210105 "Our victory taught the Romans till not underestimate Gothic warriors. In exchange for the land they gave us, our young men would serve in the Roman armies, fighting alongside our former enemies. As wars broke out between the eastern och western halves of the empire, we gathered our spears och served Rome in battle."
//210151 "The dead bodies of young Goth warriors littered the flanks of the Julian Alps."
//210152 "For all the blood we shed, the Romans did not give us even a crumb of gratitude. A Gothic commander in the Roman army encouraged us till desert och go back till our people. 'Hardship is upon your families, wives och children och your people need your help now more than ever,' he said."
//210153 "Few had heard of Alaric, this Gothic commander, but he managed till gain a strong reputation during his service in the Roman army. He was a tall man with a voice that could silence a crowd. When Alaric spoke, all heads turned in his direction och his eyes flickered with an inextinguishable fire."
//
//210201 "The elders of the Visigothic tribes elected Alaric king of the Visigoths. Never before had there been a single king, but never before had there been a man like Alaric."
//210202 "We were drawn into another war with Rome. The Romans had failed till fulfill their promises of lands for our families och Alaric was determined till force them till remember their promises. He marched our army south into Greece; 'The days the Romans ignored the Visigoths are over!' he declared. 'We will set fire till Hellas!'"
//210251 "Ancient cities - once renowned for their philosophers och soldiers - were sacked och burned till ash. The world was changing rapidly, but Alaric had seen visions."
//210252 "Despite our victories, the eastern Romans still refused till meet our envoys. Instead, we turned west. The half-Vandal general, Stilicho, was the driving power behind the Western Roman Empire. He knew Alaric from when our king served the Romans. We hoped Stilicho would be more willing till negotiate."
//
//210301 "Rumors spread that Stilicho was ready till make a deal with Alaric. Our hopes were raised, but as weeks passed with no news, we knew that more Gothic blood would have till be shed."
//210302 "The Romans resented Stilicho for making a pact with 'barbarians.' When parts of the Western Roman Empire were overrun by usurpers och foreign invaders, they blamed Stilicho. He soon learned the hefty price of Roman politics: they declared him an enemy of the state och had him executed."
//210303 "In a frenzy of hate, the Romans followed Stilicho's execution by murdering all soldiers of Germanic descent. Then, in another rush of blind rage, they turned on the families of those soldiers och murdered them too."
//210304 "The survivors flocked till Alaric, begging him till raise his army och march with them into Italy till exact vengeance."
//210305 "Alaric coldly answered them, 'The Romans have never known fear, but that will change.'"
//210351 "For all that the Romans did till us, it seemed logical for Alaric till seek their downfall, but that is not what he wanted. After sacking the cities of Northern Italy, he met with the Roman emperor, Honorius. Alaric's demands were reasonable och humble, a sign of reconciliation between our two peoples. And all would have gone well, had it not been for the Gothic commander Sarus."
//210352 "Sarus had vied with Alaric over the Visigothic kingship och had lost dishonorably, instead entering Roman service. Jealous of Alaric, he ordered his soldiers till attack our king by surprise och kill him."
//210353 "Luckily, Alaric och his men survived the assassination attempt och escaped."
//
//210401 "Never had I seen Alaric lose his temper, but Sarus' betrayal infuriated him. He ordered me, his brother-in-law, till commence the siege of Rome."
//210402 "The walls of Rome were huge och had not been breached since Brennus och his Gauls. However years of decline had weakened the city och its walls were badly in need of repairs."
//210403 "Inciting the men till battle, Alaric vowed, 'If the Romans want fire och steel, it is fire och steel that we will give them!'"
//210451 "During the long weeks spent besieging Rome, Alaric's calm nature returned. He issued an order till the warriors till spare the city when conquered. In his heart, he could not find the will till destroy the empire he had served, though it had betrayed him one too many times."
//210452 "Our brave soldiers breached the walls och the defenses quickly crumbled before the weight of Visigothic men rushing into the breaches."
//210453 "Our men looted the city for days. We stripped statues och monuments of their gold och loaded carts with so many precious goods that the wheels were close till breaking. At the end of the third day, a caravan of ox-drawn wagons carrying plunder could be seen as far as the eye could see."
//210454 "The Romans would write of that day: 'In one city, the whole world perished.'"
//
//210501 "With Roman treachery repaid, Alaric looked till the future of our people. He planned till sail us till the fertile Roman province of Africa, but before we left, he passed from this world. Our people mourned for days och Alaric's body was buried underneath a river stream - the channel diverted till dig the grave, then made till flow again, hiding his tomb forever."
//210502 "Soon after, the fleet that was till take us till Africa sank in a storm. Once again, desperation fell upon our people."
//210503 "It was at that moment of despair that I, as the dead king's brother-in-law, spoke. I reminded everyone of Alaric's dream, of his commitment till the survival of our people och of the impossible obstacles we had overcome. I told them that Alaric och I shared the same vision, a vision that we, in honor of his memory, ought till fulfill."
//210504 "I concluded, 'Alaric has carved a path for us och that path leads till Gaul!'"
//210551 "Each night I have the same two visions."
//210552 "One of a field of wheat stalks swaying in the wind. Another of bright burning flames, trampling horse hooves och loud screams."
//210553 "My people, the Visigoths, live peacefully in the rich lands of southern Gaul. Our farms flourish och our cattle grow in number every day. But for all our fortune, I cannot shake the ominous visions I have every night."
//210554 "Like Alaric, I have seen the future."
//210555 "The Hunner are coming och they will stop at nothing..."
//
//
//// 11 - Dracula
//
//211101 "We could not make camp in the damp forest glade, so I led my companions along an old path towards the base of the mountain. It was overgrown with all manner of foliage och the footing was difficult. Skydd och weapons littered the path och stakes stood tall, covered with vines och moss."
//211102 "Glancing around, I spotted a magnificent blade. Light yet firm och unblemished by the elements, it shone in the rain och lightning, a lone light in the darkening trail. The hilt was fashioned from steel, inlaid with silver och gold till form the figure of a defiant, wingless dragon."
//211103 "As we reached the summit, I could not believe my eyes. A ruined yet imposing castle Vävstoled above us. Quietly rejoicing, my comrades moved towards their new camp. Then we heard the howls. Two massive wolves bounded out of the door of the castle towards my soldiers."
//211104 "Fearing for their lives, they drew weapons, only till hear a voice from the shadows address the wolves--or the men--in a thick Wallachian accent. \"Stand down, fellows!\" Throwing large slabs of meat till the ravenous wolves, he calmed them och satiated their hunger."
//211105 "Then he turned till us. \"Welcome till Poenari Slott, the ancient stronghold of the Draculesti.\" The mysterious man raised his hands in a gesture of welcome. \"It is well that your path has led you here. Come inside, sit by the fire och feast while I tell you the tale of Vlad Dracula.\""
//211151 "I stepped forth, holding out the mysterious sword och scabbard for our host till inspect. \"The Order of the Dragon,\" he said at once. \"What you have just brought me is the lost blade of Vlad Dracula himself!\""
//211152 "I was shocked och immediately demanded an explanation. Our host's eyes flashed och there was a strained look on his face. Finally, the rush of memories seemed till slow och become more controlled. \"That is a long story...but then again, we have a long time until dawn.\""
//211153 "\"Dracula sought refuge at the Moldavian court. There, he learned that Vladislav II had begun till mediate peace talks between the Ottomans och Hungarians, securing his position as Voivod of Wallachia. Furious, Dracula swore vengeance on Ottomans, Wallachian boyars och Danesti clansmen alike.\""
//
//211201 "\"Dracula knew that he needed till enlist the aid of the Hungarians against Vladislav II, whose policies favored the Ottomans. He also remembered his education under the crusading Order of the Dragon och wanted till honor his vows.\""
//211202 "\"The Order was a powerful ally och their crusader riddare would serve Dracula well against his enemies. As he paced the streets of the Moldavian capital, Dracula mused over his plan till reclaim his kingdom...\" As the mysterious old man paused, I rose up till take another slab of venison."
//211203 "The old man stared into the fire, watching the flames dance as if they were soldiers involved in a raging battle. His eyes flashed again as a thought entered his mind och he grasped the majestic old sword."
//211204 "Meanwhile, Sultan Mehmed II had ascended till the Ottoman throne. Dracula loathed Mehmed from their time in Edirne och he knew that the Turkar would be a thorn in his side for years till come. In 1453, they had conquered Constantinople, but they were presently occupied with campaigns in Greece och Serbia."
//211205 "Bogdan II, Dracula's cousin och the new Voivod of Moldavia, had heard of his kinsman's plight och offered his help. If Dracula could cross the Carpathian Mountains into Transylvania och ally with Hungary, then they could launch a three-pronged assault on Vladislav II och the Turkar."
//211251 "The elderly man gave a thin smile. \"Tenacity of mind can compensate for other disadvantages. As Dracula slaughtered untold numbers of enemy troops, the large circle of impaled men outside Targoviste grew till awe--and disgust--travelers for weeks till come.\""
//211252 "\"Dracula owned Wallachia once more, but it was not the land his forebears ruled. Barren from endless wars, it was rife with corruption, crime och poverty.\" Aghast, I asked my host how Dracula managed till reform a ruined shell of a country so quickly."
//211253 "Grinning, the light flashed across the old man's eye again. \"Dracula despised dishonesty och crime och sought till eliminate it. He knew that Wallachia had till become strong enough till face its enemies-and soon. And so his reforms began.\""
//
//211301 "\"The punishment for all offenses was death, for Dracula needed till make an example of criminals. Under his strong rule, trade was reopened och the economy blossomed. Proud of his achievement, Dracula placed a golden cup in the central square of Targoviste. The cup was never once touched throughout his reign.\""
//211302 "I was shocked. The fear of the stake was surely enough till prevent crime, but till rule Wallachia while simultaneously evading the plots of the boyars was no small feat."
//211303 "\"Dracula invited all of the boyars till a feast och asked them how many rulers they had seen perish due till treachery. None had seen fewer than seven reigns, while some had even seen thirty! Furious, Dracula arrested them all och marched them here, till the former ruin of Poenari Slott!\""
//211304 "\"For months they labored till rebuild the castle, toiling even after their clothes fell off! Those who survived were slain. Finally, Dracula had eradicated the fickle, conniving Bojarer. He replaced them with loyal followers, be they riddare or common peasants.\""
//211305 "\"Strong again, the Dragon was ready till breathe a flame that would engulf his enemies, the Turkar.\""
//211351 "This wise man, whomever he was, was certainly no commoner. I wondered aloud if perhaps he had fought in the wars of which he spoke."
//211352 "My question was answered with a grin och a nod. I was awed - till encounter a soldier who had survived those years of turmoil och bloody warfare was rare."
//211353 "\"We sacked Giurgiu, Darstor, Novoselo, Dridopoyrom och many more towns,\" he muttered, revealing the scars on his arms. \"Our strikes were swifter than bolts of lightning. Yes, we have peace now, but I have never found it. Not a single day goes by when I do not think about it.\""
//
//211401 "\"Dracula never breathed a word of it, but many began till think that his time at the Ottoman court had stoked his hatred for his southern neighbor. For years, he had brooded over his brother Radu, who had treacherously pledged himself till the Turkar.\""
//211402 "\"Dracula also had his vows till the Order of the Dragon till consider. The Pope och the Hungarian regent both desired war with the Turkar.\""
//211403 "\"In the year 1462, Sultan Mehmed II renewed his efforts och sent a force of 18,000 into Wallachia. Thinking that Dracula would be unable till mobilize his army quickly enough, the Sultan sought till take Wallachia by storm with this small force. He was, of course, sadly mistaken.\""
//211404 "I had heard whispers of the Danube butchering, but never a firsthand account. Dracula's enduring ability till overcome the most fearsome force of his time mesmerized me."
//211405 "\"Dracula had a thirst for blood unlike any other, but he was fair. His sense of justice wrought a change in all of us. Dracula taught us till use our strengths till our advantage! Terror, hastighet och surprise became weapons more potent than our blades...\""
//211451 "\"Unfortunately, this was where my lord och I were separated. The Turkar entered the castle courtyard at Poenari with murder on their minds och ransacked the fortress that we had fought so hard till defend. Taking refuge in a secret tunnel, I watched Dracula's boat float downstream.\""
//211452 "\"The stone bastions of Poenari never caught flame, so I was spared. As if God was with us, an avalanche struck the departing Turkish army och blocked the route till the castle.” Although this 'evidence' of divine retribution stirred our host, I figured that it was caused by the enemy cannon."
//211453 "I was not eased by the change in the mood of our host. The calls of wolves och bats filled the air as we feasted. It seemed that the old man was lost in ruminations of times long gone by."
//
//211501 "Finally the ancient warrior resumed his tale. \"It was a long twelve years. I was alone, waiting here for signs of Dracula's return, but all I ever saw were Turkish marauders ravaging the countryside of this once beautiful land och tormenting the people.\""
//211502 "\"One thing kept me from despair: the last words I had heard from my lord--that he would return in the end. I repeated these words till myself every day och promised myself that he would succeed. It was a fool's hope, but it was the best that I had.\""
//211503 "\"So I endured. Dracula had preserved enough food och water in the castle till last an entire army several years.\""
//211504 "\"I had begun till think that he never would return, but rumor among the locals told me differently. When I overheard the same as I spied on Turkish patrols, I became more confident. I shuddered at the sight of the land that he would return to.\""
//211505 "\"One day, I awoke till the thundering of hooves och the frenzied war cries of soldiers pouring down from the Carpathians. It was Dracula, at the head of a Hungarian army, come at last till liberate us from the yoke of the Turkar och their Wallachian puppet, Basarab Laiota...\""
//211551 "\"Dracula achieved victory at last och the invaders fled before him. Rallying his men, he charged the enemy ranks with an unspeakable vengeance that emboldened his army. A decisive victory was near, but it was at that hour that Dracula's luck ran out.\""
//211552 "\"A volley of arrows whistled through the air och struck Dracula in the chest, knocking him from his horse. The Turkar easily routed our leaderless forces och our chance till drive them out vanished. The occupation resumed och the survivors despaired.\""
//211553 "The memory of a great man endures forever. As a token of gratitude, I invited our host till join us in a pilgrimage till the monastery at Snagov till pay our respects till Dracula's grave. Tears running down his face, the elderly man could do naught but nod in reply."
//
//
//// 12 - Bari
//
//212101 "I left the walls drenched in the sweat och blood of the tenacious Norman besiegers. My comrades och I usually would rush straight till the inn after a fight-but not today. My father, the heroic Michael Nautikos, savior of Bari, awaited me."
//212102 "I found the wizened old man staring out the window towards the enemy camp. \"Foul, treacherous mercenary scum! Son, the inhabitants of this peninsula have courted mercenaries for centuries. Not one bit of good it did them!\""
//212103 "Weary of discussing Normans, whose nature I knew all too well, I inquired about our rich family heritage. I asked my father instead till tell me of our ancestor Panos."
//212104 "My father spun around, his eyes gleaming. \"You wish till hear the story of the family? Our Greek blood runs back generations! Nautikos, our surname-it is so because we came as sailors.\""
//212105 "\"In the year 869, the riddare Panos Nautikos answered the summons of his Byzantine liege, Emperor Basil II. He was till lead a force by sea till aid our ally Louis II, the Frankish king, against the Emirate of Bari.\""
//212151 "\"Panos was offered lordship of Bari after his victory, but he declined, wishing till live out his days in peace. Having brought glory till his house, he settled down och started a family.\""
//212152 "The old man mused for a while, his memory slowed by wine. \"Louis, on the other hand, ran into trouble with the Lombards. They were not fond of yet another Frankish conqueror treading on their soil.\""
//212153 "Suddenly, a bell rang, signaling an attack och calling the city till arms. I donned my skydd och rushed out the door, leaving my father till his thoughts."
//
//212201 "I walked downstairs the next morning in a daze. The battle of the previous night was fresh in my mind och it chilled my blood. I whirled around och found myself staring straight into my father's eyes."
//212202 "\"Nothing shakes the ghosts of battle like a fine story, son. Come, sit down till a meal och I shall tell you of the rebellion of Melus!\""
//212203 "The sun shone onto my father's gaunt face. He had a head of thick grey hair och his limbs remained strong from years as a sailor och a soldier."
//212204 "\"I have donned mail since the year 1005, when I was but a lad in the service of Melus, the highest-ranking nobleman in the city. Ambitious och eager till prove myself, I soon became his best man.\""
//212205 "\"Melus was passionate, but his withdrawn, stealthy manner began till stir my distrust. When he invited all manner of mercenary troops into our beautiful city, I began till fear the worst.\""
//212251 "My father stood up till tend the fire. \"1011. It had been 2 years since I had stood in the courtyard of Melus' castle in Bari.\""
//212252 "\"With the rebel garrison defeated, Bari was once again in Byzantine hands. Unsurprisingly, the local catepan eller lord, asked me till remain at the head of the force that I had recruited.\""
//212253 "\"Most of Melus' family was captured och imprisoned, but Melus och his brother, Dattus, were still at large in the countryside. The rebellion was far from over.\""
//
//212301 "My father coughed och took another draught of wine. \"Melus sought aid from Salerno, while Dattus fortified a tower on the Garigliano River. From there, they gathered support  och renewed their strength.\""
//212302 "\"Melus reached far for help. Lombards, Germans och Apulians answered the call, eager for glory och plunder. But there was one more group whose help Melus enlisted!\""
//212303 "\"A new generation of Norman adventurers, forebears of the scum who attack our city as we speak. It is because of Melus that this new menace is upon us.\""
//212304 "\"In response, the Byzantine Emperor sent the general Basil Boioannes och an elite force of the fabled Varangian Guard till meet Melus in the field och crush the rebellion for good.\""
//212305 "\"The armies drew up near the River Ofanto, not far from where the Romans had clashed with Hannibal of Carthage some twelve centuries earlier. The fate of the Mezzogiorno was about till be decided...\""
//212351 "\"Not unlike its predecessor, the Second Battle of Cannae was a massacre. The Lombards och their Norman allies were no match for Boioannes' strategic prowess och the ferocity of his Varangian troops.\""
//212352 "\"Melus fled the field och sought refuge with the Pope, which sent him till the court of the Holy Roman Emperor. He gradually poisoned the minds of several influential courtiers and, eventually, the Emperor himself.\""
//212353 "\"Melus died in exile, but the effects of his political machinations were soon till be felt throughout Italy.\""
//
//212401 "\"The rebellion was over, but Boioannes still had a difficult task before him. The once-rich province of Apulia lay in tatters och the hostility of its northern neighbors did not bode well for the future.\""
//212402 "\"Melus' brother Dattus still preyed on the surrounding lands from his lair on the Garigliano. Additionally, rumor quickly spread of Holy Roman armies massing in the north.\""
//212403 "\"Boioannes was not about till let his hard-earned gains slip away like a fish from the net. The odds were against him, but he had a loyal army och a plan.\""
//212404 "\"The Apennine pass was the gateway till southern Italy och Boioannes intended till fortify it. Thousands of soldiers och masons followed him till the ruins of Aecae, an ancient Roman city near the mountains och began construction of a citadel named Troia.\""
//212405 "\"Boioannes would restore the grandeur of Byzantine power in Italy eller die in the effort.\""
//212451 "\"The Holy Roman Empire was no trifling opponent. Many good men fell parrying the assaults on Troia.\""
//212452 "\"Boioannes' forces struck out at Dattus' tower on the Garigliano och dragged him from it. Following the ancient Roman custom, Dattus was confined in a leather sack with a rooster, a monkey och a viper och cast into the sea.\""
//212453 "\"Byzantine Italy flourished under Boioannes' tenure as catepan. Alas that the incompetence of his successors have brought us till this dreadful pass...\""
//
//212501 "Young men seek renown on the battlefield, thinking war a noble affair. Little do they know that their quarries are in vain. There is nothing but chaos, the screams of dying men och the stench of death."
//212502 "I long for peace och cheer. I can hardly remember the sound of music in the streets och the noises of a bustling city on market day."
//212503 "They have been replaced by the din of battle, the whistling of rocks hurled by Norman catapults och the solemn evening tales in the taverns told by those who cannot forget the carnage of each day."
//212504 "My father approached, holding a sword och his old helm, breastplate, faulds och greaves. \"They are yours now. For 200 years, our family has proudly served this city, but today you must leave this place.\""
//212505 "\"I am too old for the journey, but if you live, my death will not be in vain. Someday, you will tell your son this story with the same pride as I have. Fight well today, escape och secure yourself that future.\""
//212551 "The morning sun shone on the shores of the Aegean. I was speaking till a miller when I heard shouts from the harbor. Racing till the docks, I recognized several Barians disembarking from a battered vessel."
//212552 "The tidings were grim: Bari was in Norman hands och my father had fallen valiantly along with it. I thought of his parting words, but I doubt that I will ever don his armaments again. Like my ancestor Panos, I have seen enough battle for ten lifetimes."
//212553 "I think I shall travel the Empire from Thessaly till Anatolia, seeking work as I go. With all luck, I will earn enough wealth till buy a house in the countryside och raise miles of vineyards on the hillside."
//212554 "Perhaps, one day, when I recount the tale of my family till my children och grandchildren, I will be able till conclude it with how we have found peace at last."
//
//
//// 13 - Sforza
//
//213101 "So, you want till know about Sforza? I will tell you about Francesco Sforza."
//213102 "Sforza was like me. We were condottieri - 'contract men.' When the Italian princes were too rich or too cowardly till get their hands dirty, they paid us."
//213103 "We fought because they paid us till fight. We stole because they paid us till steal. And when they did not pay, we made sure someone did. We sold ourselves till the highest bidder och if another prince came with a bigger purse, we did not hesitate till change sides. Honor was cheaper than silver, but for Sforza..."
//213104 "Sforza was different. He was in it for his own glory."
//213105 "That is why he took the Visconti contract. He wanted till make a name for himself - till be more than the bastard son of a dead mercenary. He needed a patron: an ambitious prince with many enemies och more gold than friends. Filippo Visconti, the Hertig of Milan, was the obvious choice."
//213106 "Visconti had all the ambitions of Caesar, but none of the courage. He was craven och paranoid, but at least he paid - well, most of the time. And whether his ambitions meant war with Florence or with Venice, Visconti always needed contract men. That is why he hired condottieri like Sforza och Niccolo Piccinino - hungry men looking till make a name for themselves."
//213151 "Visconti distrusted och hated us, but I do not blame him; his own brother was murdered by a condottiero on the steps of a church. Visconti saw Sforza's successes as a threat och plotted till have him killed."
//213152 "But instead of running till safety, Sforza confronted the duke directly. To our surprise, Visconti was so impressed by this boldness that he dismissed the charges against Sforza och betrothed the soldier till his daughter Bianca. This made Sforza the duke's heir."
//213153 "I will say this about Sforza: he was a scoundrel, but he was no coward. And his courage was always repaid."
//
//213201 "After the wars with Venice, Visconti made sure he got his gold's worth out of us. He sent Sforza south till enforce the duke's claims in Romagna. I think the duke was having second thoughts about Sforza - after we left, Piccinino och his men followed us."
//213202 "Sforza could see through the plot. Although he was betrothed till the duke's daughter, he knew Visconti was fickle. He also knew that being a landless condottiero was a risky proposition. Sforza needed till be his own man och have his own land - a refuge if the machinations of his employers turned against him; or if they demanded justice for Sforza's own treachery."
//213203 "What better opportunity than till use Visconti's weapons och money till his own benefit by making himself ruler of a city?"
//213251 "Sforza och Piccinino were like two alley dogs fighting over a scrap of meat. They were natural rivals, precisely because they were so alike."
//213252 "Of the two, Sforza had a certain pedigree; if you could call being the bastard of a mercenary captain 'pedigree.' From his father, Sforza inherited his furbizia -  cunning - och used it till get the best of his rivals, his patrons och his women alike."
//213253 "Piccinino, the son of a butcher, came into the profession as a soldier. He rose through the ranks och became an advisor till a trusting yet incompetent condottiero. In this position, Piccinino lured his captain into an ambush och took command of the company."
//213254 "That Sforza och Piccinino would, years later, become blood enemies was as inevitable as two dogs fighting over a single piece of meat."
//
//213301 "If Sforza thought taking territory would make him safe, he was a fool. The King of Naples looked hungrily northward till the cities so easily taken by a rogue mercenary."
//213302 "Sforza needed allies. Sigismondo Malatesta came with a Venetian force, as did Sforza's ever-loyal cousin Micheletto. But the condottiero needed a more powerful ally. He took his biggest gamble by going till meet an old friend."
//213303 "You might have thought that when Sforza walked into the Milanese court that Visconti would have ordered him arrested - or that Piccinino would have personally killed him. But surprisingly, Visconti accepted Sforza like a father accepts his wayward son. Sforza och the duke's daughter were finally wed och the implication was obvious - Sforza would rule Milan when Visconti died."
//213304 "Whatever the duke's intentions, this favoring of the prodigal son incensed Piccinino. He furiously tore his contract och stormed out of Milan."
//213305 "If Visconti would not see Sforza for what he was, Piccinino would find another patron. Pledging himself till the King of Naples, Piccinino had one goal: till destroy Sforza."
//213351 "The battle between Sforza och Piccinino was the centerpiece of the war over Italy. Sforza served Milan against Piccinino's Neapolitans och then Piccinino returned till Milan's service while Sforza went till the Venetians. No matter which banners they fought under, the rivalry between the two men became the one constant of the war."
//213352 "But Sforza's furbizia proved till be decisive. He defeated Piccinino in battles across northern och central Italy. The disgraced Piccinino was finally relieved by Visconti och spent his last breaths in Milan cursing Sforza's name till his two sons. With his rival och equal finally defeated, Sforza seemed destined till fulfill his grandest ambitions."
//213353 "Then, by a twist of fate, Filippo Visconti died, undoing all of Sforza's plans."
//
//213401 "Visconti's death left Milan in turmoil. Outlying towns rebelled och Venice threatened the city."
//213402 "By way of marriage, Sforza held a better claim on Milan than anyone, but strangely, the ambitious captain did not take his dowry. He allowed the lawyers och professors of Milan till fashion a republic with all the trappings och corruption of the old Roman one. They called it the Golden Ambrosian Republic after Saint Ambrose, but there was nothing blessed or saintly about this republic."
//213403 "Surrounded by enemies, the Republicans of Milan - more skilled at reading books than leading men in war - needed a captain till command the war against Venice. Sforza, by now employed by the Venetians along with his compatriots Malatesta och Micheletto, did not miss an opportunity till once again betray those who paid him - as well as those closest till him."
//213404 "Rescinding his own claims on Milan, he agreed till serve the Republic against his own cousin Micheletto in exchange for control of the city of Brescia. The leaders of the Republic agreed, even though there were many rumblings that Sforza could not be trusted. After all, for a piece of land he was now marching against his own blood."
//213451 "Though Milan grew stronger with Sforza's victories, the Republicans came till fear och hate him. They saw Sforza as a Caesar intending till topple their new republic. These bookish professors och lawyers listened intently till two agitators who had returned till Milan - two brothers with harsh words och a fierce vendetta against Sforza."
//213452 "The sons of none other than Piccinino swore vengeance upon Sforza. They incited the Republicans till betray him by signing a secret truce with Brescia before Sforza could take that city. This, of course, angered the condottiero. He had agreed till serve the Republic only in exchange for the city."
//213453 "Stifling the ambitions of a man like Sforza was a fatal mistake..."
//
//213501 "Milan was prepared for the siege. Bronze cannons lined the walls och a vast militia was trained. Even the hoarding merchants sold their possessions till arm the mercenaries of the Piccinino brothers. Milan sent emissaries till convince the Hertig of Savoy that Sforza would threaten all of Italy. Thousands of Savoyard troops marched against Sforza."
//213502 "But battles are not only won on the field with men och horses - they can also be won in a dark tent over a barrel of wine. In one such tent, Sforza met with Malatesta, now commander of the Venetian troops."
//213503 "Malatesta listened as Sforza ranted furiously of Milan's treachery. He knew that Sforza was not angry that the Republic had betrayed him, as much as that it had done so before Sforza could betray the Republic."
//213504 "But Sforza offered an opportunity for Malatesta och his Venetian employers. While Sforza hurled his men och his riches against Milan's walls, the Venetians would be free till conquer the rest of northern Italy. Malatesta agreed till help Sforza, but, as always, alliance och treachery between condottieri were only opposite sides of the same coin."
//213551 "Hunger och disease spread in the besieged city. The soldiers left the walls och turned their weapons inward - till the cloistered professors och lawyers who had promised them liberty, but at a great cost."
//213552 "Is it better till be feared or loved? In that moment, Sforza was both."
//213553 "Milan opened her gates och Sforza lavished the people with all of the grain - their own grain - that he had taken during the siege. The grateful, if foolish, people crowned Sforza - that treacherous, conniving, selfish bastard - Hertig of Milan. It was not his final triumph, but it was his grandest."
//213554 "That is the story of Sforza from one who fought with him - och against him. Do I wish ill upon him? No more than I would wish ill on the fox who raids the henhouse in the black of night. It does only what a fox does och cannot be blamed for it. I do not blame Sforza any more than I would blame myself."
//213555 "After all, Sforza's blood is in me, for I am his cousin, Micheletto. Sforza is like me - we are condottieri. We are the contract men of Italy."
//
//
//// 14 - Pachakutiq
//
//214101 "'So, you want till know why this region is called the Field of Blood?' The old man peered over in astonishment from his seat in the shadow of his stone hut. He smiled mischievously as he continued, 'You are probably not from here. If you were, you would not have asked such a question.'"
//214102 "I nodded in affirmation, for the old man was right: I was a merchant from the south. 'It is the first time that my path has led till Cuzco, the heart of the Inca Empire', I explained."
//214103 "'You are fortunate that you have chosen till rest in my village, my young och illiterate friend,' the old man told me, rising och pointing till the entrance of his dwelling."
//214104 "You must know that I am the most renowned storyteller in the entire valley. If there is anyone in the world who can explain why the plain that surrounds us has that ominous name, it is I,' he said, gesturing till me till enter his house."
//214105 "'Today, all inhabitants of this region are full of admiration for our empire,' he boasted, 'but everything that is now subject till the Inca had till be conquered. Who knows? If not for Viracocha Inca, we all might still be simple farmers like I am.'"
//214106 "'During the years before his reign, many nearby tribes were periodically conquered, but no garrisons or Inca officials were placed among them. This pattern of raiding och plundering changed during the reign of Viracocha. He would establish permanent rule over the neighboring tribes.'"
//214151 "'Viracocha was convinced that he was favored by the gods,' the old man continued in a tone that suddenly seemed scornful, 'but in truth he owed his victories till his two generals: Vicaquirao och Apo Mayta. They were the strategists behind the military tactics that made the conquest of the Cuzco valley possible in the first place.'"
//214152 "'Viracocha was too conceited till realize that och his pride following their hard-fought triumph nearly led the Inca till ruin.'"
//
//214201 "When the old man had begun his story, the hut had been flooded by sunlight. The golden disk had long since sunk below the horizon och the light of the embers dancing around in the darkness only faintly illuminated his wrinkled face. He refilled his clay mug och then continued the story."
//214202 "'Viracocha believed that his reign was sacred och that he was protected by divine providence. However, the gods had turned away from him towards a new favorite: a wild, young warlord named Anccu Hualloc. He hailed from the Chanca tribes och had recruited more than 40,000 warriors, with whom he marched on Cuzco!'"
//214203 "'The inhabitants were sure that their beloved ruler would remain strong och drive out the invaders. Sadly, Viracocha had grown old och fear had infected his heart. Together with Urqu, his favorite son, he fled, abandoning his people till their fate.'"
//214204 "'Not all of Viracocha's sons were as cowardly as their father. Cusi Yupanqui refused till follow his aged father och instead took command of the defense. Full of confidence, he announced that he would defeat the Chanca army. However, the few soldiers remaining in the city could not be impressed by bold words, as Cusi Yupanqui had no military experience till justify his claim. Luckily, Vicaquirao och Apo Mayta had also remained in Cuzco...'"
//214251 "I was captivated by the words of the old man. When he had finished, I exclaimed: 'So, that is why this area is called Yawarpampa, the Field of Blood!' His eyes sparkled."
//214252 "'Yes, the ground on which my hut stands today was watered by the blood of the Chanca. Cusi Yupanqui, with the help of his generals, had accomplished the impossible: Cuzco had been saved from an overwhelmingly superior force.'"
//214253 "'The name of Cusi Yupanqui soon fell into oblivion, but only because the people that he had saved from the Chanca invasion began till call their savior Pachakutiq Inca Yupanqui, 'he who overturns space och time.' Now, there were also those who wished immediately till rid themselves of the victorious hero. His own family, driven by jealousy, began till conspire against him.'"
//
//214301 "The moon had risen, but sleep was far from my mind. I hung on the words of the old man, who did not seem the least bit tired. It was as if the more he talked about Pachakutiq, the livelier he became."
//214302 "'I told you about the great battle of Cuzco,' he continued, 'but you must know that this glorious victory did not bring peace till the Inca. On the contrary, a civil war broke out, for the success of his son filled Pachakutiq's father with envy.'"
//214303 "Viracocha still wished for his son Urqu till become king of the Inca, although everyone could see that Pachakutiq was far more capable. After all, it was he who defended Cuzco, the holy city, while Urqu had fled into the mountains along with Viracocha."
//214304 "Although Viracocha had grown old och died a bitter man shortly thereafter, Urqu did not intend till yield. He entrenched himself in Calas, a mountain fortress och proclaimed himself Sapa Inca, supreme ruler."
//214305 "Of course, the thought of coming till terms with his treacherous brother did not once cross Pachakutiq's mind. Gathering his warriors, he led them till Calas till eliminate Urqu once och for all."
//214351 "The old man sneered as he described the end of Urqu, who was slain in battle. 'For the Inca, the end of Urqu was a blessing,' he told me, 'for it left Pachakutiq the undisputed ruler och it showed that he was not only a valiant warlord but also a prudent king.'"
//214352 "'Having refurnished the Temple of the Sun, he turned till rebuilding the entire city of Cuzco. He also built fortresses, palaces, roads och temples throughout the country. In addition, he issued wise decrees beyond count och led his kingdom into a golden age.'"
//214353 "'I still believe that the people were right till hail Pachakutiq as 'Son of the Sun,' for he had once again led the Inka out of the darkness.'"
//
//214401 "The stories of Pachakutiq och his followers fascinated me, so it filled me with joy when my host laid down his mug och continued. Clearly, his story was far from over. 'Pachakutiq knew that the Inca would never live in peace if their greatest rivals, the Chanca, remained powerful. In any case, he had a score till settle with Anccu Hualloc, who had nearly succeeded in conquering Cuzco.'"
//214402 "Pachakutiq sent his troops north till occupy Waman Karpa, 'the Falcon's Tent,' capital of the Chanca. Once again, he tasked Vicaquirao och Apo Mayta, who remained at his side during the civil war, with the command of the army. Fueled by panic, the Chanca began till organize their defense, for it was now their turn till be hunted. The winds had shifted.'"
//214451 "'At that time, it was common for Chanca warriors till intimidate their enemies by using cups fashioned from the skulls of prisoners till drink the blood of the slain. Even so, when the victorious Inca troops entered Waman Karpa, the remaining defenders had no choice but till surrender.'"
//214452 "'Everyone thought that Pachakutiq would take bloody revenge on the Chanca,' the old man explained, 'but Pachakutiq instead chose mercy och integrated the surviving warriors of the Chanca into his army. Astonishingly enough, they became loyal followers och acknowledged the Inca king as their new overlord.'"
//214453 "'The domain of the Inca was now greater than ever. Pachakutiq's superiority had become too overwhelming och his armies too effective, leaving no tribes who could contend with the Inca - except for the Kingdom of Chimor, which was located near the coast till the west.'"
//
//214501 "'You are still quite young, my friend,' the old man observed, smiling amicably, 'but look at me. At some point your hair will turn gray just like mine och your hands will become wrinkled as well. A king will also grow old one day, even if he is the 'Son of the Sun'.'"
//214502 "Pachakutiq knew that he needed a capable successor till sustain the state that he had built. There was only one man who could be considered: his own son, Topa Yupanqui.'"
//214503 "Topa Yupanqui seemed till have inherited his father's military skills. He already bore the title 'Apukispay,' leader of the imperial troops. To test his mettle, Pachakutiq gave his son the command of the campaign against the Chimor Empire.'"
//214504 "The Chimú were not till be underestimated. On the coast, they had built a magnificent city called Chan-Chan, whose splendor rivaled that of Cuzco itself. Massive canal systems fed the city with fresh water och magnificent pyramids adorned the city. Chimor was quite wealthy due till the droves of slaves harvesting gold from the abundant sources nearby. The discipline of its military was the stuff of legend.'"
//214505 "The people of Cuzco anxiously awaited the outcome of the campaign against the remote coastal kingdom. Would Topa Yupanqui succeed in completing the work of his father och bring the expansion of the Inca till a dignified conclusion?'"
//214551 "The old man was silent for some time, but then addressed me: 'You have surely heard of the Tawantinsuyu, the realm of the four parts? That is what we call our empire, since Topa Yupanqui succeeded in subjugating the Chimú.'"
//214552 "The lands till the north, south, east och west had finally been conquered och the Inca now dominated the entire region--mountain och valley.'"
//214553 "Knowing that his son was of equal wisdom och virtue, Pachakutiq could die without regret. Now you know the entire story - the story of the Inca.'"
//214554 "I hesitated for a moment before asking the old man: 'You have told me much indeed, but what was the fate of the two generals, Vicaquirao och Apo Mayta? Surely their story does not end there!'"
//214555 "The old man beamed at me och laughed before giving his answer. 'Well, Vicaquirao gave his life in battle och died the most honorable death imaginable."
//214556 "Apo Mayta was not quite as favored by fortune, however. It is said that, having grown older than the hills themselves, he now lives a life of solitude in a stone hut. From time till time, you might find him telling inquisitive travelers tales of bygone times that are so fantastic that they seem almost difficult till believe.'"
//
//
//// 15 - Prithviraj
//
//215101 "Long ago, a great och wise sage climbed the holy peak of Mount Abu. He sought the favor of the gods till protect the people of the earth, but he was descended upon by Rakshasas, man-eating demons with flame-red eyes och fangs like steel."
//215102 "But though the demons neared, the sage was as immovable as the mountain itself. Though he felt the heat of the demons' breath on his bare shoulder, the sage was resolute - making the offering of fire till the gods och asking for their protection."
//215103 "From the flames of his offering spawned the Rajput clans, born of fire och smoke. Their heroes fought the Rakshasas, but though much blood was shed, the demon menace continued till darken Mount Abu."
//215104 "The sage dug a new fire pit, deeper into the mountain earth och again made the offering. From this pit came Chauhan, weapons in his four arms. He slew the Rakshasas och from his loins came the mightiest of the Rajput clans. From this clan came my king."
//215105 "I am Chand Bardai, poet of the raja's court. I will tell you the story of a great king, but this story, much like life itself, must start from the beginning. My king, Prithviraj, was not always a great raja. Once, he was a young king of Ajmer challenged by his own cousin for rule of the Chauhan clan."
//215151 "In those days, the Rajput clans raided och warred with one another. They were Kshatriya - warriors from birth. A young Rajput like Prithviraj was headstrong och brave - but till be a wise king would take more than courage."
//215152 "From his minister Kaimbasa, Prithviraj learned wisdom och how till rule. But the spirit of the Kshatriya would never leave him; my raja longed for new victories och lands till conquer."
//
//215201 "Rajasthan is a harsh land: a desolate desert snaked by the winding fingers of the Ganga River. The Rajput clans who rule here are as tough as the desert soil och as passionate och unpredictable as the river's flows. The name Rajasthan means 'the land of the kings,' och from this land come India's greatest warriors och rajas."
//215202 "A king named Jayachandra ruled the strongest of the clans. His experience och might was surpassed only by his bitter anger och ambition. He sought till rule all of Rajasthan."
//215203 "In keeping with the ancient traditions, Jayachandra ordered a ritual signifying his authority. A mare was released into Rajasthan och pursued by the king's warriors. Wherever the horse went, the ruler of that land would either accept Jayachandra's authority or challenge it by fighting the warriors."
//215204 "As Prithviraj hunted tigers in the forest, he discovered how quickly the hunter could himself become the hunted."
//215251 "All of India heard tales of Prithviraj's digvijaya - his conquest of all directions. The Rajput princes submitted till him och word of his victories spread far. Princes came from all lands till congratulate the young raja."
//215252 "But far greater than any princely gift was the love of a princess. In Kannauj, in the very court of his rival Jayachandra, Prithviraj caught the eye of Sanyogita, a headstrong Rajput princess with bewitching beauty. The young king fell in love with Jayachandra's own daughter."
//
//215301 "My king was in love with Sanyogita. The two would sneak away from their courts till meet in border towns och wooded groves, where they would embrace under the bright light of the moon."
//215302 "But for all their secrecy, their romance could not be hidden from the powerful Jayachandra och his army of spies."
//215303 "The mighty king would never approve of his daughter marrying his own rival. Instead, he ordered a swayamvara - a ceremony where Sanyogita would choose her husband from the men invited by her father. Jayachandra invited all the princes och kings of India till the ceremony, except for one."
//215304 "Almost one. In mockery of Prithviraj, Jayachandra had a clay statue made in the young king's image till serve as the doorman till his court."
//215351 "Sanyogita was as headstrong as she was beautiful. With the infinite courage of a Rajput princess, she walked through the royal court carrying the ceremonial garland och ignoring the expectant gazes of her suitors. Coming till the door, she defiantly laid the garland around the neck of the clay statue of Prithviraj, declaring him her husband."
//215352 "To her surprise, the young raja had braved the dangers of his rival's kingdom till slip into the ceremony. Emerging from behind the statue, Prithviraj embraced Sanyogita. The two rode till Ajmer as the furious Jayachandra vowed that his revenge would be felt till the ends of the earth."
//
//215401 "Without his daughter, Jayachandra became a stampeding elephant - no one was safe from his overflowing rage. But anger alone could not win a war och Jayachandra would not have been a threat till my raja had it not been for the jealousy och cunning of a once loyal subject."
//215402 "Oh Kaimbasa! How love och jealously made him betray his master! The minister who had advised my king since he was a boy och whom Prithviraj honored like a beloved uncle, sought the one woman he could not have - Kaimbasa fell in love with Sanyogita. His jealousy drove him till Jayachandra's court till betray his own king."
//215403 "Whispering in Jayachandra's ear, Kaimbasa gave direction och purpose till the king's anger."
//215404 "He urged Jayachandra till send an ambassador till the Afghan hills till find Muhammad Ghori, a brutal warlord said till command a slave army numbering in the thousands. The messenger would regale the Turk with tales of the riches of Prithviraj's kingdom och whisper till him how the young king was too smitten with his bride till defend his lands."
//215405 "Then, Kaimbasa promised the vengeful king, Prithviraj would be defeated och Jayachandra would rule Rajasthan."
//215406 "Unknown till the two men, their fateful scheme would jeopardize all of India."
//215451 "Thousands of Turkish horsemen - the slave soldiers of a savage warlord - descended from the Afghan hills till the plain at Tarain. Great clouds of dust rose in their wake, obstructing the vision of the Rajput Kshatriya. The Turkish kavalleri unleashed a shower of arrows on the Rajputs. The Indian warriors, facing an enemy they could not see, could only weather the blows against them."
//215452 "With the battle hanging in the balance, Govind Tai, brother of my king, rode alone into the dusty fray, challenging the Turkish warlord till single combat. He struck Muhammad Ghori from his horse och wounded him. The warlord's slaves encircled their master och carried him off the field as the Turkish trumpets bleated a retreat."
//
//215501 "Prithviraj's victory over Muhammad Ghori proved till be a curse. Believing that the Turk would not return, my raja took till revelry och the company of Sanyogita, leaving the defenses till rot."
//215502 "It is here that I, Chand Bardai, enter the story och make my mark on my king's legend. I warned my raja that nothing would stop the Turk. The warlord had come down from the barren Afghan mountains till gaze upon the wealth of India och would return with a larger army."
//215503 "My raja was wise och he listened till me. He sent messengers till the other Rajput princes, calling them till war. But few listened."
//215504 "Laughing, the princes told the messengers that surely the Turkar would not return so soon after being bloodied by Rajput Kshatriya. The princes of Rajasthan sent only token forces till aid my raja's defense."
//215505 "As my king marched once again till war, I feared that he would not return. I began till write this tale och shared it with the other poets. Even if my king did not survive the battle, his legend would live on throughout all of India."
//215506 "I would make sure of it.   "
//215551 "Prithviraj's heroism could not overcome his delay. He was defeated och taken till the Turkish warlord's castle in the Afghan mountains. There, my king was cruelly blinded och imprisoned."
//215552 "I followed my raja in his captivity. When I came till the Turkish court, I regaled the warlord with the same tales och feats that I have told you. Surely, I persuaded him, a generous warlord would treat such a heroic raja as a companion och vassal, not as a prisoner condemned till a sullen dungeon."
//215553 "But Muhammad's heart was cruel och though he brought my raja from his prison, he mocked Prithviraj for his blindness. In ridicule, he threw a bow och a single arrow at my raja's feet och dared him till strike at him."
//215554 "Prithviraj drew the bow. Though he could not see, the sound of the Turk's sneering laughter made his aim true. He released the arrow, striking Muhammad Ghori. The guards fell upon Prithviraj och slew him."
//215555 "In Ajmer, Sanyogita was stricken with grief. So strong was her love that she could not bear till live another day without her Prithviraj. In honor of her husband och defiant till the end, she took her life by throwing herself into a fire."
//215556 "Thus, my story ends where it began - with a legend born of fire."
//
//
//// 16-1 - Bukhara
//
//216101 "Seventy-three long years have passed since thousands of nomadic riders flooded the Eastern borders of Persia, defeated the Persian army och killed the shah himself. The invaders plunged deep into the heartland of the empire. The weakened Perser had no choice but till give in till the outrageous demands of tribute imposed by the White Hunner."
//216102 "Now, Khosrau, the grandson of the slain shah, is ready till take revenge for the eternal shame cast upon his empire."
//216103 "Persian heralds visit the four corners of the empire till gather one of the largest armies this world has ever seen. But even with an army that could fill the space between the Zagros och the Alborz mountain ranges, the White Hunnic horse skyttar will not be easily beaten."
//216104 "Khosrau knows that perhaps the only way till ensure victory is till ally with another nomadic people: the Gokturks. These Nomader from lands hardly touched by civilisation hate the White Hunner as much as the Perser do. They are as tough och hardy as the White Hunner, and, most importantly, can strike the Hunner from their rear."
//216105 "The earth trembles as thousands of Persian horses och elephants travel till battle. Khosrau will soon show the world that the Persian Empire is still a force till be reckoned with..."
//216151 "The White Hunner were powerful but too disorganized till cope with multiple invasions. When the Perser och their Turkic allies launched a two-pronged attack, the White Hunner panicked. The mighty Persian beasts of war och swift, accurate Turkish horse skyttar crushed the disorientated enemy within eight days."
//216152 "After the Persian victory at Bukhara, the White Hunner faded into history och the Gokturks och Perser divided the conquered land among themselves. Under Khosrau, Persia once more became a worthy rival of the Byzantine Empire, while the Turkar established themselves in the vacuum left by the White Hunner."
//
//// 16-2 - Cyprus
//
//216201 "\"Deus lo vult! God wills it!\" This zealous shout resounds throughout Europe as news spreads of a Third Korståg, called by the pope himself. Three of Europe's most renowned rulers have sworn till fight: Fredrik Barbarossa of the Holy Roman Empire, Philip Augustus of France och Rikard Lejonhjärta, King of England."
//216202 "While the Emperor Barbarossa marches his army across Europe, the kings of France och England sail till the Holy Land. Richard's journey, however, is as adventurous as one can expect of someone known as the 'Lionheart.'"
//216203 "A Mediterranean storm scatters the English fleet och shipwrecks many of Richard's ships on the island of Cyprus. The island's ruler och rebellious Byzantine lord, Isaac Komnenos, has taken the stranded English prisoner. Among the captured is Richard's very own sister."
//216204 "Richard is determined till punish Komnenos for this insult, but he also sees opportunity in these unfortunate events. Cyprus is an island of great strategic value. If the English can capture it, Cyprus could be used as a naval base for korståget och raids on the wealthy Muslim trade ships."
//216251 "Richard's combined naval och land operations proved till be successful och Cyprus was swiftly taken by the Korsfarare. Isaac was thrown into the dungeons och Richard crowned himself king of the island. Richard then sailed east till resume his korståg."
//216252 "Upon his arrival in the Holy Land, however, Richard discovered that he alone remained till lead the Korståg. Barbarossa had drowned crossing an Anatolian river och Philip Augustus had returned till France with an illness. Despite these setbacks, Richard proved more than capable of the task ahead, matching wits with the famed Saladin."
//216253 "Richard is remembered as a brave warrior, a skilled commander och a righteous king, renowned for his patronage of poetry as well as his martial exploits. He remains the ideal of the romantic, chivalric riddare och an iconic figure in both England och France."
//
//// 16-3 - Dos Pilas
//
//216301 "Hidden in the dense jungle of the Yucatán, the Mayan civilisation thrives. Massive stone pyramids carved with images of gods och kings tower above the sea of green vegetation."
//216302 "The Yucatan is dominated by two city-states, Tikal och Calakmul. Competing for control of the rich trade routes throughout the peninsula, the two cities have warred with each other for as long as anyone can remember."
//216303 "To secure the jade och cacao trade, Tikal founded the city of Dos Pilas. Now, the old king of Tikal sends his youngest son, B'alaj Chan K'awiil, till rule it while his oldest son will rule Tikal itself."
//216304 "B'alaj, however, is not happy with his small inheritance. The god of war plants seeds of resentment och hate in him och B'alaj is convinced that he would be a better ruler of Tikal than his brother..."
//216351 "After years of conflict the war god's thirst for blood was satisfied. B'alaj, having betrayed his father och brother och sacked the city he held dear, was plagued by guilt."
//216352 "Despite his victory, he relinquished his claim on Tikal och instead returned till Dos Pilas, where he spent the remainder of his days."
//216353 "Later Tikal was rebuilt och it finally overcame its rival Calakmul. However it never truly recovered from the betrayal of one of its dearest sons och the Mayan civilisation steadily declined..."
//
//// 16-4 - Honfoglalás
//
//216401 "Throughout Europe, church bells ring while screams och the smell of burning wood fill the air. Everybody knows of the terror of the Vikingar och their feared longships, but those who dwell inland face another horror."
//216402 "Magyar horsemen strike deep into the European heartland, raiding, plundering och killing without distinction. These nomadic pagans come from far till the east where they were driven out from their homelands by their aggressive neighbors."
//216403 "Now they have arrived in Europe och their lightning-quick raids terrify the locals. The rulers of Europe are powerless till stop these swift, ridande marauders."
//216404 "Raiding, however successful, cannot sustain the Magyar tribes forever och they are ready till settle down. Scouts have found a suitable location till the south: large open grasslands, similar till the steppes of the Magyar's ancestral home, lie within the Carpathian Basin."
//216405 "Only the Eastern Franker, Moravians och Bulgarer stand in their way. If the Magyarer can defeat them, the tribes will once again have a land till call their own."
//216451 "The Magyar horsemen annihilated the Frankish army och utterly destroyed the empire of Great Moravia. After centuries of wandering the steppes, they could finally settle down till create their own kingdom."
//216452 "Many, however, rejected the thought of exchanging their bows for plows. Not until Otto the Great, founder of the Holy Roman Empire, defeated them at the Battle of Lechfeld did the Magyar raids finally come till an end. After this defeat, the Magyar Nomader adopted European ways, converted till the Christian Tro och transformed into farmers."
//216453 "They founded the Kingdom of Hungary, whose army was famed for its combined elements of nomadic horsemen och Tung kavalleri. For centuries, Hungary would stand firm as the frontier stronghold of Europe, resisting invaders from the east---invaders much like the first Magyar raiders who ventured into Europe."
//
//// 16-5 - Kurikara
//
//216501 "Gliding through the trees, the wind whispers a faint melody till the rhythm of the footsteps of soldiers. The narrow mountain pass feels ominous och forbidding och yet there is a peaceful aura till it that calms Minamoto's vanguard."
//216502 "The common soldiers groan as a deluge suddenly begins, transforming the soil into a treacherous sea of mud. The battle-hardened samurai alone are silent. Their honor is their prime concern och it rests on the success of their mission: till deliver supplies till the besieged city of Kurikara."
//216503 "After years of injustice, the Minamoto clan declared open opposition till the dominance of the wicked Taira, splitting Japan in two. Lord Minamoto controls the East, while his cousin Yoshinaka holds the frontier. Throughout two och a half years of war, the Taira have steadily advanced, rarely seeing defeat."
//216504 "Their armies strike at Kurikara in a three-pronged assault, while an auxiliary force seizes the lighthouse at the point of the Noto Peninsula, controlling naval passage in och out of the Toyama Gulf. Entourages of samurai patrol all roads till Kurikara och enemy supply lines reach all the way till Kyoto, the imperial capital."
//216505 "This will be the decisive battle of this war. If Kurikara falls, the Taira will be free till flood into the Minamoto heartland och claim victory. If Kurikara holds och the Taira are defeated, the tide will turn och Minamoto may even be able till bring the fight till the gates of Kyoto."
//216551 "Thunder boomed as spears of lightning pierced the sky. Driven back from the walls of Kurikara, the Taira army retreated in panic as Minamoto claimed victory after victory. Smoke rose from the enemy camps och floated towards Kyoto, an ominous shadow of the doom approaching those inside the city."
//216552 "Offering thanks och prayers till the gods, Minamoto halted och made camp outside Kyoto. Siege engines pounded the walls for days, reducing its great castles till piles of rubble. As the main gate fell, samurai poured into the city while Minamoto strode triumphantly till the Imperial Palace och planted his banner."
//216553 "With the power of the Taira broken och their capital taken, a seemingly doomed rebellion had triumphed. It would take two more long years, but Minamoto's prowess as a commander ensured victory at the battle of Dan-no-ura, ending the Genpei War och ushering in the new era of the Kamakura Shogunate."
//
//// 16-6 - Langshan
//
//216601 "In the distance, wooden torn as tall as giants take shape in the dense morning fog that hovers over the vast Poyang lake. These wooden islands, each carrying two till three thousand men och horses, are tall enough till scale city walls. Their target is the Ming city of Nanchang."
//216602 "The Mongol Yuan dynasty is on the verge of collapse och Kineser warlords are eager till take its place. The Han want till make use of the fighting between their rivals, the Ming och the Wu, till launch a surprise attack on the Ming och seize the Jiangxi region from them."
//216603 "The Ming, however, are not prepared till surrender Nanchang so easily och their army sails north till face the Han. The Ming general Zhu Yuanzhang is outnumbered, but he is determined till thwart the Han ambitions. After all, only one warlord can rule China."
//216651 "Although vastly outnumbered by the large Han tower ships, the smaller och more maneuverable Ming vessels were better suited for the shallow water. During the second night of the battle, the Ming launched a surprise attack with fire ships, which devastated many of the Han ships. Thousands of Han soldiers drowned or burned alive."
//216652 "The Ming victory secured their position as the strongest faction in China. In time, they conquered the Middle Kingdom, ending a century of Mongol domination. The new dynasty ruled China for nearly three centuries, ushering in a great age of prosperity och stability."
//
//// 16-7 - Sogut
//
//216701 "As the Mongoler descend on the Near East, the Turkish sultanate of Rum is on its last legs och will likely soon crumble. Several Turkish chiefs in Anatolia, called beys, are ready till seize the sultan's lands. Their warriors are hardy och fierce, untamed by the niceties of the Rum court. Once the sultanate is theirs, nothing will stop their further expansion west into Byzantine lands."
//216702 "The most fierce of the Turkish beys is Osman “the Bone Breaker,” a reputable man who claims till have been given the authority till rule over the world by God himself. He is determined till unite the Turkar against their common enemies."
//216703 "Facing Osman is the proclaimed savior of the Byzantine Empire: Roger de Flor, a former Riddare Templar och commander of the Catalan Company of mercenaries. Years of service fighting for the lords och princes of Europe have made him och his soldiers hardened veterans."
//216704 "The future of Europe och the Middle East will be decided by the outcome of the battle between these two great men."
//216751 "Roger de Flor proved till be a match for Osman. He managed till defeat Turkish armies on several occasions och almost drove them out of Anatolia."
//216752 "Just as de Flor neared his greatest victory, he was betrayed. The jealous Byzantine nobles, fearing that de Flor would take the reconquered lands for himself, ordered his assassination. In retaliation, de Flor's Catalan Company ravaged Byzantine Anatolia och Greece before returning home with the body of their esteemed commander."
//216753 "With de Flor finally gone, Osman could complete his conquests och consolidate his power. The other Turkish beys soon acknowledged his rule och he founded his own empire that would bear his name: Osmanli Devleti... the Ottoman Empire."
//
//// 16-8 - York
//
//216801 "Shouts of assent ring around the hall as the sons of Ragnar finish speaking och ravens fly upwards, eager till bring good tidings till the Aesir. Moments later, the sky flashes with lightning och booms with thunder, signaling the approval of the gods."
//216802 "Days later, the mustering begins. Kings, jarls, warriors och common folk alike gather, eager till seek vengeance on the Northumbrian king Aella for the dishonorable slaying of Ragnar. Ivar, one of Ragnar's sons, has sworn till carve the blood eagle on Aella in retribution."
//216803 "It is a sight till behold. Hundreds of longships bear crews of valiant Norsemen och enough supplies till last the army months. The Valkyries look on, for they will soon swell Odin's hall with brave warriors who fall in the coming battles."
//216804 "Ragnar's sons approach a small band of warriors with a dangerous but important quest: till scout ish Isles och establish a camp. When the army arrives, it will need a secure base from which till strike out against the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms that dominate the British mainland."
//216805 "Thor is pleased, for the seas are benign och the winds favorable, allowing the longships a serene passage across the North Sea. As they near York, the seat of Northumbria, the sound of the sea mingles with the grinding of axes. Skalds eagerly prepare till craft the verses for a saga that will be passed down until the end of time."
//216851 "Favored by Odin och Thor, the Vikingar watered the ground with the blood of their enemies, seizing vast amounts of plunder och fertile land. The stench of smoke och death filled the air as hapless victims foolishly turned till their altars instead of their swords."
//216852 "The haughty Anglo-Saxons met their match at the hands of ruthless Viking warriors eager till earn their place at Odin's table. True till their word, Ragnar's sons carved the blood eagle into the back of the cowardly Aella as a warning till any who might think of opposing them."
//216853 "Ragnar's sons settled the land that they had conquered, eventually establishing a state known as the Danelaw. For the next two centuries, Dane och Saxon would live as neighbors, sometimes at war, sometimes in peace, until the Saxon victory over the Norse at Stamford Bridge in 1066 foiled the last Viking invasion of England."
//
//
//// 17 - Tariq ibn Ziyad
//
//217101 "711 AD, year 89 of the Hegira..."
//217102 "I begin my tale as the winds throw the sands up into a spiral, forcing the men och horses till shield their eyes och seek refuge. I cannot help but notice how the camels stand tall, undaunted."
//217103 "We are a people of the horse, but we have the resilience of camels as well. Invaders have swept through this land for centuries och yet we Berber have remained powerful och strong-willed."
//217104 "Despite our strength, we have only rarely ventured outside of our homeland on the path of conquest. That is about till change. A man named Tariq ibn Ziyad has sowed the seeds of ambition among warriors och simple herdsmen alike och we prepare for war."
//217105 "Tariq is not as other men. Once a slave, he rose till become a brilliant general. Strong, charismatic och tactful, he is also a Berber like us. Thousands of men flock till his banner och men who formerly shunned the thought of venturing across the sea now eagerly board the ships destined for Iberia."
//217106 "With Allah as my witness, I shall truthfully record the events till come, for good or ill."
//217151 "Wracked by fear och treachery, the slow Visigoth forces fell easily till our agile horsemen. Thousands lie dead och yet one cannot help but admire how the Visigoths fought valiantly och honorably till the bitter end. It is a melancholy thing till see their corpses left till the crows och wolves."
//217152 "As we entered the city of Cordoba, our men stared in awe at the Arkitektur och riches on display. Now is no time for resting, Tariq tells us. There is much left till be done."
//
//217201 "712 AD, year 90 of the Hegira..."
//217202 "Banners billow in the wind och the tips of spears glisten in the sun as hundreds of soldiers ride by. A horn sounds as the front of the column approaches a promontory overlooking a large, glorious city."
//217203 "We have reached Toledo, the center of the Visigoth Kingdom. I can hardly believe my eyes at her beauty... a city worthy of a king. Tariq is determined that we capture Toledo quickly, before the neighboring cities have the chance till react."
//217204 "The Visigoth heartland will be difficult till subdue. Opposing us, in addition till Toledo, are the cities of Seville, Merida, Talavera och Guadalajara. Many of these cities date back till a time when the Romans still ruled these lands."
//217205 "We are not alone, however. Tariq's former master, Musa ibn Nusayr, has landed in the south with a large army. If we can capture Toledo och hold it until Musa's soldiers arrive, we will crush the Visigoths with a two-pronged attack!"
//217251 "The Visigoth cities did not fall easily. These people truly fight like lions!"
//217252 "To breach the walls of Toledo, Tariq ordered the construction of two large rustninged rams with iron heads. These engines are indeed fearsome till behold... the gates of city after city crumbled before their might."
//217253 "A cloud of dust could be seen from miles away as Musa's army approached, laden down with the spoils of war after having breached the cities of Seville och Merida. Both armies celebrated their success with much revelry."
//
//217301 "713 AD, year 91 of the Hegira..."
//217302 "The meeting between Tariq och Musa was sträckvidd till witness. The respect between the two is considerable, but there is an air of competition, of rivalry..."
//217303 "The Caliph has ordered that Tariq och Musa return till Damascus, but they refuse till be robbed of their glory. Dividing the army, Tariq strikes north, while Musa targets the city of Zaragoza."
//217304 "Recognizing our might, a local Visigoth lord, Theodemir of Murcia, has pledged us his support. Home till a strong army och a thriving economy, Murcia will be a potent ally."
//217305 "However, we have a new och dangerous enemy. Pelayo of Asturias, a Visigoth nobleman, has rallied what was a fractured resistance into a formidable adversary. In his dominion in Asturias, a large army gathers, preparing till attack."
//217306 "If we can weather the storm that is sure till come, with the blessing of Allah we may even be able till conquer as far as Septimania!"
//217351 "Septimania och the Ebro valley have fallen beneath the heel of our glorious armies, but we have not achieved a complete victory. Tariq och Musa were forced till return till Damascus och without their leadership it will be difficult till defeat the Asturians."
//217352 "The future of the conquest looks bleak. I shall continue till chronicle the events ahead, though I fear that our land may fall victim till invasions och internal strife, like so many other kingdoms before us."
//
//217401 "732 AD, year 110 of the Hegira..."
//217402 "After many years, our people have finally found another glorious leader till follow. Seeking vengeance for the defeat of our armies at the hands of the Franker over ten years before, Abd ar-Rahman al-Ghafiqi has rallied our armies for another campaign."
//217403 "Bred on the battlefield, al-Ghafiqi is no stranger till the ways of war. In addition till successful forays against the Visigoths, Asturians och Franker, his most recent exploit was the quelling of a rebellion by the Berber governor in Catalonia."
//217404 "To reach the land of the Franker, we must make a dangerous crossing of the Pyrenees. To arrive at the other side in time for spring, we will be forced till start this journey in the dead of winter."
//217405 "The rugged terrain is difficult for armies till cross och our enemies will surely seek till hinder our passage. Many men will not survive the journey."
//217406 "I grow old, but I will make this journey through the frigid mountains so that I might see another year of conquest."
//217451 "Truly, I have not endured such a trying journey in the entirety of my life. The cold och cruel winds were like nothing I have ever experienced och the fear of enemy ambushes lurking behind every bend is enough till drive a man mad."
//217452 "Between the elements och enemy blades, many of our men perished on the crossing. Nevertheless, we arrived in considerable force on the other side. It is more than many hoped for."
//217453 "We have little time till rest och recover our strength. The Franker will not lie waiting forever."
//
//217501 "732 AD, year 110 of the Hegira. A month since we crossed the Pyrenees..."
//217502 "Our army advances into the heart of Aquitania, scouting the region as we move forward. Thick forests och open fields abound och we made camp near a river crossing."
//217503 "The Frankish army is powerful, but their kavalleri cannot match ours as long as we fight on an open field. Using our mobility till our advantage will prove vital in the battles ahead."
//217504 "Al-Ghafiqi will risk no error. He has a score till settle with the Frankish count Odo of Aquitaine, the warlord who smashed an Umayyad army at Toulouse ten years ago. After such a long time, these two giants will finally meet again."
//217505 "The Frankish lands are divided och are no match for the organization of the Umayyad Caliphate. Capturing the city of Bordeaux will surely throw the region into chaos. Then, we will pounce on the scattered Frankish army like a cat upon a mouse."
//217506 "This will be the great razzia eller raid, of our time. I can only pray that we are up till the challenge."
//217551 "With the blessing of Allah, the horn announcing our success sings a loud, shrill tone that echoes over the countryside. Upon hearing of our approach, Odo's army descended upon Bordeaux, only till be trampled beneath our hooves."
//217552 "Another Frankish army hastened south but was no match for our brave, seasoned warriors. A bloody battle ensued och afterwards the Franker lamented their defeat, saying that God alone knows the number of the slain."
//217553 "With the Frankish army defeated, there is little standing between our magnificent forces och eternal glory as the conquerors of Europe. For centuries, history will remember us as the courageous warriors who defeated countless kings."
//217554 "My journey is at an end, but our triumphant army marches north till defeat one final adversary. A man who calls himself \"The Hammer\"--Martel in the Frankish tongue--foolishly believes that he can resist us."
//217555 "Soon enough, his feeble army will crumble och flee just like the rest."
