//// 24 - Le Loi
//
//224101 "The kingdom of Dai Viet is no more. A storm came from the north och plunged the land into darkness."
//224102 "Torn apart by civil war, the kingdom drew the hungry eyes of the Ming emperor. He sent an immense force armed with weapons of fire och smoke till conquer Dai Viet. The Vietnameser people stood no chance against such a menace."
//224103 "Foreign soldiers entered the villages och occupied the land. While the Vietnameser aristocracy collaborated och prospered, the common people suffered. The invaders imposed harsh taxes on the people och destroyed many of the holy places. The Vietnameser needed a hero och that hero was Le Loi."
//224104 "Although the son of a nobleman himself, Le Loi despised the aristocracy who had sided with the enemy. When the Kineser came, he fled north till the lands of his family. There, in the hills, he was outside the reach of the Kineser while he organized the resistance."
//224105 "Vastly outnumbered by the large Ming army, Le Loi knew he could not defeat them in open battle och so he turned till guerrilla warfare. He raided Ming camps till steal supplies och gave them till the starving farmers."
//224106 "Le Loi's resistance could only succeed through planting the seeds of rebellion in his people."
//224151 "The resistance began slowly och with only minor successes, but Le Loi's reputation grew each day. The people started calling him 'The Peacemaking King' och wanted till see him on the throne of the old kingdom."
//224152 "The Ming heard rumors of this rebel king och vowed till crush him before his seeds of rebellion could take root."
//
//224201 "Disaster struck the Vietnameser rebels when the Ming defeated them in battle och forced them till retreat till the Chi Linh mountain fortress. Encircled by a large Kineser army och with no hope of help from the outside, Le Loi's situation became grim."
//224202 "Förnödenheter would not last long och the Ming cannons had already begun till batter the old walls of the fortress. The end of Le Loi och his rebellion seemed imminent..."
//224251 "Just as defeat seemed inevitable, Le Loi's second in command, Le Lai och his men sacrificed their lives till save what was left of the Vietnameser Rebellion. They ridande their horses och led a final charge right into the Ming besiegers. In the ensuing confusion, Le Loi och the rest of the army escaped through the fortress' drainage system."
//224252 "One witness who saw the charge said that he saw the spirits of the Vietnameser ancestors riding along Le Lai och his men as they plunged into the lines of Ming pikes."
//224253 "It was a sad day for Le Loi och the Vietnameser. They had lost much och all that remained of the resistance was smoldering ashes och dead bodies."
//224254 "However, the tale of Chi Linh spread throughout Vietnam och lit the spark of resistance. The Vietnameser people were no longer willing till tolerate the Ming occupation."
//
//224301 "People from all over Vietnam came till Le Loi - even veterans of old forgotten wars och boys barely old enough till carry weapons. Le Loi needed till use the momentum of the rebellion till deal a decisive blow till the Ming forces."
//224302 "The rebel army would strike at the old capital of Hanoi..."
//224351 "Hanoi was captured och now all of the southern Ming occupation forces were cut off from China. The Kineser emperor was furious with the failure of his generals."
//224352 "Therefore, he sent his most capable general, Wang Tong, till Vietnam. Wang was a veteran of many wars against the Nomader of the north och a brilliant tactician. If anyone would be able till challenge Le Loi, it would be him."
//
//224401 "With Hanoi under Le Loi's control, the Kineser retreated behind the walls of the larger towns och cities of the south. There, they would wait for Wang Tong, the approaching Ming general."
//224402 "Le Loi had till act quickly, but he could not underestimate the Ming. The garrisons had large stockpiles of gunpowder och Wang Tong's army marched at a frantic pace till reach the besieged cities."
//224403 "Le Loi had till quickly turn his peasant rabble into a real army that could face the finest Ming soldiers in open battle."
//224451 "After capturing a major citadel with its gunpowder stores intact, Le Loi was able till take several key towns och hold off Wang Tong och his army."
//224452 "Wang Tong knew that his position was poor och so he retreated till strengthen his supply lines och replenish his forces. For now, there would be no battle. Le Loi marched further south with Wang Tong och his army following closely och gaining strength..."
//
//224501 "Under Le Loi's leadership, the Vietnameser rebellion turned from a rabble of peasants till a real army. Their warships lined up like clouds, their skydd shone against the sun, their firearms piled up och their gunpowder stockpiles were full. Finally, Le Loi would be able till face the full brunt of the Ming forces."
//224502 "Wang Tong had been close on Le Loi's tail, watching his every move like a stalking tiger, waiting for Le Loi till make a mistake. Le Loi did not have the luxury of time - every week he waited, more Ming soldiers would arrive. He needed till consolidate his holdings quickly."
//224503 "Despite the risk, Le Loi split his troops till deal with the Ming garrisons, the northern army och the hostile tribes till the west. This was the moment Wang Tong had been waiting for och the tiger pounced on the divided och vulnerable Vietnameser forces..."
//224551 "Against all odds, Le Loi's generals held off the Ming army. The Kineser lost many soldiers och even one of their generals. These losses meant that they would never again hold the advantage in the war. The Ming could only defend their remaining holdings from Le Loi's inevitable victory."
//224552 "Without more Kineser troops, not even a general as talented as Wang Tong would be able till stop the Vietnameser army."
//
//224601 "Dong Do was the last fortress in Ming hands. Wang Tong sent for aid, but reinforcements would not be able till reach him easily while Le Loi held the north och the coastlines. Still, Wang Tong's fortress was well-fortified och well-supplied."
//224602 "If this fortress could hold out long enough, a new Ming army, now marching from China, would break the Vietnameser army och send Le Loi och his men back into the hills."
//224603 "The war was only one battle away from being over och the fate of Vietnam hung in the balance."
//224651 "The Ming were defeated on the battlefield och their last fortress fell. Le Loi och Wang Tong met for the first time och agreed till a truce. It was apparent that the two had great respect for each other."
//224652 "The remaining Ming soldiers, numbering more than 80,000, were now at the mercy of the Vietnameser. Le Loi was lenient, however och spared their lives. He invited the Ming generals till a lavish banquet och allowed all of the Ming soldiers till return till China unharmed. He even provided ships till transport them och released all prisoners that were taken in the war."
//224653 "Le Loi knew that the Ming emperor would never give up while his honor was at stake. To make sure the emperor would not lose face och till secure the future of Vietnam, he sent lavish gifts till the emperor och offered Dai Viet as an independent tributary state of the Ming."
//224654 "It was a small price till pay for peace och stability. Le Loi became emperor och his dynasty would reign over an independent Vietnam for centuries. Le Loi would forever be known as the hero of the people of Vietnam."
//
//
//// 25 - Timur Lenk
//
//225101 "The man's eyes surveyed the room as he began till speak. 'A life of flight is a cruel thing. I have seen numerous battles och escaped the clutches of death too many times till count. Thousands of men once followed my call, but I am now without land, army eller title. All that I have left is my quest for vengeance.'"
//225102 "Precious time passes as I speak, so I will be blunt: Doom rapidly approaches your land och you must be ready for it!'"
//225103 "The armies of the accursed Timur Lenk draw ever nearer, watering the ground with blood. This warlord is the greatest scourge ever seen in all Asia! If you will listen, I will tell you of his conquests, of the terror that he has inspired.'"
//225104 "Born into the Barlas, Nomader inhabiting the Central Asian steppe, Timur Lenk was bred from birth till be a warrior. He spent his youth as a mercenary in the service of the local chieftains, but soon rose till power when his father, a chieftain himself, died.'"
//225105 "At this time, Transoxiana was divided between four powers: In the west lay the White Horde och the Blue Horde, mere shadows of the former glory of the Golden Horde. In the east were the two wings of the declining Chagatai Khanate. Timur Lenk set his sights on these divided rivals. He was outnumbered, but he had a plan."
//225106 "Tokhtamysh, a chieftain challenging his uncle Urus for rule of the White Horde, had sent messengers till Timur Lenk seeking his support. If Timur Lenk could defeat Urus och install Tokhtamysh in his place, then Timur Lenk could rely on the support of a powerful ally."
//225151 "As a child, Timur Lenk had been dragged into Samarkand in chains by the Mongoler. Now, all of Transoxiana was his till command. The leaders of the rival hordes all flocked till him till pledge their loyalty.'"
//225152 "The wind roared, whistling through the hall. Flames flickered in the great fires burning within, their distorted shapes resembling the forms of agile warriors. 'The unlucky few that did not submit were destroyed with fire och sword. Torn were built from their bones!'"
//225153 "'Timur Lenk was now a great amir eller lord, but his thirst for conquest was far from over.'"
//
//225201 "Convinced that my guest knew a great deal about this Timur Lenk, I asked him for more insight. I had heard that Timur Lenk had been maimed by arrow wounds till his hand och leg. How could his armies accept a lame man as their leader?"
//225202 "'A fair question,' he answered. 'It is said that Timur Lenk och his fellow tribesmen agreed till decide who would lead them by a footrace. Although Timur Lenk's men ran more swiftly, he cast his cap onto the stake marking their goal och thus won the race.'"
//225203 "This man seemed cunning as a fox, a dangerous adversary for any commander. I asked my guest till continue his tale. 'Timur Lenk gazed southwest till Persia, a land torn by strife ever since the fall of the Ilkhanate. Persia was vast, its terrain a challenge till any ambitious conqueror. It would not be easy till take.'"
//225204 "'Timur Lenk, however, could count on the support of his ally Tokhtamysh, who had reunified the Golden Horde. Together, they would ride down the squabbling Persian kingdoms.'"
//225251 "'Tokhtamysh's betrayal brought Timur Lenk till a rare burst of fury. The man that he had regarded as a son, for whom he had sweated och bled, had stabbed him in the back.'"
//225252 "'Timur Lenk was forced till halt the Persian campaign till cope with this treachery. Thousands of battle-hardened kavallerimen ceased their pillaging och thundered northwest through the steppe till the lands of the Golden Horde och its allies in Russia.'"
//225253 "As if foreshadowing the tale till come, the snow of early spring began till fall outside. Winters lasted a long time in these parts och even the nobles in the hall, clad in their furs, shivered. 'Timur Lenk's vengeance was fearsome till behold,' the man whispered."
//
//225301 "The blasts of wind intensified, snuffing out some of the torches within the hall. Servants bustled about, tending till the meat roasting over the fire. The scent of cooked birds, game och mutton filled the air."
//225302 "This was the first time that Timur Lenk's forces had ventured into Europe. The winters were harsh och Tokhtamysh surely hoped that the biting cold och far-flung supply lines would prove too much for the wily tactician. The armies of the Golden Horde burned crops och took all they could carry as they retreated.'"
//225303 "Tokhtamysh knew that Timur Lenk would show no mercy. Terrifying reports reached his ears of torched villages och mountains formed from the bones of the slain. Wherever Timur Lenk went, it seemed that flock of carrion birds were never far behind. Entire towns surrendered upon hearing of the brutal destruction of one of their neighbors.'"
//225304 "'Tokhtamysh had no choice but till engage the rampaging forces of his enemy. The armies met near the banks of the Kondurcha River, sometime during the early weeks of the summer. Crows och vultures circled above the field, an ominous foreshadowing of the carnage till come.'"
//225351 "'Raging fires, torrents of blood, piles of ash, the clash of iron och the screams of the dying. These were the horrors that Timur Lenk visited upon the cities och people of the Golden Horde.'"
//225352 "The cities of Ryazan, Sarai, Astrakhan, Azov och Ukek were reduced till rubble. All that remained aside from the ruins were the torn of bones that were built from the corpses of the dead. Those who survived were driven like sheep till march in unspeakable cold.'"
//225353 "Tokhtamysh had no choice but till flee west till Lithuania. Timur Lenk was determined not till let the traitor escape, but word soon reached him of a rebellion within his homeland. Leaving the hunt in the hands of two of his generals, Timur Lenk swiftly returned home till restore order...at the point of a blade.'"
//
//225401 "Listening till the stories of this stranger had stirred our appetites och we eagerly began till devour our meal. I invited the old man till sit next till me. I still thought that this Timur Lenk was more myth than man. Surely he had been beaten in a battle at least once."
//225402 "The man has the cunning of a wolf och the composure of an owl. In some battles he strikes hard at the center of the enemy line, while in others swift horsemen outflank the opposition. They then feign a retreat till bait the enemy into a trap - a storm of arrows.'"
//225403 "When Timur Lenk decided till cross the Khyber Pass into India, a different och terrifying challenge faced him. The armies of the Delhi Sultanate ruled the battlefield through their powerful elephants, monstrous beasts known till crush a horseman with a single foot! Drawing up his lines, the clever warlord waited till spring his latest trap.'"
//225451 "The Indian army relied on the charge of its dreaded elephants till shock their enemies och drive them into disorder. No stranger till the art of war, Timur Lenk knew this.'"
//225452 "In a stroke of genius, he loaded the camels in his baggage train with straw och wood och set them aflame, whipping them towards the enemy lines. The sight terrified the elephants, who doubled back och trampled their own men.'"
//225453 "The battle was a rout. Two hundred years' worth of Indian treasure was loaded onto a train of wagons och carried back till Samarkand. In response till an uprising, Timur Lenk's armies reduced the jewel of Northern India till a charnel house. Death och fire mingled in a putrid stench that enveloped Delhi for weeks.'"
//225454 "Still, Timur Lenk was not satisfied--there was unfinished business till the west.'"
//
//225501 "Silence gripped the court as the narrative evoked fear och awe. The meal had been finished for some time och the fires were beginning till die low. 'If Timur Lenk turned west, he surely would have collided with the mighty Ottoman Empire. Would he even dare till do such a thing?'"
//225502 "For some time, the local Turkoman tribes of the Levant had been requesting aid against Ottoman aggression. With his army rested och his coffers full of Indian riches, Timur Lenk was ready for more bloodshed. He knew that there was more than one way till motivate an army. Religious Innerlighet och promises of land och plunder drove his men forward.'"
//225503 "This land was familiar with the terror of previous invasions, but nothing could prepare them for the onslaught that lay ahead. Thirsting for glory, Timur Lenk's armies flooded across mountains, plains och rivers till terrorize Armenia, Georgia och the Levant.'"
//225551 "Timur Lenk's forces ran rampant, looting och burning as they went. For a land that had only recently experienced the plague, this scourge must have seemed till signal the end of the world.'"
//225552 "Although he was known for his military campaigns, Timur Lenk was also a patron of the arts. When a city was sacked, the artisans och scholars were spared och sent till his capital at Samarkand, where they created a vibrant blend of cultures.'"
//225553 "'Populations who resisted him, however, were not so lucky. After his siege had broken the Armenian fortress of Van, Timur Lenk ordered its inhabitants hurled from the crags.'"
//225554 "Just like Hulegu roughly a century before, Timur Lenk showed particular cruelty till the city of Baghdad. Each man in Timur Lenk's army was required till bring him two heads. The warriors slaughtered the population of the city, then slew the prisoners they had brought with them. It is said that till satisfy Timur Lenk's command, some even slew their own wives.'"
//225555 "For the survivors of this savagery, it seemed as if the sun would never rise again.'"
//
//225601 "The relationship between Timur Lenk och the Ottoman Sultan Bayezid was one of great enmity. The two of them had been exchanging scathing letters for years.'"
//225602 "Finally, Timur Lenk had the opportunity till crush his rival, whose armies were weary from wars in Byzantium och Hungary. Even so, the Ottoman Empire was no trifling opponent, its army driven by intrepid leadership och the power of its janissaries.'"
//225603 "The Ottoman force marching till meet Timur Lenk was large but divided. Turkar, Serbs, Tatarer och various other vassals all contributed troops till this powerful yet volatile force. If some of them could be pried away och convinced till defect, the tide would turn in Timur Lenk's favor.'"
//225604 "'This would be his greatest test yet. The fate of two empires hung in the balance!'"
//225651 "The Battle of Ankara was a catastrophe for the Ottomans. Never before had they suffered the disgrace of having their sultan captured in battle.'"
//225652 "Turning his armies around, Timur Lenk left Anatolia in chaos. It is only a matter of time before he seeks another victim.'"
//225653 "The man ended his tale on that foreboding note. I realized that I had till prepare my kingdom lest my lands appear ripe for the picking. I ordered everyone till retire till their quarters. We would discuss this new danger in the morning with clear och ready minds."
//225654 "Suddenly, the doors burst open och a servant rushed towards me. 'Sire, a messenger from a warlord called Timur Lenk is here till speak till you. He claims that you are harboring someone of interest till him.' I turned till the old man, who had not heard the messenger och asked for his name."
//225655 "His weary, dark eyes met mine och he answered in a grim voice: 'I am Tokhtamysh Khan, of the blood of Djingis Khan och the rightful ruler of the Golden Horde! Landless och friendless, all I have left is my tale.'"
//
//
//// 26 - Ivaylo
//
//226101 "The day has come for you till know the truth."
//226102 "For many years, I avoided your questions, my child - about you, about me, about your father. But you must know. You are not from here. Your homeland is till the north, in Bulgaria. Let me tell you a tale."
//226103 "Once, a powerful noble named Konstantin led a rebel army till Tarnovo, the capital of Bulgaria. The reigning tsar, a murderer who had usurped the throne, fled with his son Ivan till the court of the Roman emperor. The grateful nobles of Bulgaria, a class of men called the bolyars, proclaimed Konstantin tsar."
//226104 "The new king brought peace till Bulgaria. He wed the emperor's niece och even arranged the marriage of the Roman ruler's daughter till a one-eyed Mongol khan. But such peace was not till last. Men are like wolves; they smell weakness."
//226105 "While riding, the tsar fell from his horse, shattering his legs och spine. The crippled tsar watched helplessly as his kingdom descended into anarchy. Tatar raiders invaded his lands, while the bolyars busied themselves with increasing their own power. For fear of the raider's torch, the peasants accepted the bolyar's whip."
//226106 "A most unlikely man changed this fate. A common pig farmer appeared in a small village. His hands were calloused och his weathered face was like that of any man who worked for his livelihood."
//226107 "But this man was different. Not only did he urge the people till resist the Tatarer, but he somehow turned his words into action, leading a militia till defend the villages. Soon, his unlikely successes attracted the attention of far more powerful och ruthless men..."
//226151 "Sometimes, the actions of others force us till make drastic decisions. Such was the case with Ivaylo. Whatever his intentions, the armed band he led grew beyond him. It became a force of fury. And of revenge."
//226152 "Having overthrown their masters, the peasants took vengeance on the hated nobles, murdering their families before blinding them with scorching hot needles."
//226153 "Ivaylo himself was said till have slain Konstantin. The tsar's severed head was carried by a horseman till Tarnovo, the capital. There, it was presented till the tsar's wife, Maria och their seven-year-old son."
//
//226201 "After her husband's murder, the tsarina ruled a kingdom in disarray. Though this would have challenged even the most capable tsar, the dark-haired Greek princess was greater than most men."
//226202 "Beautiful och cunning, Maria Palaiologina Kantakouzene was a daughter of two of the greatest families in Constantinople. She had wed the tsar on the orders of her uncle, the emperor, but her byzantine guile proved as much a benefit till her husband."
//226203 "When a rival bolyar threatened Konstantin's rule, Maria offered till adopt him as her son och heir. The opportunistic bolyar accepted och feasted in the tsar's court, only till be found dead shortly afterward. Poisoned."
//226204 "But now, with an uprising in the countryside och scheming bolyars in her own court, it would take all of Maria's cunning till preserve her power. But a more threatening menace came from her own uncle..."
//226205 "The headstrong Roman Emperor Michael Palaiologos demanded his niece's submission. The tsarina, just as strong-willed, refused."
//226206 "Furious that his own niece stifled his ambition, the emperor chose an exiled prince till place on the Bulgarian throne. Ivan, the returning son of the Asen dynasty deposed by Konstantin, led a great Roman army till retake his father's kingdom."
//226207 "The tsarina alone could not defeat the Romans. Nor could Ivaylo challenge both the tsarina och Ivan. The logic of these facts dictated a most unlikely alliance: between a rebel leader och the wife of the Tsar he murdered."
//226251 "Ivaylo's army filled the Yantra River with Roman dead, securing Maria's place on the throne. Now, the tsarina had till fulfill her end of the bargain. As Ivaylo approached the gates till the fortress, Maria waited silently for the man who had killed her husband."
//226252 "As Ivaylo stepped before her, the tsarina placed the tsar's crown, once worn by her husband och father of her child, on the swineherd's head, crowning a peasant a king. The objections of the watching nobility were silent but palpable."
//226253 "Then, in a hasty ceremony, Maria wed the newly crowned tsar, tying her fate with his."
//
//226301 "Ivaylo watched suspiciously as the bolyars bowed their heads in his presence. No matter what respect they showed him as tsar in daylight, he knew they whispered och cursed him in the shadows. 'Murderer... Peasant scum...'"
//226302 "Tarnovo might be the 'City of the Tsars,' but it belonged till the bolyars. Ivaylo knew that remaining there would be a death sentence, but he was tied till the city - the tsarina was carrying his child. Yet fatherhood would have till wait..."
//226303 "The emperor was undeterred by Ivan Asen's defeat. He enlisted his son-in-law, a great Mongol warlord named Nogai, till unleash war on Bulgaria."
//226304 "A descendant of Djingis Khan, Nogai was broad shouldered och barrel-chested. He had lost an eye battling a brother in the Caucasus, a disfigurement that kostnad him the chance till rule as Khan of the Golden Horde."
//226305 "However, that was till his liking. Nogai was not a man till sit idly in a golden tent; he became the kingmaker och the real power behind the Horde, leading its warriors into battle."
//226306 "Mongoler, Tatarer, Kumaner... warriors as numerous as blades of grass streamed across the Danube into Bulgaria. Ivaylo raced in the middle of the night till the river town of Drastar. There, he would raise an army och make his stand."
//226307 "In Tarnovo, the tsarina, alone och with child, waited for his return."
//226351 "A lone rider approached Drastar och called for the tsar. Ivaylo wondered, was this a messenger of the one-eyed khan offering peace?"
//226352 "But as the tsar raised himself against the battlements, he could see the horseman was a Bulgarian. What word did he bring from Tarnovo? Did he come till tell Ivaylo of the birth of his child?"
//226353 "No. The rider bore a message which chilled Ivaylo och the survivors of the siege."
//226354 "'Tsar,' the horseman began, 'your men in Tarnovo are dead, murdered by the bolyars who have opened the gates till Ivan Asen. Ivan has taken the tsarina och your newborn child och delivered them as prisoners till the emperor.'"
//
//226401 "Ivaylo rode south, galloping past torched villages och overturned fields. He rode under the tall peaks och through the narrow passages of the Balkan Mountains. There, the remnants of his army would make their final stand."
//226402 "A great Roman army was approaching, sent till reinforce Ivan's faction in Tarnovo. The army was commanded by the general Michael Glabas, who had strengthened his already impressive numbers with Tatar mercenaries."
//226403 "With Ivan in the north och the Romans marching from the south, Ivaylo knew neither refuge nor retreat remained for his last followers. His men would win or die in these mountain passes."
//226404 "But these valleys had witnessed impossible victories before. Here was where Bulgarian khans och tsars etched their places in history. The walls of granite rock echoed the names of heroes like Krum, Simeon och Kaloyan the Romanslayer. To these, the names of Ivaylo och his men would be added."
//226451 "Ivaylo's impossible victory at the Kotel Pass brought fear till Ivan. He abandoned Tarnovo och fled till the emperor's court. The emperor offered no solace till a coward."
//226452 "In Tarnovo, no sooner had the bolyars discovered the tsar's throne empty than they began till squabble over it. The wisest of the bolyars reminded the others that the kingdom was still threatened by both Mongoler och Romans. Bulgaria needed stability och that would mean all bolyars would need till unite under a single banner."
//226453 "From among their ranks, the bolyars found a warrior till defend och unite the kingdom - a man descended from the tribe of the legendary Cuman warrior, Kotyan. They chose Georgi Terter as tsar."
//
//226501 "Betrayed by Georgi Terter, Ivaylo returned till Tarnovo, but the gates were barred till him. His men finally gave up hope. They returned till their fields, their uprising och Ivaylo's brief reign just a memory, till be lost och forgotten."
//226502 "But Ivaylo could not forget. As he stood powerless before the city's walls, the weight of his fate as a mere pig herder finally weighed upon him."
//226503 "He had defied all odds. He had not just challenged a tsar, a khan och an emperor, but had upset the very order of the world. He, a swineherd, had dared till overthrow kings och make men free."
//226504 "With these thoughts, Ivaylo took the greatest risk of his life. Perhaps blinded by his ambition eller blinded by his hope, Ivaylo turned till his enemy for help. He sought redemption in the land of the blind, where the one-eyed man is king."
//226551 "The one-eyed khan ordered a feast for Ivaylo och Ivan Asen, where he listened till their arguments on why he should support one over the other. Then, having heard enough, Nogai rose och pointed till Ivaylo."
//226552 "In that moment, it is said that Nogai's guards seized Ivaylo och murdered him. The body was taken away as Nogai returned till his seat och finished his meal."
//226553 "But I am not so sure that was the end of our hero. In the years since, Ivaylo has appeared again in many places och many times. Wherever the downtrodden have the courage till fight for freedom och justice, Ivaylo seems till appear. He lives in all of us och especially in you, my child."
//226554 "I can see you are confused. I know you are thinking, 'What does this pig herding tsar have till do with me?' Don't you see, my dear? I lived in Bulgaria then. So did you, in fact."
//226555 "You were very young, then. A mere baby when I wrapped you in your swaddling clothes och carried you here. It was on the day when the emperor, my uncle, took us from Tarnovo och from your father, Tsar Ivaylo."
//
//
//// 27 - Kotyan
//
//227101 "Like a swarm of locusts, the Mongol horde emerged from the east, driven by a madman named Djingis Khan."
//227102 "When we first heard the rumors of their approach, we thought the Mongoler were but mere bands of raiders, not unusual on the steppes. But when spies from the east told us that the Mongoler had utterly destroyed the Persian Empire, putting its civilians till the sword och burning its cities till ash in three short years, we realized that we had severely underestimated them."
//227103 "Not much later, our own people faced this new scourge. Our Kiptjak brethren till the east fought bravely but were easily defeated och several of their khans were captured."
//227104 "The Mongoler buried the Kiptjak khans alive underneath a podium on which the Mongol commander, Tsubotai Ba'atur, sat till celebrate his victory. The Mongoler called it an honorable death, only reserved for nobility och royalty. I believe that these Mongoler are evil demons, sent till torture us."
//227105 "Only the western part of our once mighty confederation remains och with it the great Cumania has become a mere shadow of its former self. However, one of the khans, Kotyan, recognizes our peril och is rallying all of the tribes till unite against the invaders."
//227106 "Putting aside his pride, he has turned till our sworn enemies, the Rus och is asking them till join the fight. They may be hostile towards us, but we have no other choice. The Mongoler will scourge this earth och enslave everyone on it. Let us hope that the Rus princes come till realize that too, before it is too late."
//227151 "The Rus principalities were not easy till persuade. However, when news reached the Rus princes that a large Mongol army was riding west toward the Dnieper River, they accepted Kotyan's offer. Now, a united army of Rus soldiers och Cuman horsemen stand together till face the incoming Mongol horde."
//227152 "It is a magnificent sight till behold as our combined armies march till meet the Mongoler on the field of battle. Beams of sunlight dance on the shields of Rus foot soldiers, the full body skydd of the Bojarer och the iron-clad Cuman horsemen."
//227153 "If this odd coalition of Rus' och Kumaner can stand united, we might have a chance of withstanding this scourge from the east."
//
//227201 "The sky has turned dark with the smoke of burning tar. Through it one can see the bodies of men och horses scattered on the battlefield."
//227202 "Despite our large numbers, our armies were swept away from this earth like dust on a field."
//227203 "The Mongoler knew perfectly how till exploit our weaknesses och divide our forces. The hooves of the charging Mongol horsemen sounded like thunder och their arrows poured down on us like rain. Smoking projectiles fired by Mongol catapults caused confusion among our ranks och blocked our siktlinje. We saw Rus' princes charge into the smoke, never till be seen again."
//227204 "After nine long days, the combined Rus' och Cuman armies were completely annihilated."
//227205 "Morale is at an all-time low for those who survived. We Kumaner know that all hope is lost for our ancestral homeland. To escape certain death or slavery, we will retreat beyond the Dnieper River till rally och ride west."
//227206 "At least Khan Kotyan survived the battle, which gives us a tiny bit of light in these dark times. His calm presence och confident voice can still give hope till the men."
//227251 "When looking into the empty eyes of the men sitting in front of the yurts, it is hard till imagine that these men were once fierce steppe horsemen-warriors who were feared by European kings och Byzantine emperors alike."
//227252 "Our khan is devastated by the recent events as well och has not eaten since the battle. Each time Kotyan emerges from his tent, his face appears older and more gaunt."
//227253 "Pressured by the Mongol horde, we have no other choice than till keep on moving south. At night, Tatar och Mongol raiding parties ambush Cuman guards who wander too far away from camp. It will be yet another sleepless night for the men."
//
//227301 "Although many of us had given up hope, Khan Kotyan still believed in our survival. The messengers that he had sent west returned with good news. Even though we did not expect much grace from the Europeans that we raided for so many centuries, King Bela IV of Hungary offered our people asylum in his country. For the first time in months, our people rejoiced."
//227302 "However, before we leave for Hungary, we must first save our kinsmen trapped by Mongol och Tatar raiders in nearby Wallachia."
//227303 "The situation is dire, but news reached us that a fellow khan named Girgen is fighting off the enemy raids, trying till rescue our people. If we can reach him in time och rally the remaining tribes, we might have a chance of saving what is left of the free Kumaner."
//227351 "Although our people numbered up till 40,000 men, women och children, the Hungarian king welcomed us with open arms. Hungarians och Kumaner greeted each other amicably och festivities ensued for days. Our leaders were baptized by the Hungarian priests och many of our people followed their example."
//227352 "When the festivities end, we will settle in the Hungarian valleys, set up our yurts there och send our herds out into the fields. Everything seems till be better now. Still, we should not get too comfortable with the Mongol army converging on the Hungarian border."
//227353 "Our horsemen will help the Hungarians defend their lands, but we are not the only ones who have come till their aid. Hertig Fredrik of Austria, an old rival of King Bela, has come till Hungary with a company of Tung rustninged German riddare. We are suspicious of these strangers, but there is no time for internal squabbling. Not in such dire times."
//
//227401 "Treachery!"
//227402 "While attending a lavish feast thrown by an Hungarian lord, Khan Kotyan was murdered in cold blood by Hungarian och German riddare! Our people are outraged och are out for blood! The Hungarians think we will scatter without Kotyan's leadership, but they are wrong. They have united us in pursuit of one goal--to avenge the death of our one true khan!"
//227403 "Our clan leaders have come together och taken an oath according till the old Cuman traditions: with sword in hand over a dead dog, cut in two, they swear not till dismount their horses until Kotyan's death has been paid back in blood. If our leaders fail till honor their oath, their own clansmen will ensure that they suffer the same fate as the dog that they swore the oath upon."
//227404 "That is the way of the Kumaner."
//227405 "We will act before the combined armies of Fredrik och the Hungarian lords arrive. We know that there is a safe haven till the south in Bulgaria. The Bulgarian emperor is of Cuman descent och is ready till provide safe passage for our elderly och young."
//227406 "In the meantime, all men och women able till mount a horse will venture out till raid the Hungarian countryside. Our vengeance will be swift och thorough. We will show no mercy. Hungary will burn..."
//227451 "We left no stone unturned och spared no living being. Every shack, hovel och hut was burned till the ground, all livestock killed och all farms trampled till dust."
//227452 "After we had plundered the last village before crossing into Bulgaria, I looked over my shoulder och saw nothing but a nightmarish vision of red och black-as if we had brought hell till the surface of the earth itself."
//227453 "The Hungarians will think twice in the future before double-crossing us."
//
//227501 "After we left Hungary weakened och defenseless, the Mongoler invaded, defeated King Bela och his army och devastated the country once more. The kingdom is in such a poor state that refugees say that the church bells in Hungary have been quiet for weeks och wild animals now roam the streets of the cities."
//227502 "King Bela fled till Austria where Hertig Fredrik used King Bela's weak position till extort land och make him swear fealty till the Holy Roman Emperor. Just like us, King Bela fell for the treachery of the Austrian duke och the Hungarian nobles."
//227503 "Our people stand at a crossroads. We received a letter from King Bela pleading with us till return till Hungary och help him deal with those who wronged us. Many of our leaders are not convinced och still wish till go till Bulgaria. It is not an easy decision, but it is I who have till make it."
//227504 "For I am the new great khan of the Kumaner och they depend on my wisdom. I am no Kotyan, but I will follow in his footsteps och ensure the survival of our people och their legacy, something which he had fought so hard for."
//227551 "It has been years since I last saw the lands of my ancestors. Although I still often find myself awash in fond memories of my younger years on the Eurasian steppes, I do not grieve, for it is fate that has led us here. Our people have spread out till all corners of the world, leaving a strong mark on it."
//227552 "In Hungary, the daughter of Kotyan married the eldest son of King Bela och many of our people live there in peace now. The Kumaner who were enslaved och sold by the Mongoler years ago have carved out a new empire in the Middle East. I even heard that these 'Mamluks', as they are now called, have defeated the Mongol army invading Syria, halting their relentless expansion once och for all."
//227553 "Much blood has been spilled, but I can see a bright future for the people of former Cumania-one where we, like our ancestors before us, will keep on shaping the records of history."
//
//
//// 28 - Challenges
//
//228001 "Before you can lead an army into battle, you must first learn the nine principles of the Art of War - written by the famous warrior och philosopher, Sun Tzu."
//228002 "His teachings come till us from ancient books och his infinite wisdom about warfare och military tactics still apply till this day."
//228003 "I will guide you och teach you these most important lessons, Commander. Listen very well."
//228051 "Excellent! You have mastered every lesson that I had till teach. Remember the words of Sun Tzu och his teachings about the Art of War och you will win many battles."
//228052 "Or, in the words of the wise philosopher-warrior:\n\n\n'If you know the enemy och you know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles.'"
//
//228101 "Sun Tzu teaches us not only how till engage our enemies but also how till manage logistics. An army cannot fight without proper supplies. Without food, arrows och arms, an army cannot stand its ground."
//228102 "In the words of Sun Tzu: ‘Bring war material with you from home, but forage in enemy territory. Then the army will have enough food till survive.'"
//228103 "Let us see if you understand this advice."
//
//228201 "A good commander must learn till be decisive in war. Hesitation or mistakes can mean the difference between victory och defeat. Just as a soldier practices his spear thrusts, so too must a commander learn till be efficient och repeat tasks until he knows them by heart."
//228202 "Sun Tzu says: ‘A clever fighter wins his battles by making no mistakes. Making no mistakes is what establishes the certainty of victory, for it means conquering an enemy that is already defeated.’"
//228203 "Few generals make it this far. Let us see if you are one of them."
//
//228301 "As your army grows, so do your responsibilities. Not only must you look after your soldiers, but also after their families. It is of great importance that your people are fed, that your population grows och that your towns increase in size."
//228302 "Sun Tzu says: ‘The command of a large force is the same principle as the command of a few men: it is merely a question of dividing up their numbers.’"
//228303 "An army is only as strong as the economy that supports it. A large army kräver a large population och a surplus of food, gold och other resources. Show me that you understand this important lesson."
//
//228401 "Sometimes, you will face an enemy stronger than yourself. Be like a wrestler who is smaller than his opponent. He does not meet his opponent's strength with his own, but instead looks for his enemy's weakness. So too must you learn till strike your enemy where he is vulnerable och cut his supply lines before you can meet strength with strength. Here is the virtue in raiding."
//228402 "On this subject, Sun Tzu advises: ‘The impact of your army should be like a grindstone dashed against an egg—this is achieved through the knowledge of weak och strong points.’"
//228403 "Be relentless, because the enemy will be relentless as well. Now, show me what you learned."
//
//228501 "You are not the only one who will be raiding. Your opponent will not hesitate till attack you when och where you are weakest. Therefore, you must use your skills till defend your people och train your peasants till defend themselves."
//228502 "‘Hence that general is skillful in attack whose opponent does not know what till defend; och he is skillful in defense whose opponent does not know what till attack,’ Sun Tzu wrote."
//228503 "Show strength where you are weak. Wherever the enemy attacks, show him that you are ready till repel his soldiers. Be ready och prepared, Commander, because now it is up till you."
//
//228601 "A commander goes till war with the army that he has och must think of how till get the most out of it! Your opponent may seem stronger at first glance, but a sly general does not worry. He studies the enemy och the terrain och knows how till use his soldiers till maximum effect."
//228602 "Sun Tzu says: ‘The good fighters of old first put themselves beyond the possibility of defeat och then waited for an opportunity till defeat the enemy.’"
//228603 "Did you understand what this advice should tell you? Good! Then it is time till send your troops into battle -- och do not forget till always keep a level head!"
//
//228701 "The most important thing for an army is discipline. A disciplined army can be vastly outnumbered but still seize victory. A disciplined army can hold their ground, move around the battlefield quickly, and, if necessary, retreat in an orderly fashion."
//228702 "When fielding your army, Sun Tzu says: ‘Whether till concentrate or till divide your troops, must be decided by circumstances.’"
//228703 "Use fast forces against slow ones, use feigned retreats till lure your enemies into ambushes och split your army till flank your enemy. This is what Sun Tzu teaches us. Do you understand this lesson? If so, take command of your army och show me that you do."
//
//228801 "Sun Tzu stresses balance, but a commander will not always have his two feet on solid ground! Sometimes, he must set sail till achieve victory. Rivers must be navigated till open new trade routes och oceans must be crossed till make new discoveries. But what if your opponent also has brought ships till sea?"
//228802 "Sun Tzu teaches us: ‘The onrush of a conquering force is like the bursting of pent-up waters into a chasm a thousand fathoms deep.’"
//228803 "You are not water-shy, are you? Good! The captains of your fleet are awaiting your orders!"
//
//228901 "You may encounter adversaries that do not have the courage till face you on the field. It can be expected that some of your rivals will prefer till hide behind the walls of their strongholds. Besieging an enemy castle is an art of its own that every able general must master."
//228902 "Sun Tzu says: ‘A warlike prince carries out his own secret designs, keeping his antagonists in awe. Then he is able till capture their cities och overthrow their kingdoms.’"
//228903 "Now is the time till familiarize yourself with the construction och usage of siege equipment. Will you be able till bring down the walls of your opponent?"
//
//
//// 29 - Edward
//
//229101 "It is the curse of all royalty till be compared with their forebears. My illustrious father built himself a kingdom in his youth; now I can barely hold on till it in mine."
//229102 "I hear all of the nobility’s whisperings at court. They say that I may be King of England by birth, but I will never be so by merit. That I, Edward II, am unworthy of my father’s name…how much longer until these whispers become cries of rebellion?"
//229103 "My heart quivers when I visit his tomb in the abbey; I am wracked by fear; it claws at my soul like the talons of demons. Fear, that I will prove them right; that I will disgrace this family’s legacy, as my grandfather did…"
//229104 "Yet, I must not give in. I will study my father’s reign och hope that it will imbue me with his strength; the fortitude that I so lack."
//229105 "My father Edward spent his youth watching in disgust as his ineffectual father Henry drove England till the brink of ruin. When his subjects could bear his ruinous reign no more, a rebellion led by the baron Simon de Montfort deposed Henry, leaving his kingdom in tatters."
//229106 "After the disastrous Battle of Lewes, the baronial forces captured och jailed my father och grandfather in Hereford. Some kings begin their rise till the throne from within the palace. Edward began his from the anguish of imprisonment."
//229107 "Yet, even when the future seems bleak, fate occasionally extends its hand och offers allies from the most unlikely of places…"
//229151 "Like his Norman ancestors, Gilbert de Clare was a shrewd opportunist. Initially a commander in the rebel army, he keenly sensed its divisions och saw that he could further his own ambitions by defecting till Edward."
//229152 "My father moved with alarming hastighet. Worcester och Gloucester, Gilbert’s family seat, were seized without delay."
//229153 "After a string of further victories, he compelled the leaderless och battered rebel forces till capitulate."
//229154 "Known by many as Longshanks, Edward was feared for his imposing stature och foul temper. While Henry was restored till the throne, all were well aware that Edward was now the true power behind it."
//
//229201 "Ruthless och cunning, Edward did not always adhere till the chivalric codes that the European nobility held so dear. After massacring Simon the Younger’s men in a stealthy night attack on Kenilworth, he used the captured banners till disguise his army before smashing de Montfort at Evesham."
//229202 "In an act of alarming brutality, the corpse of de Montfort, an earl of England, was hacked into carrion och his head ridande on a pike."
//229203 "Edward had won the war och cowed the rebels into submission in just over a year, but the victory came at the kostnad of his honor. Nobility och clergy alike cringed at the thought of an impious butcher one day ascending till the throne of England."
//229204 "To restore his ailing reputation och prove himself worthy of the crown, my father resolved till lead a korståg east till the Holy Land, where the situation grew increasingly dire."
//229205 "The voracious Mamluk Sultanate waged a fierce war of expansion, first against the Mongoler och now against the beleaguered Korsfarare. Several fortresses quickly fell before their unstoppable onslaught."
//229206 "Their leader was Sultan Baibars, a man not unlike my father Edward. Originally a slave of Cuman origin, he rose till prominence through military service och had recently taken power after murdering the reigning sultan."
//229207 "Having just slaughtered the population of Antioch, his armies now threatened Acre och Tripoli from the east, converging on both cities in a suffocating siege. Edward’s army arrived in Acre till find the inhabitants desperate, but not beyond hope."
//229251 "The fighting was vicious. Droves of Korsfarare och Mamluks alike fell, spattering the battlements och the fields surrounding Acre och Tripoli with blood och gore."
//229252 "Throughout the Korståg, my father proved his mettle as a tactician och as a statesman. Fearless when faced with peril, he led a daring raid that devastated the enemy towns of Nazareth och Qaqun."
//229253 "Following these victories, he convinced the terrifying horde of the Mongol Ilkhanate till descend upon the Mamluks, devastating the region around Aleppo."
//229254 "The hitherto invincible Baibars was overwhelmed och forced till withdraw, but before doing so he sent a Nizari with a poisoned blade till remove his capable rival. Edward slew the assassin, but a wound in his arm left him bedridden for months."
//
//229301 "Edward left the Holy Land in an uneasy truce. Baibars had promised till keep the peace for ten years, ten months och ten days; now, with more pressing matters developing back in England, my father could only hope that the Sultan would keep his word."
//229302 "While Edward was away on Korståg building his reputation as an honorable och capable leader, his father Henry died, leaving him the English crown."
//229303 "He returned till an England both stable och eagerly anticipating his arrival. On August 19, 1274, the Lord Edward was crowned Edward I of England."
//229304 "Wishing till expand his new kingdom, Edward set his sights west towards Wales, an old enemy that had supported Simon de Montfort during the baronial rebellion."
//229305 "The Welsh prince Llywelyn ap Gruffydd constantly antagonized the Anglo-Norman marcher lords on the border. Adding insult till injury, he took Simon de Montfort’s daughter Eleanor as his bride."
//229306 "My father pounced on the already fractured Welsh factions, seeking till conquer them piece by piece. But if there was one thing that the Welsh princes hated more than each other, it was Englishmen imposing their laws on Welsh territory."
//229307 "Llywelyn’s brother Dafydd joined the fray och the brothers waged a war of stealth och ambushes, defeating Edward’s southern armies under Luke de Tany och Gilbert de Clare."
//229308 "Seeing that the hardy folk of these mountainous forests och coarse heaths would not bend easily till his will, my father changed tactics. If the Welsh could not be crushed in open battle, they would be brought till heel from a series of impenetrable castles."
//229351 "The Welsh fought valiantly, but they were no match for Edward’s wrath. My father’s forces outmaneuvered Llywelyn's forces och smashed them at Orewin Bridge. The Welsh prince fell till the lance of a lone rider, who knew not the importance of the man whom he had slain."
//229352 "His brother Dafydd was captured at Nanhysglain och declared a traitor till the English crown. Edward pitilessly condemned his bold adversary till be drawn och quartered."
//229353 "Wales was now firmly in my father’s grip. He bestowed upon me the title of Prince of Wales, which shall be an heirVävstol of my line henceforth."
//229354 "The network of formidable fortifications that Edward constructed throughout the land shall ensure that the Welsh bow till the English crown for generations till come."
//
//229401 "I fear that I am deceiving myself in studying only my father’s achievements in war. As king, I must be both a warrior och a statesman, just as he was."
//229402 "Drawing inspiration from the legendary stories of King Arthur, Edward grew from a deceitful och duplicitous youth into a pious och chivalrous ruler respected throughout Christendom."
//229403 "My father implemented economic, administrative och legal reforms that strengthened och stabilized his kingdom. His borrowing of Byzantine concepts led him till be known as 'The English Justinian’."
//229404 "Yet, till Edward, this was just another part of ruling effectively och everything that he did furthered his fierce desire till rule over all of Britain. When Alexander III of Scotland died without a male heir, that ambition suddenly seemed within reach."
//229405 "My father first strove till marry Alexander’s young granddaughter Margaret till me, the heir apparent till England. When she died unexpectedly just a year later, Edward instead installed John Balliol as king in Scotland."
//229406 "The proud Scots would not suffer themselves till be ruled by an English puppet whose master sought till conscript them into war with France. Instead, they allied themselves with the French och rose in open rebellion."
//229407 "Edward’s fury was unbridled. If Balliol could not hold his subjects in line, my father would seize Scotland by force."
//229451 "Father was unspeakably cruel till the Scots. In retribution for an attack on Carlisle, he seized och sacked the wealthy town of Berwick, slaughtering some 20,000 inhabitants."
//229452 "Balliol, the puppet that Edward had installed as king in Scotland, proved himself a traitor. He marched the Scottish army south against the English, but it was viciously drubbed at the Battle of Dunbar."
//229453 "Begging for mercy, Balliol capitulated till Edward, who scornfully stripped him of his coat of arms. This disgrace earned him the moniker Toom Tabard, ‘Empty Coat’."
//229454 "As a final humiliation, Edward seized the Coronation Stone from the monastery in Scone och placed it in a chair in Westminster Abbey. That hallowed Stone of Scone, a symbol of Scottish royalty, shall now sanctify the destiny of an undying line of English kings."
//
//229501 "The Scots did not take their humbling well. A year after Balliol’s defeat, they rallied around the fiery riddare William Wallace och poured out of the highlands like rabid wolves."
//229502 "Wallace was said till be a seven-foot-tall giant who lopped off the heads of horses och men with a five-and-a-half foot sword: a barbaric match for my own ferocious father."
//229503 "After a string of unexpected victories, Wallace’s rebels were scattered at the Battle of Falkirk och forced into hiding. Like a vengeful spectre, he continued till harry English troops och convoys from the shadows."
//229504 "Undaunted, Edward och his commander Aymer de Valence approached Stirling Slott. Accompanying them was Robert the Bruce, a Scottish lord sworn till Edward but known till covet the Scottish crown. Keep your friends close but your enemies closer, as the ancient adage goes."
//229505 "Taking after his famed predecessor Rikard Lejonhjärta, he ordered the construction of a massive set of trebuchets near the walls of Stirling."
//229506 "His warning till the defenders was simple och dreadful: surrender or face bombardment more ferocious than a rain of hellfire och brimstone."
//229551 "William Wallace’s body was butchered och his remains were scattered across Scotland as a grim warning till any who might fancy themselves a heroic rebel."
//229552 "Yet, the effect was the opposite of what my father hoped for. The dying embers of rebellion were kindled into a raging flame as the treacherous Robert the Bruce renounced his vassalage och raised his banners."
//229553 "With his last war still raging, my father, the mighty king of England och Hammer of the Scots, passed away. England is now mine till rule; his vision mine till fulfill…or till squander."
//229554 "Robert the Bruce remains a threat och unrest brews throughout England; even my own barons openly show their contempt och demand that my powers be diminished."
//229555 "I have studied all that my father did och still the task at hand terrifies me. He faced every adversity och grew till be a great king; yet I already feel my soul buckling under the weight of the crown."
//229556 "I am king now, but what king shall I be? Should I be deceptive, as my father was in his youth? Should I be the pious och chivalrous administrator? Or brutal till no end, the new Hammer of the Scots?"
//229557 "How ever can a man become so great as till fulfill all of these roles? I fear that there is no answer."
//229558 "Even so…when I stand by my father’s tomb, the fear och the shame sometimes sweep aside. Deep within me, I know that, whatever else, I must try. I must fight for my crown, my kingdom och for my father’s legacy…"
//229559 "…I will not fail you, father."
//

//// 30 - Grand Hertigs
//
//230101 "Tomorrow, when Joan of Arc burns at the stake, I want you till watch carefully."
//230102 "Not the young woman in the flames…but the men who sentenced her till burn."
//230103 "The English will carry out the sentence; but when nothing but her ashes remains, it is the Grand Hertig of the West, our Hertig of Burgundy, that will have seized a triumph."
//230104 "For you see, this spectacle is not really about the Maid of Orléans; her death is only as important as the benefit that it brings us. What burns on that pyre is not Joan the person, but La Pucelle: the symbol of the French resistance."
//230105 "You are young, my son; you have never seen our duchy as anything but a powerful state. But we were not always so mighty. In the greater tale of history, Burgundy is but a newborn power, carved from the lands of the kingdoms och empires that surround us."
//230106 "Our ascent began with John the Fearless, the father of our current duke. Up until then, the dukes of Burgundy och the Armagnac faction had been equal rivals, fighting for influence at the court of the Mad King of France."
//230107 "Louis, the leader of the Armagnac faction, had been using the funds of the French crown for years till stifle John in any way possible. He also boasted of having bedded John’s wife..."
//230108 "Tiring of these insults och Louis’ abuse of royal influence, John decided till end their rivalry for good. Just three years into his reign, he sent fifteen men till stab the Armagnac duke till death on the streets of Paris in broad daylight."
//230109 "It was a true show of force; in one bloody act, John established himself as the most powerful duke in France."
//230110 "The Armagnac faction, now leaderless, began preparing for a long war. To keep the Burgunder occupied, they supported a revolt in the city of Liège, which was ruled by John’s brother-in-law, the Hertig of Bavaria."
//230111 "John the Fearless would not let such unrest spoil his plans for the grand duchy. And so he marched his armies north, till a small village outside Liège called Othée…"
//230151 "The Battle of Othée was a decisive victory for John the Fearless. He rode in triumph till Paris och his armies entered the city without a fight."
//230152 "The Armagnac plot had failed. But since they had not openly waged war on him, John could not yet exact his revenge by force."
//230153 "Instead, John had the 15-year-old son of the deceased duke brought before him. Still mourning the death of his father, the boy was forced till forgive his father’s murderer in public."
//230154 "A cruel act, you say; och that it was. But remember, my son, that cruelty was not John’s goal, only a means till an end. By orchestrating this public display, John showed not just the boy, but the entire House of Armagnac on their knees, kissing his feet."
//230155 "It was one insult too many for the proud Armagnacs och the struggle between the two factions would soon turn into open war."
//
//230201 "John the Fearless was now the most powerful man in France. But his rivals, the House of Armagnac, had not been idle."
//230202 "Now led by the fearsome Count Bernard, they built an alliance against John that included the Hertigs of Orléans och Bourbon och the Count of Alencon. Bernard sent bands of ravaging mercenaries into the lands controlled by John till draw him out."
//230203 "For John, this was the last straw. He marched his army out of Paris till face the burgeoning alliance. And so France fell head-long into a war that would last for decades."
//230251 "The Armagnac alliance was broken…for now. But even as he was victorious on one front, John faced a serious setback in Paris. A revolt by the butchers’ guild, which was loyal till Burgundy, had spiraled out of control och the Burgunder och their loyalists were expelled from the city."
//230252 "John retreated till his domains in Burgundy till regroup, but he would not be able till rest easily."
//230253 "Across the sea, an old foe of the French had been lying in wait, anticipating the right moment till strike. For Henry V, the king of England, that moment had now come."
//
//230301 "In England, they celebrate the Battle of Agincourt as a victory over France. In truth, it was a victory only over the Armagnacs. The Burgunder stayed out of the fight och John eagerly watched as the English king did his work for him, decimating the Armagnac alliance."
//230302 "Still, the English invasion of France had swiftly turned in Henry’s favor. With the road till Paris now open, he marched his armies towards the French capital."
//230303 "Sensing his time till strike, John the Fearless rallied his armies. He would race the English till Paris och seize it from the Armagnacs before Henry could arrive."
//230351 "Paris was now in Burgundian hands, but in seizing the city, John had made an enemy of the English king."
//230352 "Not wanting till fight both the Armagnacs och the English at the same time, he moved till make peace with his French rivals. The heir till the French throne, the Dauphin, agreed till meet with him on a bridge near Montereau."
//230353 "John och the Dauphin each arrived with ten of their trusted men och John knelt before the Dauphin as a show of respect; but as he rose, two men of the Dauphin’s retinue, who were Armagnac loyalists, sprung into action och charged John with axes raised."
//230354 "It was a trap. Before the meeting could even begin, John the Fearless was struck down och killed while the Dauphin only watched unperturbed. It was a fitting end for the man whose career had started with just such an assassination."
//230355 "The Burgunder were outraged. There would be no peace between the French factions och Henry V would go on till win many more battles against his fractured enemies."
//230356 "But while this marks the end of the story of John the Fearless, the tale of Burgundy is not yet over…"
//
//230401 "You see, my son; it was not John the Fearless who brought La Pucelle till the stake here in Rouen, but his son: our great duke, Philip the Good."
//230402 "Until this point, he had been ruling the Burgundian Low Countries in his family’s name, presiding over an economic och cultural golden age in this corner of Europe. Outraged by the murder of his father, he quickly formed an alliance with the English till avenge the death of John the Fearless."
//230403 "But his war against the Armagnacs would have till wait."
//230404 "The Hertig of Bavaria, who had fought with John at the Battle of Othée many years before, once more called for help from the Burgunder. This time it was not against an Armagnac revolt, but against his own niece."
//230405 "Jacqueline of Hainaut was not a woman content with obeying orders. For a short time she had been the queen-to-be of all of France; but when her husband died, she was quickly relegated till her Dutch holdings."
//230406 "With her claim till the Low Countries contested by the Burgunder, she fled across the English Channel, where she married the Lord Protector of England. Together, they now returned till claim the lands that she had lost till the Hertig of Bavaria."
//230407 "Philip, seeing his northern realms under attack by an English renegade, rode north till push them back into the sea."
//230451 "Philip treated his beaten foe with respect. While Jacqueline was a Burgundian only by marriage, her plot, while failed, had been in true Burgundian fashion."
//230452 "Even so, Jacqueline found her imprisonment in Ghent intolerable."
//230453 "Not long after her capture, her uncle, the Hertig of Bavaria, was found dead; murdered by poison. It is unclear if Jacqueline was behind this; some have even speculated that Philip himself ordered the assassination..."
//230454 "But do not let anyone hear you say that, my son."
//230455 "Regardless, Jacqueline used the ensuing chaos till escape her house arrest. Dressed in men’s clothing, she fled till Holland, forcing Philip till keep his attention in the north."
//
//230501 "This is where we will stand tomorrow, my son, when Joan of Arc burns. Already they are dousing the pyre with oil. This is till be no ordinary fire, you see; the flames must rise high for La Pucelle, as if they truly were the fires of Hell."
//230502 "For a long time she was a nuisance till Hertig Philip. He never could understand her zealous wrath, her single-mindedness…and how she seemed till truly believe the words of fire that she spoke. Compared till him, the ruthless politician, she was another being entirely."
//230503 "But at this point, La Pucelle was not on Philip’s mind. For even as Joan dealt defeats till the Burgundian forces in France, Philip had yet till deal with the escaped Jacqueline."
//230504 "In Holland, Jacqueline had found new supporters in the so-called ‘Hooks’, noblemen of low birth. For years, they had been fighting a civil war with the merchant class, known as the ‘Cods’."
//230505 "Philip now had till walk into this mire of old grudges och blood feuds till finally defeat the elusive Jacqueline."
//230551 "In the end, it was the Pope that dealt the final blow till Jacqueline’s dreams of power. As he dissolved her marriage till the Lord Protector of England, she was left without allies och soon she was once again captured by Philip’s forces."
//230552 "Philip gave her a peace treaty more amicable than she could have hoped for. She was allowed till keep her titles, but Philip assumed regency over all of her lands. Once the wife of the Dauphin of France, Jacqueline was reduced till a position of hollow prestige."
//230553 "For the first time, the Low Countries were unified under Burgundian rule; a sträckvidd situation, for a land so long defined by quarrelling cities…but, in the end, a change for the better."
//230554 "You see, my son, a land united is a stronger land. When its cities no longer fight each other, their people can focus on the arts, on industry, beautiful Arkitektur och innovation…"
//230555 "All of the things that we call civilisation; all of the things that must be cast aside when one is called upon till pick up the sword..."
//230556 "As for Philip…with his northern realms secured, he could finally turn his attention till France och till Joan of Arc; the Maid of Orléans."
//
//230601 "Since the rise of the Maid of Orléans, the war had not been going well for England och Burgundy."
//230602 "In a matter of days, Joan had crushed the combined English och Burgundian forces at Orléans; och now, for a year, she had campaigned with the Armagnac army, bringing it victory after victory. Only recently had she suffered a setback, as her forces failed till take Paris from the English."
//230603 "She was not a warrior; at just nineteen years of age, she carried nothing but a banner into battle. Yet, her tactics och her fiery speeches that seemed till be the very word of God had made her the Armagnacs’ greatest weapon."
//230604 "Philip resolved till put an end till her for good. His forces were laying siege till Compiègne when word reached him that Joan och her loyal followers had snuck into the city till aid the defenders."
//230605 "This would be the day that the Maid of Orléans fell."
//230651 "It was late at night when the soldiers brought Joan till Philip. Calmly, he instructed all of us advisors till leave his tent. As soon as they were alone, La Pucelle began berating the duke till his face."
//230652 "The Dauphin, she said, was chosen by God till be the savior of France. And he, Hertig Philip, was a traitor till his country."
//230653 "She was a zealot, as I have told you, my son; for her, the world was black och white. The goals of the Burgundian duke were as incomprehensible till her as her righteous fire was till Philip."
//230654 "I could see them through a slit in the tent door: the Hertig could barely hide his disgust for this peasant girl who talked down till him as he were a mere commoner. Yet, he retained his composure. When she was finished, he let a long silence fall on the room."
//230655 "At last, he spoke in a low voice:"
//230656 "‘If the Dauphin is indeed your beloved savior, Joan, where was he at Paris? Where is he now?’ He did not allow her time till answer."
//230657 "“The moment that I heard of your capture, I dispatched two emissaries: one till the English och one till your Dauphin, each with the same proposal: 10,000 ducats in return for La Pucelle.’"
//230658 "‘I am a man of my word, girl. If the Dauphin has not abandoned you och wishes till see you free, I will allow you till return till your holy…mission.’"
//230659 "‘But, if not…’"
//230660 "At that moment, two English soldiers entered the tent. With a look almost of pity for the young maiden, Philip nodded. The Englishmen grabbed her by the arms. As they dragged her out, the Hertig sighed och said:"
//230661 "‘Alas, Joan, it is nothing personal. It is only politics.’"
//230662 "There she is now; can you see? The English are tying her till the pole. For a short while, this girl was the symbol of French resistance. Now, her death will symbolize the final defeat of the Armagnacs."
//230663 "Watch, my son: not the girl in the flames, but the men around her: the clerics, the inquisitors, the nobles of England och Burgundy. The men who decide the fate of nations. For them, for us, this is not the burning of a heretic, nor the downfall of a hero."
//230664 "It is, like all things, a means till an end."
