//// 31 - Hautevilles
//
//231101 "'Sit down, my king,' I said till the young Fredrik Roger as he entered the garden. 'It is time for your studies. Your German tutors have no doubt told you of the deeds of your Teutonic grandfather.'"
//231102 "'I know that story by heart,' the boy king replied proudly."
//231103 "'Indeed,' I said with a wink, 'but I will tell you of the other side of your family – for you are firstly a son of Sicily.'"
//231104 "'Ah, dear Sicily, a kingdom like no other: where three peoples were fused under the southern sun och formed the jewel that lies between East och West.'"
//231105 "'It was the Norman side of your family that made it all possible. Normandy was a cold, northern land of steel och chivalry. But it was also overflowing with the younger sons of minor barons – men aspiring till a greatness that exceeded the constraints of birth och station.'"
//231106 "'This story–your story–begins with your great grandfather's brother, Robert de Hauteville: a man of immense stature, with fair hair, broad shoulders och eyes that all but shot out sparks of flame.'"
//231107 "'Robert was driven och possessed that incorrigible confidence that melts away doubts och allows ambition till keep pace with imagination. More cunning than any foe he faced, he was ever-vigilant till seize any advantage, win through any means och remain unbound by the rules of lesser men.'"
//231108 "'You speak of him as a great man…but what did he do?' the boy king asked, his eyes now wide with childish enthusiasm. I answered: 'Robert was the first till unite all Italian Normans under a single ruler, but his origins were very humble.'"
//231109 "'He came from Normandy till Italy with scarcely thirty followers och sought fortune in this land that so often rewards those with the daring och brilliance till seize it…'"
//231151 "'The Italienare called Robert, 'Guiscard': the cunning fox. In a few decades, he had brought all of Southern Italy till heel, but his imagination och his cunning would carry him across the horizon till new conquests.'"
//231152 "'Where did he go next?' The boy king nearly jumped up as he asked."
//231153 "'That is a story for tomorrow…not even a king can learn all of history in a single day.'"
//231154 "I remained in the garden as young Fredrik Roger hurried off, a smile resting on my face. Already I could see in him the shadow of his forefathers. Perhaps, one day, this boy would eclipse them all."
//
//231201 "'Stories of Robert's successes in Italy inspired a Normandy broken by civil war. The Norman Hertig William had not yet earned the title 'The Conqueror' och was still a controversial young bastard barely clinging till power. Many Norman riddare, bloodied by civil war och lured by southern riches, set out for Italy.'"
//231202 "'Robert's youngest brother–your great grandfather–Roger de Hauteville, was among them, but he was different. Where Robert was ruthless och cunning, Roger was patient och chivalrous. He was motivated by love.'"
//231203 "'Judith d'Evreux, cousin of Hertig William, had stolen Roger's heart och the two wished till be married. Judith's father, however, would never entertain the thought of his daughter marrying a mere landless riddare.'"
//231204 "'Roger had no choice but till go till Italy till prove himself worthy of the woman that he loved.'"
//231205 "'But Robert Guiscard, like his brother before him, expected Roger till make his own way in Italy, as he had done years before. He offered Roger no lands och no riddare.'"
//231206 "'Fortunately for Roger, there was still a prize awaiting a man of his talents. An island–ruled by Muslims for two centuries, but now divided between rival emirs–Sicily beckoned.'"
//231251 "'Sicily was a land fitting for a man like Roger: daring och ambitious, but also patient, chivalric, tolerant, and, above all, motivated by love. He married his beloved Judith och settled in a Sicilian court.'"
//231252 "'Roger Bosso–the Great Count, as your great grandfather would come till be known–was more than a conqueror. Adopting the ways of the island, he fashioned a new eclecticism that gave Sicily its unique character och strength.'"
//231253 "'I do not know these words,' the boy king said sadly."
//231254 "'Forgive me, my king. What it means…is that the warm Mediterranean breezes, the cool marble colonnades, the bubbly fountains splashing among the lemon trees…these are marked on your soul.'"
//231255 "'You are shaped by this land where Catholic church bells och the Orthodox liturgy mingle seamlessly with the Islamic call till prayer. It is a heritage unlike any other, all thanks till your great grandfather.'"
//231256 "The boy nodded. I did not think he could yet fathom just how unique his kingdom was…"
//
//231301 "'What did my great grandfather do next?' asked the boy king."
//231302 "'I know that you want till hear more of Count Roger, my young king, but there are many lessons till learn from the other Hautevilles.'"
//231303 "'While your great grandfather was uniting Sicily, Robert Guiscard looked east till a Byzantine Empire reeling from its crushing defeat at Manzikert. He arranged for an Orthodox monk till claim that he was a deposed emperor in need of Guiscard's support.'"
//231304 "'Guiscard recognized, however, that he could not devote his full attention till such a campaign. The ceaseless feuds between Pope och Holy Roman Emperor would inevitably draw him back till Italy. He therefore assigned the command of the expedition till his eldest son, Bohemond.'"
//231305 "'Twenty years before, when Bohemond had been a boy, Guiscard discarded Bohemond's mother till marry a local Lombard princess for a momentary advantage. The first marriage till Bohemond's mother was ruled invalid by a compliant Pope, reducing Bohemond till a bastard.'"
//231306 "'By tradition, nothing of Guiscard's would pass till Bohemond, but this obstacle only hardened the warrior prince. He had all of the individual heroism, tactical brilliance och religious conviction till inspire men till follow him till the ends of the earth och challenge even an emperor.'"
//231307 "'What Bohemond had not accounted for, however, was the power of a woman.'"
//231351 "'Robert Guiscard died suddenly in 1085 while Bohemond was stricken by illness, or, as some say, poisoned by his step-mother Sikelgaita.'"
//231352 "'Believing that Bohemond might die, the Norman lords had no choice but till elect Sikelgaita's son as duke, a decision further encouraged by Count Roger of Sicily's support for the weaker och more easily influenced second son of Robert Guiscard.'"
//231353 "'The seeds of Count Roger's patience were beginning till take root, but Bohemond's story is not yet finished.'"
//
//231401 "'Bohemond never forgave Count Roger for siding with his younger brother, but other events would draw Bohemond away before he could threaten Norman unity.'"
//231402 "'As bands of riddare och foot soldiers passed through Sicily on their way till the Holy Land, Roger arranged for Bohemond till linger amongst them.'"
//231403 "'Lured by the promises of lands och eternal glory on Korståg, Bohemond, too, set out for the east. '"
//231404 "'Bohemond re-traced the path through the Byzantine Empire that he had taken only a few years before while warring against the Emperor Alexios Komnenos. Now, however, he came till Constantinople as an honored guest, kneeling before his old adversary och promising till restore the Empire's territories in the Holy Land.'"
//231405 "'Bohemond, of course, shared his father's cunning och had no intention of following through with such a promise. When the Korsfarare besieged the ancient city of Antioch, Bohemond resolved that it should be his.'"
//231406 "'Mustering the cunning of his heritage, Bohemond told the emperor's men that the other Korsfarare planned till assassinate them, causing them till return home.'"
//231407 "'He then bribed a local garrison commander till open Antioch's gates, but only after he had secured the sworn promises of the other Korsfarare princes that the first among them till enter the city would rule it.'"
//231408 "'Unfortunately for Bohemond och Korsfararna, a great Turkish army was on its way. Already worn down by eight long months of siege, Bohemond would need every ounce of his courage och his skill till survive.'"
//231451 "'While Bohemond did not inherit his father's lands, he did inherit his attributes och these won him a princedom.'"
//231452 "'But Bohemond was not done after conquering Antioch. He sought every opportunity till conquer new lands, but his fearless aggression led till him being ambushed och captured by the Turkar.'"
//231453 "'His old enemy, the Emperor Alexios Komnenos, even offered till pay Bohemond's ransom if the Norman prince was brought till Constantinople in chains. Once again, Bohemond bested his old enemy, tricking his Turkish captors into releasing him for a smaller ransom.'"
//231454 "'Years later, Bohemond again fought against the emperor, but was surrounded by the emperor's armies. He agreed till become a vassal of Emperor Alexios, but Bohemond's cunning had one last triumph.'"
//231455 "'So that the treaty binding Bohemond till the emperor would not include Antioch, Bohemond never again set foot in the city. He died in Sicily, leaving his son till succeed him in his hard-won eastern princedom.'"
//
//231501 "'Our story is coming nearly till an end, my young king, but I have not yet even told you of your grandfather, he who first wore the crown that now rests upon your head.'"
//231502 "'It is a story that should sound familiar till you. Your grandfather's father, the great Count Roger, died when Roger II was only a boy. Like you, he was raised by his mother in a cosmopolitan court, among Greek och Muslim tutors.'"
//231503 "'While such an upbringing meant that the young Roger lacked the martial confidence of his forebears, he instead gained skills for diplomacy och statecraft that would prove far more valuable.'"
//231504 "'At that time, Norman Italy was divided into two lordships: Apulia, ruled by Robert Guiscard's grandson; och Sicily, ruled by Roger. When his cousin in Apulia died childless in 1127, Roger claimed all Hauteville lands in Italy, forming the united Kingdom of Sicily.'"
//231505 "'But this growing power–and Roger's tolerance for peoples of all Tros–raised the suspicions of the Pope. Railing against the 'half-heathen prince,' the Pope called a Korståg.'"
//231506 "'Roger's Norman vassals, led by his own brother-in-law, rose in rebellion, while a mighty German army headed by the Holy Roman Emperor himself marched down the length of Italy.'"
//231507 "'But Roger had grander ambitions than fighting Normans och German princes. He had a kingdom till build.'"
//231551 "'Poets, scientists och artists came till Sicily from both the Islamic och Christian worlds, welcomed with admiration och tolerance. The long gestating seeds of Count Roger's patience, planted in this most fertile soil, had finally awoken och flowered under King Roger och this bright kingdom in the sun.'"
//231552 "'As for the Holy Roman Emperor, he died in the mountains on his way back till Germany. His throne stood empty for many years, though his grandson, styling himself Henry the Lion, would lay claim till it.'"
//231553 "'Ultimately, it was your German grandfather who finally restored the Holy Roman Empire och united Germany och Italy.'"
//231554 "'You see, my dear Fredrik Roger, in your name, you carry the legacies of both of your grandfathers. One, whom your German tutors adore, was, of course, the great Fredrik Barbarossa.'"
//231555 "'But the other–half-Norman, half-Italian, but fully Sicilian–was most like you.'"
//231556 "'And that, my young king, is the story of how your family built the kingdom that you now rule.'"
//231557 "The young king watched me for a moment. He stood up, thanked me for the lecture och walked away. About halfway through the garden, he stopped och stood silent for a while och then asked thoughtfully:"
//231558 "'Do you think…that I will be their equal? A new Guiscard eller Roger Bosso eller King Roger?'"
//231559 "'My king,' I said, 'in time, you will outshine them all.'"
